The keeping and maintaining of permitted animals in the R-2, R-3, R-4 and R-5 zoning districts of the city shall conform to the standards relating to proper care and maintenance as found in section 6-18 and other requirements of this article. 
(h)  B district regulations. The keeping and maintaining of animals in the B zoning district shall be limited to security animals and animals in commercial kennels, pet shops, pet hospitals or pet grooming shops. 
(i)  I district regulations. The keeping and maintaining of animals in the I zoning district shall be limited to keeping and maintaining security animals. 
(j)  FF district regulations. The keeping and maintaining of animals in the FF zoning district shall be limited to security animals and animals in commercial kennels, pet shops, pet hospitals or pet grooming shops. 
(Code 1984, § 430:84; Ord. No. 09-02, § 4, 1-5-2009; Ord. No. 10-01, § 3, 1-19-2010) 
Sec. 6-18. - Standards for keeping and maintaining animals. 
(a)  Statutes adopted by reference. Minn. Stats. §§ 343.20-343.36 relating to cruelty to animals are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in and made a part of this article as though fully set forth in this section. 
(b)  Federal regulations adopted by reference. The Code of Federal Regulations relating to humane handling, care, treatment and transportation of animals, being 9 CFR 1, is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in and made a part of this article as though fully set forth in this section. 
(c)  Animal restraint. In all situations in the R-A and R-1 zoning districts where animals of the hoofed variety or the fowl family are permitted to roam and/or graze about the property, a suitable fencing system shall be in place so as to restrain the animals roaming and/or grazing to the property of the person keeping or maintaining the animals. 
(1)  The fence shall be of sufficient type so as to effectively control the animals therein and to prevent an animal from crossing the boundaries established by the fence. 
(2)  Such fence shall also be in compliance with all fencing specifications as set forth in section 36-816. 
(3)  In addition, neither such fence nor any animal shelter or stabling facility shall be any closer than 75 feet from any structure which is used for residential purposes and is not the residential structure of the animal owner or keeper. 
(d)  Animal stabling. All areas where animals are to be kept, stabled or maintained shall be of adequate space to maintain such animals in reasonably healthy condition and comfort, and the space shall be in compliance with the requirements of this Code. In no instance shall any one horse, colt or pony be kept in an area that is less than one undivided acre. 
(e)  Pollution of public water. The keeping, storing, stabling or maintenance of any animal in any district shall not directly contribute to the pollution of any public body of water. 
(f)  Sanitary conditions. 
(1)  Any person who owns, keeps, harbors, or has charge or control of a dog shall immediately collect and remove any and all feces deposited by the dog on public property or on private property not occupied by or under the control of that person. 
(2)  While such a person is with any such dog on property not occupied by or under the control of that person, such person shall have in his immediate physical possession a means to collect and sanitarily dispose of all the dog's fecal matter deposited on public property or the private property of another. 
(3)  Any person who owns, keeps, harbors, or has charge or control of a dog in or upon premises or land occupied by, or under the control of, that person shall frequently collect and remove any accumulation of dog fecal matter that is unhealthy or offensive to any person or neighborhood. 
(4)  The premises on which any animal is kept or maintained shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall not be a harbor for rodents, flies, or insects. 
(Code 1984, § 430:87) 
Sec. 6-19. - Dead animals. 
    Disposal of dead animals is regulated as follows: 
(1)  The term "body" does not include the ashes of a cremated animal. 
(2)  The body of any animal that dies in the city shall, within 24 hours of death, be cremated, removed from the city, or buried in accordance with the terms of this section. No animal weighing more than 100 pounds shall be buried in the city except as provided in subsection (4) of this section. 
(3)  Burial of an animal shall be at a minimum depth of at least three feet and in a manner designed so as to prevent exposure of the carcass by erosion, the digging by other animals, or any other reasonably foreseeable act or occurrence. No animal shall be buried in any area deemed by the city to pose a threat to the public's health, safety or welfare, such as low swampy areas, areas which may be subject to flooding, areas in close proximity to any water table, or under any other conditions, soil or otherwise, which could create the potential threat to the public's health, safety or welfare, unless proof acceptable to the city is provided showing that any such condition present or likely to be present will not pose such a threat or will be neutralized so as to substantially eliminate such a threat. 
(4)  Dead animals may be buried in a pet or animal cemetery established within the city with the consent of the city council. Burials shall be made in such cemetery pursuant to such terms and conditions as are established by the council and the owner of the cemetery. 
(5)  No person shall assist in, countenance or allow any interment or deposit of a dead animal or any other activity in violation of provisions of this section. 
(Code 1984, § 430:90) 
Sec. 6-20. - Wild animal feeding prohibitions. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section of the City Code is to protect the community from the problems associated with the feeding of wild animals. 
(b)  Feeding of non-domesticated animals prohibited; exceptions. 
(1)  Prohibition. No person shall feed or allow the feeding of any wild animal within any area of the city. For the purpose of this section, feeding shall mean provision of one-cubic foot or more of grain, fruit, vegetables, nuts, hay or other edible material, either on the ground or at a height of less than five feet above the ground, in a manner that attracts wild animals on a regular basis. Living food sources, such as fruit trees and other live vegetation, shall not be considered as feed. 
(2)  Exceptions. This prohibition shall not apply to veterinarians, city animal control officers, or city, county state, or federal game officials who are in the course of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 05-36, § 1, 10-17-2005; Ord. No. 07-01, § 1, 4-16-2007) 
Secs. 6-21-6-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOG AND CAT LICENSES 

Sec. 6-41. - Generally; rabies vaccination. 
(a)  All dogs, cats, and ferrets must have a certificate issued by a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine confirming that the dog, cat, or ferret has been vaccinated against rabies, and that such vaccination is effective on the date the certificate is presented. 
(b)  Any dog, cat, or ferret found not to be currently vaccinated against rabies shall be subject to immediate impoundment, and its owner or any person who claims the animal shall pay, in addition to the fees and charges authorized in section 6-8, the actual cost of any rabies vaccination administered the animal by or at the direction of the city's agent. 
(c)  No dog, cat, or ferret shall be released from impoundment by the city's agent, regardless of reason for impoundment, until the certificate required in this subsection has been supplied or other adequate proof has been furnished to the city ensuring compliance with the vaccination requirement. 
(Code 1984, § 430:06; Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-42. - Identification required. 
(a)  Dog and cat owners are no longer required to obtain an animal license for their pet. 
(b)  All dogs, cats, and ferrets are required to have some identification on them. Identification allowed under this subdivision includes microchips, veterinarian issued rabies tags, or any tags or collars with contact information and phone number(s) inscribed on it. 
(Code 1984, § 430:09; Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 6-43. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2012, deleted § 6-43, which pertained to tags not transferable and refunds of license fees and derived from Code 1984, § 430:12. 
Sec. 6-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2012, deleted § 6-44, which pertained to counterfeiting tags and derived from Code 1984, § 430:15. 
Sec. 6-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-16, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2012, deleted § 6-45, which pertained to licensing agents and derived from Code 1984, § 430:33.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 8-1-8-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State building code, Minn. Stats. § 16B.59 et seq. 

Sec. 8-31. - Minnesota State Building Code. 
(a)  Codes adopted by reference. The Minnesota State Building Code, as adopted by the Commissioner of Labor and Industry pursuant to Minn. Stats. §§ 16B.59 to 16B.75, including all of the amendments, rules and regulations established, adopted and published from time to time by the Minnesota Commissioner of Labor and Industry, through the Building Codes and Standards Unit, is hereby adopted by reference with the exception of the optional chapters, unless specifically adopted in this ordinance. The Minnesota State Building Code is hereby incorporated in this section as if fully set out herein. 
(1)  Application, administration and enforcement. The application, administration, and enforcement of the code shall be in accordance with the Minnesota State Building Code. The code shall be enforced within the extraterritorial limits permitted by Minn. Stats. § 16B.62, subd. 1, when so established by this section. The code enforcement agency of this municipality is called the building inspection services department. This code shall be enforced by the Minnesota Certified Building Official designated by this Municipality to administer the code (Minn. Stats; § 16B.65, subd. 1). 
(2)  Permits and fees. The issuance of permits and the collection of fees shall be as authorized in Minn. Stats. § 16B.62, subd. 1. Permit fees shall be assessed for work governed by this code in accordance with the fee schedule adopted by the municipality in City Code Chapter 16. In addition, a surcharge fee shall be collected on all permits issued for work governed by this code in accordance with Minn. Stats. § 16B.70. 
(3)  Violations and penalties. A violation of the code is a misdemeanor (Minn. Stats. § 16B.69). 
(4)  Building code optional chapters. The Minnesota State Building Code, established pursuant to Minn. Stats. §§ 16B.59 to 16B.75 allows the municipality to adopt by reference and enforce certain optional chapters of the most current edition of the Minnesota State Building Code. The following optional provisions identified in the most current edition of the State Building Code are hereby adopted and incorporated as part of the building code for this municipality: 
a.  Chapter 1306, Special Fire Protection Systems, subpart 3. 
b.  Chapter 1335, Floodproofing Regulations, parts 1335.0600 to 1335.1200 
(b)  Certificate of survey required. Any permit application for construction of a new building or expansion of an existing building shall be accompanied by a certificate of survey. The certificate of survey required by this article shall contain all the following information: 
(1)  Scale of the drawing and a thorough legal description of the property. 
(2)  Names of all abutting streets, dimensions of all lot lines, and dimensions and locations of all easements of record. 
(3)  Locations of all existing buildings on the subject lots. 
(4)  Location of sanitary and storm manholes, hydrants, catch basins, power poles, telephone boxes and curb lines. 
(5)  Location, including front and side yard setback dimensions to buildings located on adjacent lots. 
(6)  Location, including front, side and rear yard setback dimensions to the proposed structure. 
(7)  Outside dimensions of proposed structures. 
(8)  The type of building. 
(9)  Location of stakes established by the surveyor along each side lot line at the proposed front and rear building line. 
(10)  Benchmark description, elevation and location. 
(11)  Grade of elevations to meet sea level datum (1929 NVGD) at the following points: 
a.  Existing and proposed at each lot corner. 
b.  Crown of street at each lot line extended or top of curb. 
c.  Existing and proposed of all major corners of proposed structure. 
d.  Proposed lowest floor. 
e.  Proposed garage floor. 
f.  Proposed top of foundation. 
g.  The top and toe of all other slopes. 
h.  The proposed midpoints or proposed critical points along each property line. 
i.  Any break in grade on adjoining lots within 25 feet of the property line of the subject lot. 
j.  Existing proposed elevations at any point along the property line intersected by an adjoining property line. 
k.  Top of foundation of any existing buildings located on adjacent lots. 
(12)  Proposed retaining walls to be constructed as part of the final grading, including top and bottom elevations. 
(13)  The proposed disposal of drainage and surface water indicating direction of surface water drainage by arrows. 
(14)  Garage notation, driveway location and percent slope of driveway. 
(15)  Proposed slope or grades of ground for a distance of no less than 25 feet in front of and in back of the proposed structure. 
(16)  All existing wetlands, ponds, streams and lakes. 
(17)  Proposed erosion control measures. 
(18)  Signature of registered surveyor. 
(19)  Registration number of surveyor. 
(c)  Building official. For purposes of this section, the director of building inspection services is the building official of the city. The director of building inspection services is responsible for the administration or the Minnesota State Building Code, and shall be a state certified "building official". 
(d)  Licensed activities. 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, it is unlawful for any person to perform any work subject to the provisions of the building code unless he or she is currently licensed to do so under applicable provisions of this Code of Ordinances and state law. Such work, includes, but is not limited to, electrical installations, plumbing, high pressure steam fitting installation and elevator construction. 
(2)  Exceptions: 
a.  An owner of any building is not required to be licensed under this section in order to personally perform any general construction work not involving plumbing, mechanical, gas fitting, electrical, or fire suppression systems, when such work is in connection with the owner's building or appurtenance, including the right of the owner to engage the services of any aids or helpers. 
b.  An owner of a residence may do plumbing work without a license on premises or that part of premises owned and actually occupied by the owner as a residence. 
c.  An owner may perform electrical work without a license on premises the person owns and actually occupies as a residence or owns and will occupy as a residence upon completion of construction. 
When otherwise exempt by local ordinance or state law. 
(e)  Copies on file with the city clerk. Official copies of the documents referred to herein and the documents incorporated with the Minnesota State Building Code shall be on file in the city clerk's office and marked official copies for anyone wishing to examine said copies upon the premises of city hall during city business hours. 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 1, 4-7-2003; Ord. No. 07-18, § 1, 8-20-2007) 
Secs. 8-32-8-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOVING, DEMOLITION, ERECTION OR ALTERATION OF BUILDINGS; TEMPORARY BUILDINGS AND PARKING LOTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 28. 

Sec. 8-61. - Permit required. 
    No person shall erect, wreck, move into the city or move out of the city, or move within the city any building or portion thereof nor convert an accessory building into a commercial or residential building without first securing a permit therefore from the city council, which may grant or deny such permit solely at its own discretion. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(1); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(a)), 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 8-62. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for each permit required in this section shall be as set forth in chapter 16, article V. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(2); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(b)), 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 8-63. - Performance bond. 
(a)  Before a permit may be issued pursuant to this section, the owner of any building or property which is the subject of such a permit shall post with the city a performance bond acceptable to the city and in an amount as determined by the director of inspections. Said bond shall be conditioned upon the satisfactory completion of the purpose(s) for which a permit is issued, all requirements, terms, and conditions attached to any such permit and the requirements of all applicable laws, city ordinances and regulations. The said performance bond shall be returned to the applicant or the bonding company upon the satisfactory completion of the bond conditions. 
(b)  A cash deposit, letter of credit or other form of surety satisfactory to the city may be deposited at the city's option in lieu of the said performance bond. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(3); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(c)), 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 8-64. - Application for permit. 
    Each application to move any building into or around within the city shall be written and presented to the director of inspections. The applicant must furnish a recent photograph or photographs of the building, along with the application, which photograph or photographs shall clearly show the building proposed to be moved. Each application shall state: 
(1)  The exact then location of any building proposed to be so moved; 
(2)  The exact location of the land where the building is proposed to be moved; 
(3)  The owner of such lands; 
(4)  The owner of such building; 
(5)  The methods proposed for moving such building; 
(6)  The person or firm which will be moving the building; 
(7)  The proposed route of travel for such moving, within the city; and 
(8)  Any additional information the city may from time to time require. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(4); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(d)), 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 8-65. - Inspection and recommendation. 
(a)  If the applicant has made proper application, posted the necessary performance bond, and paid the non-refundable inspection fee required in chapter 16 of this Code, the director of inspections shall thoroughly inspect the subject building and shall report his findings to the city council and make appropriate recommendations as to the issuance of a permit. The report shall determine whether the building can be safely moved, whether it meets the building requirements of the ordinances of the city, and whether it can be improved at its proposed destination to acceptable building standards. 
(b)  The city council shall approve or deny said application after reviewing said report of the director of fire and building inspection services. 
(1)  Any permit approved by the city council shall be conditioned upon the successful rehabilitation of the structure, within a period (as specifically designated by the council) of up to six months of the date of issuance of the permit, to acceptable building standards at its proposed destination, and upon such other terms as the council may deem appropriate. 
(2)  If an application is denied the reasons for the denial shall appear in the record of the council's deliberations. 
(c)  All buildings moved into or within the city shall, after being removed, comply with the provisions of this Code including, without limitation, construction, location, use, setback, garage and sidewalk requirements. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(5); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(e)), 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 8-66. - Expiration and non-transferability of permits. 
    All such permits for moving buildings shall expire 120 days after issuance, subject to renewal by the director of inspections only in instances where he is satisfied that extenuating circumstances exist. Any moving permit shall apply only to the subject building and shall not be transferable by the person to whom originally issued. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(6); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(f)), 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 8-67. - Temporary buildings and parking lots. 
(a)  Permit for use in excess of 30 days. Prior to locating railroad coaches, box cars, street cars, bus bodies, trailers, construction sheds, or similar conveyances or structures on any property, improvement or unimproved, in excess of 30 days, a special permit authorizing said act and location shall first be obtained from the city building official. 
(1)  No permit is required for any such conveyance or structure actively used for current demonstrable construction purposes if located on the specific lot or property being improved. Examples of such would include construction office trailers and trailers containing plumbing or electrical supplies at the site of a building under construction. 
(2)  If the conveyance or structure is used for construction purposes in connection with the improvement of any lot or property other than the one on which it is located (such as in a housing development where several homes are simultaneously under construction) or is not actively being used for current demonstrable construction purposes where it is located, the permit requirements of section 8-61 shall apply. As to residential construction, such structures must be located in the plat or subdivision being constructed or improved. 
(3)  Permits shall expire upon the earliest of the following occurrences: 
a.  Completion of the residential subdivision; 
b.  Issuance by the city of a certificate of occupancy for nonresidential construction; 
c.  Expiration of one year from their issuance. 
(b)  Temporary parking lots. Prior to locating or establishing a temporary parking lot on any property for use in excess of 30 days, a special permit authorizing said act and location shall first be obtained from the city council. Such a permit shall expire at such time as the council deems appropriate but not longer than three years after its issuance. The council may require a surety in an amount and form satisfactory to the council, to assure that the land on which the parking lot is located is restored to its previous condition or better. The council may also, either prior to its issuance or during its term impose such conditions upon said permit as it deems reasonably necessary for the protection of the public's health, safety and welfare. 
(c)  Permit fees. The fee for permits issued pursuant to this section shall be as set forth in chapter 16 of this Code. 
(d)  Renewal of permit. Except for permits issued pursuant to subsection (c) above, permits issued pursuant to this section may be renewed with the approval of the issuing authority and upon payment of the fee referred to in subsection (e) of this section. Permits issued pursuant to subsection (c) of this section may also be renewed providing the fee is paid and providing further that the total time the permit, together with its renewals if any, may allow the temporary parking lot to exist shall not exceed three years. The expiration date of any permit shall appear thereon, but the lack of said date shall not extend the period of the permit beyond the limits set forth in the paragraph of this section under which the permit was issued. 
(e)  Granting of permits; appeals. The permits, renewals, and conditions provided for in this section may be granted or denied solely at the discretion of the issuing authority subject to the appeal procedures set forth in this Code. 
(Code 1984, § 300:05(7); Ord. No. 03-10, § 1(8-32(g)), 4-7-2003; Ord. No. 07-18, § 1, 8-20-2007) 
Secs. 8-68-8-90. - Reserved.

Sec. 8-91. - Compliance with state law.

(Code 1984, § 300:10)

ARTICLE V. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 8-121. - Property maintenance code. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted as the property maintenance code of the city, the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 as published by the International Code Council. A copy of said document shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(1)  Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said International Property Maintenance Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed below. 
(2)  Where there is any conflict between the provisions of the International Property Maintenance Code and any other applicable code or ordinance enforced by the city, the more restrictive provision shall apply. Where the conflict involves definitions and neither is necessarily more restrictive than the other, the definition set forth in the code or ordinance which more particularly addresses the subject at hand shall apply. 
(3)  The International Property Maintenance Code is amended and revised in the following respects. 
a.  Section 101.1 is amended by inserting "City of Maple Grove" in the brackets. 
b.  The definition of "code official" set forth in section 202.0 shall read as follows: The building official, who is charged with the administration and enforcement of this code, or any duly authorized representative. 
c.  Section 303.2 is amended by replacing "24 inches (610 mm)" with "18 inches (457 mm)". 
d.  At section 304.14 the following dates shall be inserted in this order in the first two lines: 
May 1  October 15 
e.  Section 602.2 is hereby amended in its entirety to read as follows: 
602.2. Residential Buildings: Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are properly installed, and which are maintained in safe and good working condition, and which are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and water closet compartments located therein to a temperature of at least 68 degrees Fahrenheit at a distance of three feet above floor level and three feet from exterior walls at an outside temperature of minus 25 degrees Fahrenheit. 
f.  In the fifth line of section 602.3 and the third line of section 602.4 the following dates shall be inserted in the following order: 
January 1  December 31 
g.  Section 110.0 is deleted. 
h.  The sixth line of section 605.2 shall be amended by deleting the word "new". 
i.  Chapter 8 is amended by substituting the following as the third sentence: The standards referenced below will only apply in those situations not covered by codes, rules and regulations referred to in section 18-71 et seq., and 8-31 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Maple Grove, Minnesota, or not otherwise governed by codes, rules or regulations adopted and enforced by the State of Minnesota. 
(4)  Nothing in this section or in the property maintenance code hereby adopted shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding impending in any court, or any rights acquired, or liability incurred, or any cause or causes of action acquired or existing, under any other code or ordinance enforced by or in the city, nor shall any just or legal right or remedy of any character be lost, impaired, or affected by this section. 
(Ord. No. 03-10, § 2, 4-7-2003; Ord. No. 12-04, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
Secs. 8-121-8-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTRICAL INSTALLATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 34. 

Sec. 8-151. - Inspection required. 
    Any person making in the city a new electrical installation governed by the provisions of the Minnesota Electrical Act, Minn. Stats. §§ 326.241-326.248, shall request inspection of such work by the city before commencement of any installation required to be inspected. Such request shall be made according to standardized procedures specified by the building official. 
(Code 1984, § 302:00) 
Sec. 8-152. - Filing of copy of state license. 
    Each person doing in the city electrical work governed by this article shall file with the city before commencement of any such work a copy of that person's current license issued by the state board of electricity pursuant to the Minnesota Electrical Act or such other evidence of such license as may be provided by the board. This requirement may be satisfied by the submission of a written statement signed and dated by the person required to make such filing that the required license or evidence thereof was previously filed with the city, the address in connection with which that information was filed, and that all the information contained on the license or evidence thereof is still current. 
(Code 1984, § 302:05) 
Sec. 8-153. - Inspection fees. 
    No requested inspection will be made under this article until the applicant has paid to the city the required inspection fees as set forth in chapter 16. 
(Code 1984, § 302:10) 
Sec. 8-154. - Violations. 
    The activities described as crimes in Minn. Stats. § 326.246 shall also constitute violations of this article when committed with reference thereto. 
(Code 1984, § 302:15) 
Sec. 8-155. - Electrical inspector. 
(a)  Pursuant to authority set forth in Minn. Stats. § 326.244, subd. 4, and the Minnesota Electrical Act, the city hereby creates the position of electrical inspector. 
(b)  Whether the person filling the position of electrical inspector is an employee of the city shall be determined by the terms of his employment agreement. 
(c)  As directed by the terms of his employment agreement, the electrical inspector shall inspect new electrical installations for compliance with the Minnesota Electrical Act, the ordinances of the city, and accepted standards of construction for safety to life and property. 
(d)  The electrical inspector must be a licensed master or journeyman electrician under Minn. Stats. § 326.242, subd. 1(1) or 2(1), and may not otherwise engage or be employed in the sale or installation of electrical wiring, devices, appliances or equipment, and shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in any such business. 
(e)  The electrical inspector shall report to the building official, who shall be responsible for the enforcement and administration of the laws, ordinances and standards referred to in subsection (c) of this section. 
(f)  In addition to any powers or duties given the electrical inspector, the inspector shall have the powers and duties set forth in Minn. Stats. § 326.244, subd. 2(d) and (e). For purposes of administering those statutes, any reference to the "board" shall mean the city. 
(Code 1984, § 302:20) 
Secs. 8-156-8-180. - Reserved.
