ARTICLE IX. - SWIMMING POOLS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Insurance requirements for public and semi-public swimming pools, § 16-434. 
State Law reference- Public pools, Minn. Stats. § 144.1222; municipal pools, Minn. Stats. § 471.15. 

Sec. 8-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director of fire and building inspection services means the individual duly appointed and entitled by the city council. 
    Portable swimming pool means any body of water contained in a rubber or plastic vessel which can be erected without permanent support. 
    Residential swimming pool means any pool which is used, or intended to be used, with a single-family residence, and available only to the family of the householder or his private guests. 
    Semipublic swimming pool means any swimming pool other than a residential swimming pool. 
    Swimming pool means any body of water contained by steel, concrete or fiberglass vessel and includes, but is not limited to, a portable swimming pool, such swimming pools being used for swimming or bathing, and capable of containing over 18 inches in water depth, or with a surface area exceeding 150 square feet. 
    Swimming pool construction fence means a fence constructed according to the specifications in section 8-255(11). This fence shall apply to swimming pool construction only. 
(Code 1984, § 355:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-252. - Permit requirements; submission of plans. 
(a)  Before work is commenced on the construction of a swimming pool, or any alteration, addition, remodeling, repair or other improvement to a swimming pool in excess of the value of $500.00, two sets of plans and specifications and pertinent explanatory data shall be submitted to the director of fire and building inspection services for approval relative to design, operation and maintenance insofar as health and safety features are concerned in accordance with the standards prescribed by this article. Individual permits shall be obtained from the director of fire and building inspection services for pool installation, plumbing installations and gas line and/or gas-related mechanical installations. 
(b)  Plans, specifications and pertinent explanatory data required to be submitted with an application for a permit to construct a swimming pool or any alteration, addition, remodeling or other improvement to a swimming pool shall comply with the provisions of this article and include the following plans and information as well as such other data as may be reasonably requested by the director of fire and building inspection services: 
(1)  Plans which shall show, but not be limited to showing, the general layout of the entire building lot on which the pool is to be located, distances of the pool from the lot lines, required fence system around the pool, water supply systems, buried sewers and sewage systems, utilities (electric, gas, telephone, etc.), or other sources of contamination within 50 feet of the pool and shall be drawn to a scale of not smaller than one-fourth inch to equal one foot, indicating all dimensions, including the effective length, width, and depth of the pool and width of the pool deck and similar items. 
(2)  Pipe diagrams showing material and size of all pipes, inlets, outlets, make-up water lines, vacuum lines, waste and discharge lines, circulation and other piping. 
(3)  Source of water supply. 
(Code 1984, § 355:05) 
Sec. 8-253. - Permit fees. 
    The fee for a swimming pool permit shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 16, article V. 
(Code 1984, § 355:10) 
Sec. 8-254. - Construction to be in accordance with approved plan. 
    All swimming pools, appurtenances, water supply and drainage systems and other features shall be constructed in conformity with the approved plans. If any deviations from such plans are desired, a supplementary plan covering that portion of the work involved shall be filed for approval and shall conform to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 355:15) 
Sec. 8-255. - General design and construction requirements. 
    Swimming pool design and construction shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Structural design. The pool structure shall be engineered and designed to withstand the expected forces to which it will be subjected. 
(2)  Overflow and surface drainage. The pool and surrounding area shall be constructed and arranged in such a manner that no splash or overflow water shall return to the pool. No surface or roof drainage shall be permitted to enter the pool. 
(3)  Handholds. Handholds shall be provided and shall not be more than nine inches above the water line and shall extend around the entire periphery of the pool. 
(4)  Pool deck. 
a.  Unobstructed areas of not less than 48 inches wide shall be provided to extend entirely around the pool. The deck shall be designed so as to prevent back drainage into the pool. 
b.  If deck drains are provided, drain pipe lines shall be at least two inches in diameter. Drain openings shall have an open area of at least four times the cross-sectional area of the drain pipe. 
c.  The deck drain system shall have indirect connection to the sanitary sewer and shall not be connected to the recirculation system piping. 
d.  No deck, other than the ground surface, shall be required for aboveground pools. 
(5)  Filters. Where a swimming pool or portable swimming pool is equipped with a filter, all pressure filter systems shall be equipped with an air release at the high point in the system. Where dissimilar metals are used in the construction of the filter, suitable provisions shall be made to resist the electrolytic corrosion. 
(6)  Pumps. When the pumping equipment is installed above ground level below the overflow level of the pool as may be dictated by the contour of the plot on which the pool is constructed, a valve shall be installed on the main suction line located in an accessible place outside of the walls of the pool. 
(7)  Pool piping. The piping system shall be constructed in accordance with the Minnesota State Plumbing Code. The piping shall be sized to permit the rated flows for filtering and cleaning without exceeding the maximum head at which the pump will provide such flows. The recirculation piping and fittings, where vacuum fittings are provided, shall be located in accessible positions below the water line. 
(8)  Water supply. 
a.  Water supplies serving all swimming pools or portable swimming pools shall be of a safe sanitary quality or otherwise acceptable to the director of fire and building inspection services. Suitable facilities for adding make-up water as needed shall be provided. 
b.  There shall be no physical connection between the water supply line and pool system. 
c.  If the make-up water is added directly to the pool, the fill spout shall be at least six inches above the upper rim of the pool. 
d.  If the make-up water line discharges to a surge or balancing tank, the point of discharge shall be least six inches above the rim of the tank. 
e.  If a hose connection from a sill cock or other plumbing fixture is to be used for supplying make-up water, then an approved vacuum breaker shall be installed between the sill cock or control valve at the fixture and the hose connection. 
f.  Any sill cock used for this service shall be installed above the ground level. 
g.  No over-the-rim spout will be acceptable unless located under a diving board or installed in a manner approved by the director of fire and building inspection services. 
(9)  Drainage. 
a.  The main outlets, for purposes of recirculation and emptying swimming pools, shall be so located as to provide at least one outlet at the deepest point in the pool if the pool width does not exceed 20 feet. If the pool width is more than 20 feet, multiple outlets shall be provided and spaced not more than 20 feet apart, and not more than ten feet from walls. 
b.  All main outlets shall be equipped with gratings having an area of openings not less than four times the cross-sectional area of the outlet pipe. The gratings shall be of such design so that they cannot be readily removable by bathers and will not injure bathers' fingers. 
c.  Swimming pools shall be equipped with facilities for completely emptying the pool and other drainage by gravity if elevations permit, and the discharge of the pool water to the sanitary sewer is readily available, or other suitable means of disposal acceptable to the director of fire and building inspection services, at a rate not exceeding 250 gallons per minute. No direct connection shall be made to the sewer. The outlet from the pool recirculation system shall terminate at least six inches above the receptacle connected to the sewer. 
d.  The drainage system shall be constructed in conformance with the provisions of the Minnesota State Plumbing Code and under the supervision of a licensed plumber. 
(10)  Heaters. Gas-fired swimming pool and portable swimming pool heaters and boilers shall bear the American Gas Association seal of approval. Oil-burning equipment shall bear the Underwriters' Laboratory, Inc., seal of approval. 
(11)  Construction fence. No person shall introduce or cause to be introduced any water to a depth of more than 18 inches into the shallowest portion of any swimming pool newly constructed or being constructed until such time as the director of fire and building inspection services authorizes the filling of such pool with water. Such authorization shall be withheld until, as a minimum, the permittee has caused such pool to be completely enclosed by a swimming pool construction fence. The construction fence shall: 
a.  Be of snow fence like or similar design and be securely anchored in place. 
b.  Be constructed with its base flush to the ground. 
c.  Be at least four feet in height and have supportive posts placed no more than eight feet apart. 
d.  Remain in place until a permanent fence completely enclosing the swimming pool is installed by or at the direction of the permittee pursuant to specifications as set forth in section 8-258 and section 36-816, and the permanent fence is approved by the director of fire and building inspection services. Such installation and approval shall be achieved no later than ten days after the director of fire and building inspection services authorizes the filling of the pool with water. 
(12)  Permanent fence; final inspection and approval. No swimming pool, even though containing water for construction purposes, shall be occupied or used at any time prior to installation by or at the direction of the permittee of a permanent fence complying with the provisions of this article and the final inspection and approval of the pool and permanent fence by the director of fire and building inspection services. 
(Code 1984, § 355:20) 
Sec. 8-256. - Electrical requirements; lighting. 
(a)  All electrical installations and current-carrying electrical conductors for swimming pools shall conform to the Minnesota State Electrical Code. 
(b)  All metal fences, enclosures, or railings near or adjacent to residential swimming pools which might become electrically alive as a result of contact with broken overhead conductors, or from any other cause, shall be effectively grounded. 
(c)  Lights used to illuminate any outdoor pool shall be so arranged and shaded as to reflect light away from adjoining premises. 
(Code 1984, § 355:25) 
Sec. 8-257. - Disinfecting method. 
    Gaseous chlorinated systems shall not be used as a disinfecting method for residential swimming pools or portable swimming pools. 
(Code 1984, § 355:30) 
Sec. 8-258. - Fences. 
(a)  Required. All swimming pools or portable swimming pools of a water depth greater than 18 inches shall be completely enclosed by a type of fence resistant to being climbed unless specifically exempted in this section. 
(b)  General standards. All fence openings or points of entry into the pool area enclosure shall be equipped with gates. The fence shall comply with all construction specifications pursuant to this section and section 36-816. Where conflicting requirements exist between ordinances, the requirements as specified in this section shall prevail. 
(c)  Dimensions; materials; gates; posts. 
(1)  The fence and gates shall be at least four feet in height and shall be constructed of a minimum no. 11 gauge woven wire mesh corrosion-resistant material, or other materials approved by the director of fire and building inspection services. 
(2)  One gate shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices placed at the top of the gate or otherwise inaccessible to small children. Any other gate in the fence will be presumed to be solely for maintenance purposes and shall remain locked at all times when not used for maintenance purposes. Each such maintenance gate shall bear a sign complying with chapter 24 and approved by the director of fire and building inspection services, which sign conveys the message that the gate is to remain locked and is for maintenance purposes only. 
(3)  All fence posts shall be decay- or corrosion-resistant and shall be set in concrete bases or other suitable protection. 
(4)  The openings between the bottom of the fence and the ground or other surface shall not be more than four inches. 
(d)  Aboveground pools. Aboveground pools of four feet or more in wall height shall be exempt from complete enclosure by a type of fence resistant to being climbed. However, aboveground pools shall be equipped with a fence and gate system at all points of entry to the pool. Such fence and gate system shall effectively control access to the pool and shall be constructed pursuant to the specifications listed in this section. 
(e)  Construction fence. At all times applicable, preceding the erection of a permanent fence as specified in this section, a construction fence pursuant to the specifications set forth in section 8-255(11) shall completely enclose the pool. 
(f)  [Exemptions.] Except where otherwise noted, the following are specifically exempted from this section: 
(1)  Hot tub or spa that accommodates no more than ten adults and has a locking cover. 
(Code 1984, § 355:35; Ord. No. 03-30, § 1, 11-15-2003) 
Sec. 8-259. - Approval of other design or equipment. 
    Any swimming pool, the design and equipment of which incorporate features other than those set forth in this article, shall be subject to review and approval by the director of fire and building inspection services and in accordance with acceptable standards and current public health and safety practices. The applicant may appeal the decision of the director of fire and building inspection services to the city council. 
(Code 1984, § 355:40) 
Sec. 8-260. - Location. 
(a)  No portion of a swimming pool or portable swimming pool or appurtenances thereto shall be located at a distance less than five feet from any side or rear property line, or extend into the minimum front yard setback of the property. 
(b)  No swimming pool accessory equipment which generates noise, such as, but not limited to, pumping or filtering equipment, shall be located in a side yard unless all of the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The equipment is fully screened from view; 
(2)  The equipment, screening and any appurtenances thereto are at least ten feet from the nearest property line; and 
(3)  The noise generated by the equipment when operating satisfies the requirements of section 36-823. 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall not apply in side yards abutting streets if the equipment is fully screened from view, nor shall such provisions apply in the R-A zoning district. 
(Code 1984, § 355:45; Ord. No. 03-32, § 2, 12-1-2003) 
Sec. 8-261. - Operation and maintenance. 
    No residential swimming pool or portable swimming pool shall be used, kept, maintained or operated if such use, keeping, maintaining or operating shall be the occasion of any nuisance or shall be dangerous to life or detrimental to health. 
(Code 1984, § 355:50) 
Sec. 8-262. - Inspection. 
(a)  The director of fire and building inspection services shall have authority to inspect any residential swimming pool at any reasonable time during the construction and thereafter to determine whether or not the provisions of this article regarding health, sanitation, operation and safety applicable thereto are being complied with. 
(b)  The director of fire and building inspection services shall have the authority to enter upon any premises as may be deemed necessary to inspect work done and installations made under permits issued by the building department. 
(c)  Swimming pools shall not be filled with water to a depth of more than 18 inches at the shallowest point in any swimming pool newly constructed or being constructed prior to authorization by the director of fire and building inspection services. The installer must call the building department for all required inspections. The pool shall not be occupied at any time prior to its final inspection and approval by the director of fire and building inspection services. 
(Code 1984, § 355:55) 
Secs. 8-263-8-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PRIVATE ANTENNAS AND TOWERS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 34. 

Sec. 8-291. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antenna means that portion of any equipment used for transmitting or receiving radio or television waves located on the exterior or outside of any building or structure for the noncommercial use of the information. For commercial wireless telecommunication antenna and tower regulations, see section 36-13. 
    Tower means any pole, spire, or structure or any combination thereof to which the antenna is attached and all supporting lines, cables, wires, and braces. 
(Code 1984, § 365:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-292. - Conflicting regulations or agreements. 
    It is not the intention of this article to interfere with, abrogate or annul any covenant or other agreement between any parties; provided, however, where this article imposes a greater restriction upon the use of premises for antennas or towers than are imposed or required by other ordinances, rules, regulations or permits, or by covenants or agreements, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(Code 1984, § 365:50) 
Sec. 8-293. - Permit required; exceptions. 
(a)  No antenna or tower of any kind shall hereafter be erected, constructed, or placed, or re-erected, reconstructed or replaced, anywhere within the city without first making an application for and obtaining from the city a permit therefor and providing to the city proof of the manufacturing engineer's seal for the antenna or tower. 
(b)  Except for the provisions of section 8-298, this article shall not apply to, and no permit shall be required for: 
(1)  An antenna and tower, or antenna alone, on the roof or chimney of a building if the antenna and tower, or antenna without a tower, does not exceed a height of six feet measured from the highest point of the antenna and tower, or of the antenna without a tower, to the nearest point at which the antenna or tower is attached to the roof or chimney of such building; or 
(2)  Antennas or towers: 
a.  Used by a political subdivision for its purposes. 
b.  Erected, constructed or placed on public property pursuant to written agreement with the political subdivision owning the property. 
(Code 1984, § 365:05) 
Sec. 8-294. - Application for permit; permit fee. 
    Application for the permit required by this article shall be made to the director of fire and building inspection services in the same manner as for a building permit pursuant to this Code. A fee equal to that which would have been payable if a building permit had been applied for shall be payable at the time application is made (see chapter 16). 
(Code 1984, § 365:10) 
Sec. 8-295. - Construction requirements; height restrictions. 
    All antennas and towers hereafter erected, constructed or placed anywhere within the city and all wiring therefor shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All applicable provisions of this Code, including, but not limited to, the provisions of this article and the provisions of article II of this chapter, shall be complied with. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection (3) of this section, no part of any tower or antenna, or any equipment or lines used in connection therewith or connected thereto, shall be constructed or maintained, at any time, permanently or temporarily, in, upon or over any required setback area or any required yard area for the district in which the antenna or tower is to be located, nor shall any tower, antenna, equipment or lines be located between the principal or any accessory building on the lot or plat and the required front street or side street setback area. 
(3)  The ten-foot towers referred to in section 8-299 and any antenna or guy lines attached to any such ten-foot tower may be constructed and maintained within the interior side yard and rear yard setback areas. 
(4)  Antennas and towers shall not be erected in violation of the following height restrictions: 
a.  No tower shall be in excess of 50 feet in height when attached to the ground as measured from the highest point of the tower to the ground at the base of the tower. 
b.  No tower and/or antenna height shall be in excess of a height equal to the distance from the base of the tower and/or antenna to the nearest electrical power line (excluding secondary electrical service lines or service drops), less ten feet. 
c.  No antenna shall extend more than ten feet above the highest point of a tower. An antenna attached to a building but not attached to a tower shall not extend more than ten feet above the nearest point at which the antenna is attached to the building. 
d.  In cases of roof mounting procedures, the highest point of the antenna, when mounted to the highest point of the tower, shall not be in excess of 60 feet from the ground. 
e.  Subject to the exceptions set forth in section 8-293, the terms of this subsection (4) are intended to establish a citywide standard whereby the highest point of any antenna, whether mounted on a tower or on a building, is no more than 60 feet from the ground, except that an antenna no more than ten feet tall may be mounted on a building more than 50 feet in height. 
(5)  Towers, except for the ten-foot towers referred to in section 8-299, shall be constructed of steel or other corrosive-resistant, noncombustible materials. They shall not be constructed of wood, including timbers or logs. 
(6)  No part of any antenna or tower, or any lines, cables, equipment, wires or braces in connection with either, shall, at any time, extend across or over any part of the right-of-way of any public street, highway or sidewalk. 
(7)  Antennas and towers shall be designed to resist two times the wind uplift calculated pursuant to the Uniform Building Code as adopted by the city (see article II of this chapter). 
(8)  Antennas and towers shall be adequately grounded for protection against a direct strike by lightning and shall comply, as to electrical wiring and connections, with all applicable state statutes, regulations, and standards as well as city codes. 
(9)  All lines and wires extending substantially horizontal above the ground from a tower or antenna to a building, tower or structure shall be at least eight feet above the ground at all points. 
(10)  Every tower affixed to the ground shall be wrapped in hardware cloth or like material to a height of at least eight feet above the ground to prevent climbing of the tower by unauthorized persons. 
(Code 1984, § 365:15) 
Sec. 8-296. - Antennas and towers existing on March 6, 1980. 
    Antennas and towers in existence as of March 6, 1980, and which do not conform to or comply with this article are subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  Such antennas and towers may continue to be used for the purposes now used and as now existing, except as provided in this section, but may not be replaced, expanded, enlarged or added to in any way without complying in all respects with this article, except that antennas may be replaced, provided the new antenna fully complies with the provisions of this article applicable to antennas. 
(2)  If existing antennas or towers are, or either of them is, hereafter damaged or destroyed due to any cause whatsoever, the antenna or tower may be repaired and restored to its former use in the same location and to the same physical dimensions upon obtaining a building permit therefor but without otherwise complying with this article; provided, however, that if the cost of repairing or restoring such damaged or destroyed antenna or tower is 50 percent or more, as estimated by the city council or some official designated by it, of the cost of purchasing and erecting a new antenna and tower of like kind and quality and to the former use, physical dimensions and location, then the antenna and tower may not be repaired or restored except in full compliance with this article. 
(3)  No such antenna or tower shall be used or remain erected for a period longer than 15 years from March 6, 1980, and such antennas and towers shall be removed, or be made to comply with this article, within six months after the end of the 15-year period. 
(Code 1984, § 365:20) 
Sec. 8-297. - Antennas and towers existing on September 30, 1987. 
    Antennas and towers erected, constructed or placed, or re-erected, reconstructed, or replaced, after March 6, 1980, and through September 30, 1987, which antennas and towers do not conform to or comply with this article, are subject to section 8-296(1), (2) and (3). 
(Code 1984, § 365:21) 
Sec. 8-298. - Lights and signs; platforms or similar structures. 
    Unless otherwise required by state or federal law or rule, no antenna or tower shall have affixed or attached to it in any way any lights, reflectors, flashers, or other illuminating device, or any sign, banner or placard of any kind, except one sign not over ten square inches indicating the name of the manufacturer. No tower shall have constructed thereon or attached thereto, in any way, any platform, catwalk, crow's nest or like structure. 
(Code 1984, § 365:25) 
Sec. 8-299. - Number of towers and antennas allowed. 
(a)  Only one of the towers referred to in section 8-293(b)(1) shall exist at one time on any one lot or plot. 
(b)  As to other towers regulated by this article, not more than three towers shall exist at any one time on any one lot or plot; provided, however, that two of such towers shall not exceed ten feet in height, shall blend with the surroundings, shall be shielded from adjoining properties by shrubbery or fences and shall be used for guy wire supports and/or dipole or V-type antenna purposes only, with each tower to have but one guy wire and/or antenna wire attached to it. 
(c)  Only one antenna may be erected on a lot or plot with or without a tower pursuant to section 8-293(b)(1). Any number of antennas may be erected on any one tower (except the ten-foot towers referred to in this section), or on any one lot or plot without a tower, but all such antennas, in the aggregate, shall not exceed the mass, bulk or size of one three-element Triband beam antenna with a lowest frequency of 14 megacycles. 
(d)  For purposes of this section, the term "lot" or "plot" shall include the definitions in chapter 36, and shall also include any one or more lots or plots owned by the same person and used as a single tract. 
(e)  No such antenna or tower shall be used or remain erected for a period longer than 15 years from March 6, 1980, and such antennas and towers shall be removed, or be made to comply with this article, within six months after the end of the 15-year period. 
(Code 1984, § 365:30) 
Sec. 8-300. - Variances. 
    Variances from the strict provisions of this article may be granted in the same manner as variances are granted under chapter 36, article II, division 5. 
(Code 1984, § 365:35) 
Sec. 8-301. - Removal of abandoned towers. 
    Any tower or antenna which is not used for six successive months, commencing after March 6, 1980, shall be deemed abandoned and shall be removed as abandoned property pursuant to the procedures set forth in chapter 14, article II, division 3, or in the Uniform Building Code as adopted by the city pursuant to article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1984, § 365:40) 
Secs. 8-302-8-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - RESERVED[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-11, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 2009, repealed Art. XI, §§ 8-331-8-337, which pertained to wind energy conversion systems and derived from Code 1984, §§ 366.00, 366.35, 366.05, 336.10, 366.15, 366.20 and 366.25. See § 36-833 for provisions pertaining to wind energy conversion systems. 

Secs. 8-331-8-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME COURTS 

Sec. 8-361. - Purpose; variances and amendments. 
    The intent and purpose of this article is to ensure quality development equal to that found in other types of residential areas throughout the city. Excellence of design, development and maintenance of mobile homes and mobile home courts is the desired objective. The council has the authority to vary any of the requirements of this article provided it acts to vary or amend with at least four-fifths vote of the entire council, and that it acts within the intent of the variance provisions as established in chapter 36, pertaining to zoning. 
(Code 1984, § 325:00) 
Sec. 8-362. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Camping trailer and folding tent trailer mean a vehicular portable structure mounted on wheels and constructed with collapsible partial side walls of fabric, plastic or other pliable material which are adapted for folding for towing by another vehicle and unfolding at the campsite to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use. 
    Doublewide means two or more mobile home units, separately towable but designed without a permanent foundation to be joined into one integral unit, capable of being again separated for repeated towing (see also Sectional house and Expandable ). 
    Expandable means a mobile home containing a collapsible or telescoping unit which meets highway towing standards when closed, and expanded at the site (pulled out like a bureau drawer to form a bar or an ell) for added living space. 
    Mobile home means any type of transportable structure or vehicle not drawn by its own power, with a permanently attached undercarriage and wheels, which is designed, constructed and equipped for use as a single-family dwelling place, living abode, or living quarters, suitable for occupancy during the entire year, which contains the same water supply, waste disposal and electrical conveniences as immobile housing. It is the intention of the council that this definition shall include manufactured homes as defined in Minn. Stats. § 327.31, subd 6. 
    Mobile home court means any premises on which are parked two or more occupied mobile homes, but this definition shall exclude sales lots on which automobiles or unoccupied mobile homes, whether new or used, are parked for purposes of inspection or sale. 
    Mobile home lot means a parcel of land for the placement of a single mobile home for the exclusive use of the occupants of the mobile home. 
    Mobile home stand means the part of an individual mobile home lot which has been reserved for placement of the mobile home, appurtenant structures, or additions. 
    Motor home and motorized home mean a vehicular structure built on a self-propelled motor vehicle chassis, primarily designed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use. 
    Prefabricated housing means conventional type housing for permanent foundations, assembled and "finished" on-site, from factory preconstructed separate sections of walls, roofs, etc., typically lifted from trucks into place with the aid of cranes. 
    Sectional house means a factory-prefinished house shipped in (normally two) complete sections, fastened together and "finished" at the site, and designed for a permanent foundation which can include a full-depth basement. 
    Trailer means any vehicle or structure designed and used for human living quarters which meets all of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Is not used as the permanent residence of the owner or occupant. 
(2)  Is used for temporary living quarters by the owner or occupant while engaged in recreational or vacation activities. 
(3)  Is towed or otherwise transported by its own or by other motor power on the public streets or highways incidental to such recreational or vacation activities. 
    Trailer, dependent, means a travel trailer which is dependent upon a service building for toilet and lavatory facilities. 
    Trailer park means a park, court, campsite, lot, parcel or tract of land designed, maintained or intended for the purpose of supplying the location or accommodations for any trailers, and upon which such trailers are parked. The term "trailer park" shall include all buildings used or intended for use as a part of the equipment thereof whether a charge is made for the use of the park and its facilities or not. 
    Travel trailer means a vehicular portable structure, mounted on wheels, of such size or weight as not to require special highway movement permits when drawn by a stock passenger automobile, primarily designed and constructed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use. 
    Truck camper means a portable structure designed to be loaded onto, or affixed to the bed or chassis of, a truck, and constructed to provide temporary living quarters for recreation, camping or travel use. 
(Code 1984, § 325:10) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-363. - Violations; penalties; maintenance or repair by city. 
(a)  Penalty. Violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. Each day that the violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Additional remedies. In the event of a violation or a threatened violation of this article, the council or any member thereof, in addition to other remedies, may institute appropriate actions or proceedings to prevent, restrain, correct or abate such violations or threatened violations. 
(c)  Maintenance or repair by city. 
(1)  If the owner or any successor owner shall at any time fail to maintain any of the recreational areas or streets or any of the common space areas within the mobile home court in reasonable order and condition, the city may enter upon such areas pursuant to the easement agreement as required in section 8-368(l), to provide the necessary maintenance to establish the mobile home court in an attractive, well-kept condition. 
(2)  Before the city shall make any repairs upon such areas, the city shall give written notice to the record owner shown upon the records of the county auditor, making demand that the specific repairs or maintenance shall be made by the owner immediately or, in the alternative, that the city shall make such repairs and thereafter assess the costs to the owner thereof. 
(3)  If the owner fails to fully comply within 30 days of such notice, the city may perform the repairs and maintenance, which shall be billed to the owner of the mobile home court and/or the recorded property owner, and payment shall be made to the city by the owner to reimburse the city immediately thereafter. 
(4)  If the owner of the mobile court fails to make payment to the city upon the city having so demanded payment for repairs and maintenance as set forth in this section, the city shall have the right without further notice to assess such costs, including administrative costs of the city, and certify such assessments to the county auditor as an assessment levied to be paid with the taxes on the property on which the mobile home court is located. 
(Code 1984, § 325:40) 
Sec. 8-364. - General regulations. 
(a)  Conditional use permit required for mobile home courts. No person shall develop or operate any mobile home court without having a conditional use permit pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Permitted locations for mobile homes. 
(1)  Mobile homes shall be located only in zoning districts that permit single-family detached homes or approved mobile home courts, except for the temporary maintenance, pursuant to a permit issued by the city, of a mobile home for business purposes, on the business premises or adjacent property, where the mobile home is used in connection with work performed on the business premises. 
(2)  Permits for such excepted mobile home use may be issued by the director of fire and building inspection services for a period not to exceed 90 days if the conditions stated in this section appear to his reasonable satisfaction. 
(3)  Any renewal of such permit shall require approval of the council, it being the intent of the council that extensions should be granted only in unusual or emergency situations that require a brief extension only. 
(c)  Alterations to mobile homes. The following are prohibited with respect to a mobile home properly located, either temporarily or permanently: 
(1)  Removal of wheels therefrom. 
(2)  Construction of a permanent foundation or enclosure thereunder. 
(3)  Construction of any additions to provide extra floorspace, unless the additions are provided by a manufacturer and specifically designed for use with mobile homes, but subject to the other provisions of this article and other applicable ordinances with respect to setbacks and similar matters. 
(d)  Water and sewer connections. A mobile home shall not be used as a permanent place of abode or as a permanent dwelling unless it is properly connected to a municipal sanitary sewer system. All water and sewer systems shall be constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the engineer. It is the intention of the council that the council approve the water supply system and sanitary sewer connections to mobile home courts as a part of their original construction. 
(e)  Permitted locations for mobile home courts. A conditional use permit for a mobile home court shall be granted only in zoning districts set forth in chapter 36 as a district permitting mobile home courts as a conditional use within the district. 
(Code 1984, § 325:05) 
Sec. 8-365. - Procedure for approval of mobile home courts. 
    The procedure applicable to this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Application for conditional use permit. The application for a mobile home court conditional use permit with all required materials shall be submitted to the zoning administrator. Required materials shall include: 
a.  The name and address of the developer and the description of the construction scheduled and the construction cost. 
b.  Location and size of the mobile home court. 
c.  Location, size and topography of all mobile home lots, mobile home stands, storage areas, roadways, parking spaces and sites and all setback dimensions. 
d.  Location of sidewalks. 
e.  Plans for sanitary sewage disposal, surface drainage, water systems, electrical service, telephone service and gas service. 
f.  Location and size of all streets abutting the mobile home court and all roadways from such streets to the court. 
g.  Complete data as to dwelling unit sizes and ratios of units to total lot space. 
h.  Such other information as may be requested or required by the city. 
(2)  Processing of application. The zoning administrator shall place the application on agenda for the planning commission at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(3)  Review of sketch plan The planning commission shall then schedule a meeting with the applicant in person or his designated agent for the purpose of reviewing the proposed plan. The planning commission may request further data or information that shall be supplied by the applicant prior to the planning commission making a decision thereon. The planning commission, after due examination and reviewal of the applicant's proposal, shall approve of the plan or approve the plan with modifications, or deny the plan. 
(4)  Contents of preliminary plan. If the planning commission shall approve the sketch plan in its concept the applicant shall then prepare preliminary plans to be presented to the planning commission for approval. The preliminary plans shall contain detailed information on all matters set forth in subsection (1) of this section, but shall also include six copies of all plans that shall indicate: 
a.  Detailed landscaping plans and specifications. 
b.  Location and width of sidewalks. 
c.  Plans for the overhead street lighting system, which shall be submitted to the engineer. 
d.  Method of disposing of garbage and refuse. 
e.  Plans and specifications for all road construction either within the court or directly related to the court operation. 
f.  Floor plans and elevations of all buildings to be constructed within the mobile home court. 
g.  Detailed description of maintenance procedures and ground supervision. 
h.  Complete data as to dwelling unit sizes and ratios of units to total lot size. 
i.  Such other information as may be required or requested by the city. 
(5)  Processing of preliminary plan. The applicant shall ask the zoning administrator to place the application with the preliminary plans on the agenda for the planning commission at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(6)  Review of preliminary plan. 
a.  The planning commission shall then schedule a meeting with the applicant in person or his designated agent for the purpose of reviewing the proposed plan. 
b.  The planning commission may request further data or information that shall be supplied by the applicant prior to making a decision thereon. 
c.  The planning commission may or may not, at its discretion, hold a public hearing on the applicant's proposed plan. 
1.  If the planning commission requests a public hearing, the hearing shall be held before the commissioners before granting approval or denial of the plan. 
2.  Notice of the public hearing shall be by publication once in the official newspaper of the city at least ten days before the date of such hearing, and it shall specify the general purpose of the hearing and the time and place where the hearing is to be held. 
d.  Upon completion of the entire review of the plan by the planning commission, the commission shall grant approval of the plan as submitted or grant approval of the plan subject to specific modifications or adjustments or deny approval of the proposed plan, stating the reasons for denial. 
(7)  Approval of preliminary plan by council. Upon approval of the planning commission, the plan shall be submitted to the council for its preliminary approval or disapproval. If approval is granted, the applicant shall prepare a final development plan for approval by the planning commission and the council, which shall be a final, overall development plan. 
(8)  Contents of final development plan. The final development plan for the overall development, or, if authorized by the approved overall preliminary development plan, a final development plan for the first stage of development, shall be submitted to the planning commission for its approval and shall include the following: 
a.  A detailed site plan showing all proposed streets, structures, parking areas, utility easements, common open areas, and recreational facilities, and a landscape schedule. 
b.  A boundary survey and legal description of the entire tract covered by the application, prepared by a land surveyor. 
c.  A layout of all proposed water mains, sanitary sewers, and storm drainage facilities, together with profiles for all street roadways. 
d.  A general overall grading plan indicating grades and direction and destination of surface drainage. 
e.  Elevation drawings of all proposed structures except detached single-family dwellings. 
f.  At least one perspective drawing or model which will clearly show the architectural style of the development. 
g.  Copies of all proposed covenants, agreements and provisions which govern the use and maintenance of common open areas. 
h.  The owner's or developer's contemplated development schedule. 
(9)  Required findings. The planning commission shall report favorably upon the final development plan only upon finding that: 
a.  The proposed development will not be detrimental to property surrounding the mobile home court. 
b.  The proposed development is consistent with the comprehensive development plan for the city. 
c.  The design reasonably accommodates and preserves the natural amenities of the area. 
d.  The proposed development provides a proper relationship quality between natural features, common space and living space. 
(10)  Approval of final development plan by council. 
a.  Upon approval of the final development plan by the planning commission, the matter shall be referred to the council for approval or denial of the final development plan. 
b.  The council may accept or deny the findings of the planning commission and thereby approve or disapprove the final development plan. 
c.  If the final development plan is approved, the conditional use permit for the mobile home court shall be granted. 
d.  If a development in stages is authorized in the approved overall preliminary plan and the final development plan is approved by the council for the first stage of development only, the applicant shall apply for final development plan approval for each succeeding stage of development as set forth in this section. 
(11)  Filing of plans. The approved overall preliminary development plan and final development plan shall be filed with the zoning administrator. 
(12)  Changes to approved plans. 
a.  Subsequent to final plan approval, minor changes in the location, placement, and height of buildings or in grading or landscaping plans may be authorized by the zoning administrator where unforeseen circumstances such as engineering requirements dictate such a change. 
b.  Changes in the shape and arrangements of lots and blocks, or in the allocation of open space, and all other substantial deviations from the final development plan shall be referred to the planning commission for report and recommendation, after which the council shall decide to either approve or deny the changes in the final development plan. 
c.  If such changes are authorized, the owners or developers shall submit a revised plan showing authorized changes, which revised plan shall be filed with the zoning administrator. 
(13)  Compliance with approved plan; inspections. 
a.  The planning commission shall review all mobile home courts within the city at least once each year and shall make a report to the council on the status of each of the courts. 
b.  If the council finds that the court or its development has not occurred in reasonable conformity with the approved requirements or schedules for such mobile home court, the council may initiate proceedings to revoke the conditional use permit pertaining to the court. 
c.  Upon recommendation of the planning commission and for good cause shown by the property owner, the council may extend the limits of the development schedules, but may not waive any of the other requirements of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 325:30) 
Sec. 8-366. - Fees. 
(a)  Conditional use permit fee. The fees for the conditional use permit on a mobile home court shall be as set forth in chapter 16. 
(b)  Development fee. There shall be a development fee, as set forth in chapter 16, for each mobile home lot in the court, based upon the capacity of the court as shown on the approved plans when the conditional use permit is issued. Both the conditional use permit fee and the development fee shall be paid before issuance of the conditional use permit and before any grading, excavation or construction of any kind is started on the court site. 
(c)  Location fee. In addition to the conditional use permit and development fees as provided for in this section, the owner or operator of a mobile home court shall pay a location fee, as set forth in chapter 16, for each mobile home prior to the parking of the mobile home in any mobile home court. This fee shall be paid upon issuance of a completed location permit for the mobile home pursuant to applications therefor filed at the clerk's office. An application shall be filed and approved before any location or relocation may be made of any mobile home within a mobile home court within the corporate limits of the city. 
(d)  Inspection fees. In addition to the fees otherwise required by this section, the normal inspection fees, as set forth in chapter 16, shall be charged and paid. 
(Code 1984, § 325:35) 
Sec. 8-367. - Standards for mobile home courts. 
(a)  Minimum number of lots. A mobile home court shall contain area sufficient to accommodate at least 150 mobile home lots, plus recreational areas and streets as required by this article. Prior to occupancy of any mobile home in such court at least 50 mobile home stands must be fully developed as required by the provisions of this article, including all required auxiliary buildings and other areas. 
(b)  Utility installation. All utilities, such as sewer, water, fuel, electric service, telephone service and television antenna lead-ins, shall be buried to a depth specified by the engineer, and there shall be no overhead wires. All utility connections shall be approved by the municipal inspectors prior to connection. 
(c)  Drainage, sanitation and refuse collection. 
(1)  All land areas shall be adequately drained and properly maintained free of dust, refuse, garbage, rubbish or debris. 
(2)  Plans for the disposal of surface stormwater shall be approved by the engineer. 
(3)  The proposed method of garbage, waste and trash disposal must be approved by the municipal inspectors and must conform to the regulations of the state pollution control agency. 
a.  Refuse collection stands shall be provided for all refuse containers. Such stands shall be so designed as to prevent containers from being tipped, to minimize spillage and container deterioration, and to facilitate cleaning around them. 
b.  The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the mobile home court shall be so conducted as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, accident or fire hazards or air pollution. 
(d)  Recreational areas. 
(1)  All mobile home courts shall have one or more recreational areas which shall be easily accessible to all court residents. 
(2)  Recreational areas shall be so located as to be free of traffic hazards and should, where the topography permits, be centrally located. The recreational areas shall be a minimum of ten percent of the land area of the entire court. 
(3)  All equipment installed in such an area shall be owned and maintained by the owner or operator at his own expense. 
(e)  Water and sewer service. All water supply and sanitation facilities must conform to the current recommendations of the state department of health. Fire hydrants shall be provided as required by the engineer. 
(f)  Storage area. All mobile home courts shall have an area set aside for dead storage usage by occupants of all the mobile homes within the mobile home court. The storage shall be ample to store such large items as boats, trailers, motorcycles and similar items. The storage area referred to shall be fully screened or otherwise closed so as to be hidden from view. 
(g)  Landscape area. 
(1)  A landscape area with a minimum depth of 50 feet shall be maintained around the perimeter of each mobile home court. 
(2)  The area shall not be a part of any mobile home lot, as it shall be part of the common ground of the mobile home court. 
(3)  There shall be natural growth as part of the landscaping along such perimeter grounds, such growth being not less than two feet six inches high at the time of planting. Such growth shall be maintained along with the general landscaping in such a manner as the landscaping and planting shall not become unsightly or die. 
(h)  Access to lots; traffic. 
(1)  No mobile home lot shall have direct access to a public street. 
(2)  Each mobile home lot within a mobile home court shall abut on and have access to a private road used by the inhabitants of the court and built and maintained by the owner thereof. 
a.  The road shall have a paved surface at least 30 feet in width from curb to curb and lead to and furnish ingress and egress from a public street to controlled driveways, which shall not be less than 24 feet in width. 
b.  The private roads shall be paved with a concrete or bituminous material complying with the specifications for the construction of any city residential street. 
(3)  The operation of motor vehicles on such private roads within a mobile home court shall be subject to the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 169, notwithstanding the provisions therein excluding its operation upon private roads. 
(4)  All such private roads shall be adequately lighted for the purpose of protecting vehicular traffic thereon and pedestrian use thereof. 
(i)  Width of right-of-way. Public street rights-of-way shall not be less than 40 feet in width. 
(j)  Curb and gutter. A concrete curb and gutter shall be constructed on each side of the road. The curb and gutter shall comply with all applicable ordinances of the city. 
(k)  Sidewalks. A concrete sidewalk not less than 48 inches wide shall be constructed adjacent to the concrete curb (or a curb and sidewalk combination, 48 inches in width). This sidewalk shall be connected to each unit entrance by a concrete walk not less than 36 inches in width. 
(l)  Community building. 
(1)  Each mobile home court must have one or more central community buildings with central heating which must be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition. 
(2)  Such buildings shall be adequately lighted during all hours of darkness and shall contain laundry washers, dryers and drying areas and public telephones, in addition to the public toilets and lavatory. Toilet facilities shall comply with requirements of the state department of health. 
(3)  Each court shall have a building for the use of the operator distinctly marked "office" and such marking shall be illuminated during all hours of darkness. An illuminated map of the court shall be displayed at the office. 
(4)  All of such buildings must be constructed to meet existing codes and ordinances of the city and shall provide below-grade storm shelters to house all mobile home court residents, containing at least 15 square feet in area for each mobile home. 
(5)  Portable fire devices, as approved by the fire marshal, shall be kept in all service buildings. 
(m)  Fire devices. Fire devices, as approved by the fire marshal, shall be provided, maintained and located in each mobile home. 
(n)  Caretaker; register; marking and numbering of lots. A caretaker must be on duty at all times in the mobile home court. The operator of every mobile home court shall maintain a register in the office of the court, indicating the name and address of each current resident of the court and the make, type, license and serial number of each mobile home and automobile of each current resident, and the date of arrival of each mobile home on the premises. The corners of each lot shall be marked with surveyor's irons, and each lot shall be numbered. 
(o)  Off-street parking. In addition to the required off-street parking for each mobile home lot, the mobile home court shall provide and maintain a paved off-street parking lot for guests of occupants. 
(p)  Animals; loudspeakers; camping. No dogs or other animals shall be permitted to run at large within a mobile home court. No public address or loudspeaker system shall be permitted. There shall be no outdoor camping anywhere in the mobile home court and no tents shall be erected or occupied. 
(q)  Trailers. No trailers shall occupy any lot in a mobile home park. 
(r)  Signs. Advertising of the mobile home court on the premises shall be limited to one nameplate sign containing the court name, which plate shall not exceed 25 square feet, with lighting, heights and location as approved by the municipal inspectors, with a 25-foot setback from any lot line. 
(Code 1984, § 325:15) 
Sec. 8-368. - Standards for mobile home sites. 
(a)  Area, dimensions and setbacks. Minimum requirements for mobile home lots shall be as follows: 
(1)  Lot area per dwelling unit: 7,200 square feet. 
(2)  Lot width: 60 feet. 
(3)  Lot depth: 120 feet. 
(4)  Front yard setback: 30 feet. 
(5)  Side yard setback: Ten feet. 
(6)  Rear yard setback: 20 feet. 
(b)  Planned unit developments. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the minimum lot requirement set forth in subsection (a) of this section, a property owner may apply for a mobile home court permit within the city following all of the procedural requirements in chapter 36 relating to planned unit development. 
(2)  The council may at its discretion grant a mobile home court conditional use permit, permitting the clustering of mobile home units within the court pursuant to the proposed planned unit development. 
(3)  The maximum density within the court, if the conditional use permit is granted for the planned unit development, shall comply with all density requirements of the zoning district wherein the court is to be located, except that under no circumstances shall the planned unit development permit a density exceeding four units (mobile home sites) per acre. 
(c)  Setback for accessory structures. An accessory structure, including, but not limited to, an awning, storage cabinet, carport or porch, shall be considered to be part of the mobile home for the purposes of all setback requirements. 
(d)  Maximum coverage by structures. The area occupied by structures shall not exceed 25 percent of the total area of a mobile home lot. The lot may be occupied by a mobile home, an accessory building, a carport, an awning, and a storage closet or cupboard, all with such 25 percent limitation. 
(e)  Parking spaces and driveways. Each mobile home site shall have two paved (concrete or bituminous) off-street parking spaces for automobiles. Each parking space shall be at least 200 square feet in size and shall not be located within five feet of the side of any mobile home or within five feet of any lot line. The driveways shall also be paved in similar style. 
(f)  Landscaping. Except for the areas used for the mobile home, patio, sidewalk and off-street parking space, the entire remaining area of the mobile home lot shall be sodded and maintained with grass. At least two shade trees with a minimum diameter of two inches at the time of planting shall be planted and maintained on each mobile home lot. 
(g)  Surface of mobile home stand. The mobile home stand shall consist of a crushed rock surface at least two feet longer and two feet wider than the mobile home, and the minimum depth of the crushed rock shall be four inches. 
(h)  Anchors and tiedowns required. The mobile home stand shall be provided with anchors and tiedowns, such as cast-in-place concrete foundations or runways, screw augers, arrowhead anchors or other devices providing for stability of the mobile home. 
(i)  Placement and strength of anchors and tiedowns. Anchors and tiedowns shall be placed at least at each corner of the mobile home stand and each anchor shall be able to sustain in a minimum tensile strength of 2,800 pounds. 
(j)  Fuel supply Each mobile home lot shall be served by a central fuel supply system, such as natural gas or a central LP system. No separate or private fuel containers, such as fuel oil tanks or LP tanks, shall be allowed in the mobile home court. 
(k)  Inspections. 
(1)  Periodic inspections by municipal personnel of the entire court and all its facilities may be required. 
(2)  Utility and heating facilities shall be inspected at least every six months. 
(l)  City easements. The property owner will grant to the city an open space easement and permit the city to have an easement to enter upon, as the grantee, any open space, street or recreational areas provided within the mobile home court, for the purpose of permitting the city to service structures, make repairs or maintain as is necessary and appropriate to adequately maintain such areas in the event that the owner of the property or his successors or assigns fail to comply with the standards and requirements as set forth within this article. 
(Code 1984, § 325:20) 
Sec. 8-369. - Structural requirements; occupancy of mobile homes. 
(a)  Maintenance of structures. Every structure in a mobile home court shall be developed and maintained in a safe, approved and substantial manner. The exterior of each structure in a mobile home court shall be kept in good repair, and shall be repainted or refinished at such reasonable times in such reasonable manner as may be required by the city, it being the intent of this provision that the court shall not be permitted to present a run-down or shabby appearance. 
(b)  Building permits. All structures, other than the mobile home, shall require a building permit. It is not the intent of this article to repeal or abrogate any part of the building code. The provisions of this article shall be enforced in addition to and in conjunction with the provisions of the building code. 
(c)  Requirements for mobile homes. Mobile homes shall not be located or permitted to remain in the city unless they: 
(1)  Conform to all requirements of state law, including, but not limited to, Minn. Stats. ch. 327; 
(2)  Are in sanitary condition; and 
(3)  Are structurally sound, particularly with respect to the safety and welfare of their occupants. 
(d)  Occupancy of mobile homes. It is the purpose of this article to restrict occupancy of mobile homes to the owners of such mobile homes, on the basis that owner-occupancy is more likely to result in a well-maintained mobile home. Accordingly, all mobile homes in the city shall be owner-occupied and no mobile home may be inhabited by more than one family. Unoccupied mobile homes must be removed from the court within 90 days after they become unoccupied. 
(e)  Inspections. Municipal employees, including particularly police, building inspectors, health inspectors, and the like, shall be permitted in the mobile home court at all reasonable times for the purposes of making any inspections under this article or other applicable ordinances or state laws. 
(f)  Enclosure of area beneath mobile home. The area beneath all mobile homes shall be enclosed with a normal exterior material that shall be generally uniform through the entire mobile home court, except that such an enclosure must be so constructed that it is subject to reasonable inspection. 
(g)  Prohibited structures and vehicles. Campers, camping trailers, motor homes, prefabricated homes, sectional houses, tent trailers, dependent trailers, travel trailers, or truck campers shall not be located on any mobile home lot. 
(Code 1984, § 325:25) 
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES AND LICENSING[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 4; emergency management, ch. 12; business license and permit fees, business taxes and miscellaneous permit fees, § 16-81 et seq.; utilities, ch. 34; business district, § 36-461 et seq.; industrial district, § 36-521 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Applicability of business and licensing regulations. 
(a)  Persons deemed engaging in business. It shall be unlawful for any person either directly or indirectly to engage in any business, or to use in connection therewith any vehicle, premises, machine or device, in whole or in part, for which a license or permit is required by any provision of this Code or any other law or ordinance of the city, without a license or permit therefor being first procured and kept in effect at all times as required by any such provision of this Code or any other law or ordinance of the city. For the purposes of this Code, any person shall be deemed to be engaged in any business for which a license is required, and thus subject to the requirements of this Code or any other law or ordinance of the city, when such person does within the corporate limits of the city one act of: 
(1)  Selling any goods or service for which a license is required. 
(2)  Soliciting such business or offering such goods or services for sale or hire. 
(3)  Acquiring or using any vehicle or any premises for such business purposes. 
(b)  Agents and representatives; branch establishments. 
(1)  The agents or other representatives of non-residents of the city who are doing business within the corporate limits of the city shall be personally responsible for compliance with the provisions of this Code by their principals and by the businesses they represent. 
(2)  A license shall be obtained in the manner prescribed in this Code for each branch establishment or location of the business engaged in, as if each such branch establishment or location were a separate business. 
(3)  No license shall be required of any person for any mere delivery in the city of any property purchased or acquired in good faith from such person at his regular place of business outside the corporate limits of the city where no intent by such person is shown to exist to evade the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1984, § 400:00) 
Sec. 10-2. - Application for license; fees; bonds. 
(a)  Every person required to procure a license under the provisions of this chapter or any other law or ordinance of the city shall submit an application for such license to the clerk. The application shall: 
(1)  Be a written statement upon forms provided by the city, such forms to include an affidavit to be sworn to by the applicant before a person authorized to administer an oath. 
(2)  Contain all information necessary to comply with this Code and the ordinance under which the license is required, and any other information required by the clerk, including the full identification of the applicant and his address, and the description of the premises where the licensed business or other enterprise is to be conducted. 
(b)  The full amount of the required license fee as set forth in chapter 16 shall be paid to the treasurer at the time the application is filed with the clerk. If the provisions under which any license is to be issued require the licensee to furnish a bond, such bond shall be duly executed by the licensee and a corporate surety and shall be furnished at the time the application is filed or as soon thereafter as the clerk shall request. Such bond shall be in such amount and with such penalty provisions as shall be required. 
(Code 1984, § 400:05) 
Sec. 10-3. - Procedure for issuance of licenses. 
(a)  On receipt of an application for any license, the clerk shall cause investigation to be made of the qualifications of the applicant and shall determine whether the applicant has complied with all requirements of this Code and the ordinance or law under which the license is to be issued, which requirements are prerequisites to the issuance of the license. 
(b)  Unless the provisions of this Code, the law or other ordinance pursuant to which the license is to be issued require issuance of the license by the council, the clerk shall issue such license upon determination that such prerequisites have been complied with, but if he shall have determined that such prerequisites have not been complied with, he shall deny the application for issuance of the license. 
(c)  The applicant for any license which has been denied by the clerk may appeal the decision of the clerk to the council by filing with the clerk, within ten days after receipt of notice of such denial, a request for review by the council of such determination. The clerk shall thereupon refer the request to the council at its next regular meeting, at which time the council shall hear the applicant and review the determination of the clerk and may grant or deny such license. 
(d)  If any license shall be required to be duly issued by the council, the clerk shall refer the application, together with a report of investigation and determination with respect to the applicant and his compliance with the licensing requirements, to the council. The council shall thereupon consider the report and findings of the clerk and may grant or deny the license. 
(Code 1984, § 400:10) 
Sec. 10-4. - License period; renewal of license; duplicate license or tag; refund of fees. 
(a)  All licenses issued under any provision of this Code or any other ordinance or law shall terminate on December 31 of the calendar year in which issued, unless otherwise indicated. 
(b)  Applications for renewal of any license shall be made to the clerk on forms provided by the city, and shall contain any information required for renewal of the license by the provisions of this Code and law or other ordinance under which the license is to be issued, and such additional information as the clerk shall require. 
(c)  A duplicate license certificate or tag shall be issued by the clerk to replace any license certificate or tag previously issued which has been lost, stolen, defaced or destroyed, without any willful conduct on the part of the licensee, upon the filing by the licensee of an affidavit attesting to such fact and paying a fee as set forth in section 16-82. 
(d)  No rebate or refund of any license fee or part thereof shall be made by reason of nonuse of such license, or by reason of a change in location or business rendering the use of such license ineffective, provided that the clerk shall have authority to refund a license fee collected through an error, or in cases where the application is denied. 
(Code 1984, § 400:15) 
Sec. 10-5. - Duties of licensees. 
    Every licensee under this Code shall: 
(1)  Permit all reasonable inspections of the business and examinations of the business books and records by such authorities so authorized by law, ordinance or regulation. 
(2)  Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws, ordinances and regulations applicable to such business. 
(3)  Refrain from operating the licensed business after expiration of the license and during the period his license is revoked or suspended. 
(4)  Post and maintain the license issued to him upon the licensed premises in a place where it may be seen at all times, and if the license is for operation or use in connection with any vehicle, the license or license insignia issued for that purpose shall be affixed to each vehicle licensed. 
(5)  Not loan, sell, give, or assign, to any other person, or allow any other person to use or display or to have in possession, any license or insignia which has been issued to such licensee. 
(6)  Pay, prior to date penalty attaches for nonpayment, all special assessment and real and personal property taxes levied against real and personal property owned by the licensee and used in the licensed business. 
(Code 1984, § 400:20) 
Sec. 10-6. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the health officer of the city, or other authorized representative, to inspect all premises licensed under this Code for the purpose of determining any violation of law relating to health. It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to inspect and examine all premises, businesses and enterprises subject to license or which have been licensed under this Code. The city administrator shall have the right to direct the health officer, any police officer, or any other appropriate officer of the city to make such inspections at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1984, § 400:25) 
Sec. 10-7. - Procedure for suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  At any time that the clerk shall determine that any person licensed under this Code shall have failed to comply with any requirement of law or with any provision of this Code or other ordinance, he shall notify the licensee in writing of such violation, such notice to be delivered by the U.S. mail or personally as the clerk may determine, and deposit of the notice in the U.S. mail, addressed to the address stated on the license application, shall constitute service of the notice. If such person cannot be found otherwise the notice may be posted on the premises licensed. 
(b)  The notice shall require compliance with the provisions of law, regulation or ordinance specified within a reasonable time set forth in the notice. 
(c)  Upon expiration of such time, unless the licensee shall have requested a hearing in writing, the council may thereafter terminate such license, subject to compliance with any procedure prescribed by the ordinance pursuant to which the license was issued. 
(Code 1984, § 400:30) 
Sec. 10-8. - Hearing on suspension or revocation of license. 
    If a hearing is requested by the licensee pursuant to section 10-7, the clerk shall set a time for such hearing not less than ten days and not more than 20 days after the request, at which time the council shall hear all testimony offered by the licensee, and shall inform the licensee of all information upon which the alleged violation of law by the licensee has been determined. On completion of such hearing, the council may make a final order suspending or terminating the license in question. 
(Code 1984, § 400:35) 
Secs. 10-9-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENT CENTERS AND AMUSEMENT MACHINES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Insurance requirements for amusement machines and amusement centers, § 16-435. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate amusements, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 25. 

Sec. 10-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement center means a business or location open for public use and participation and devoted primarily to the operation of five or more amusement machines, except that the following locations having five or more amusement machines will not be considered primarily devoted to such a business if the presence of such machines is not advertised in print or media: 
(1)  A location licensed pursuant to article II or article III of chapter 4. 
(2)  A restaurant or eating establishment other than a convenience food or drive-in restaurant or eating establishment. 
(3)  A motion picture theater. 
(4)  A bowling establishment. 
(5)  An athletic club. 
(6)  A health spa. 
(7)  A hotel, motel or campground. 
(8)  A club room or lodge. 
    Amusement machine means, but is not limited to, any of the following types of equipment available for public use: 
(1)  Any table of the pool, billiard, foosball, or ping pong variety and any machine or electronic contrivance available for public use, including, but not limited to, any pinball machine, mechanical miniature pool table, bowling machine, shuffleboard, electric rifle or gun range, miniature mechanical and electronic device and game or amusement patterned after baseball, basketball, hockey, or similar games and any like device, machine, jukebox, or game which may be played, which table, device, or game is commonly, but not necessarily, played by the insertion of a coin or at a fee fixed and charged by the establishment in which any such table, device, or machine is located. 
(2)  A coin-operated ride that is manually, mechanically, or electrically operated and customarily placed in a public location and that does not normally require the supervision or services of an operator, and any device designed for and used exclusively as a ride by children, including, but not limited to, any kiddie car, miniature airplane ride, mechanical horse, and other miniature mechanical device, not operated as a part of or in connection with any carnival, circus, show, or other entertainment or exhibition. 
Machines, projectors, or devices described in the definition of adult motion picture arcade in section 36-3 and section 10-441 are not included within the definition of amusement machine. 
(Code 1984, § 402:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-32. - License required. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person shall operate or allow to be operated any amusement machine or amusement center within his control in the city without first having obtained a license from the city to do so. 
(b)  No amusement machine or amusement center shall be used or operated in any location other than that for which it is licensed. No such license shall be transferable to any other person or location. 
(c)  A license shall not be required for the following: 
(1)  An amusement device held or kept for sale or storage or which is not actually in use or displayed for use. 
(2)  An amusement device used for private, noncommercial purposes, such as, but not limited to, home use. 
(3)  An amusement device located on commercial or industrial premises in a lunchroom, break room, employee cafeteria, or recreation room which is provided for use by employees and not available for use by the general public. 
(4)  An amusement device located in a recreation center or recreation room in a multiple-family or townhouse residential complex, which center or room is provided for use by residents, owners, and their guests and is not available for use by the general public. 
(Code 1984, § 402:05) 
Sec. 10-33. - Application for license. 
(a)  Application for a license to operate an amusement machine and/or amusement center shall be made upon such forms as the city may require and make available through the city clerk. The application shall contain the name of the applicant, and if a partnership the names of the partners, and if a corporation the names of the officers of such corporation, the place at which each amusement device is to be located, the home address of all persons listed on the application, the type of amusement device to be licensed, and such other further information as the city may from time to time require. 
(b)  The application shall be signed by the owner, lessee, or operator of the premises at which the licensed machine or center will be operated. The lack of any necessary signature shall make the license application null and void. 
(Code 1984, § 402:10) 
Sec. 10-34. - Fees. 
(a)  The fee for an amusement machine license and amusement center license issued under this article shall be in an amount and on such fee-related terms as are established by the city council in this article and in section 16-81.
