Rental unit owners and operators are responsible to take such reasonable steps as are necessary to ensure that the tenants who occupy such rental units may pursue the quiet enjoyment of the normal activities of life in surroundings that are safe, secure, sanitary, free from noise, nuisances and annoyances, and free from crimes and criminal activity. 
(b)  Definitions. The terms used in this section shall have the same meaning as those defined in the city's general rental ordinance, City Code section 10-343, unless modified or supplemented below: 
City administrator means the City Administrator of the City of Maple Grove. 
Criminal activity means prostitution, criminal street gang activity, threatening, intimidating or assaultive behavior, the unlawful discharge of firearms, or any other criminal activity on or near the premises that jeopardizes the health, safety and welfare of the landlord owner, his agent operator, other resident, neighbor or other third party, or involving imminent or actual serious property damage. 
Drug-related criminal activity means the illegal manufacture, sale, distribution, use or possession with or without intent to manufacture, sell, distribute, or use of a controlled substance or any substance represented to be drugs as defined in Section 102 of the Controlled Substance Act [21 U.S.C. 802]. 
Near the premises means any lot or unplatted parcel of land in its entirety including, but not limited to, any primary structures, common areas, parking lots, recreational areas, open space, or accessory structures or other structures that is adjacent to a premises. 
Premises means the entire lot or unplatted parcel of land upon which there is a rental unit, including, but not limited to, a rental unit and any common area, parking lot, recreational area, open space, or accessory structure or other structure thereon. 
Tenant means any adult person(s) granted temporary use of a rental unit pursuant to a lease with the owner or operator of the rental unit. 
(c)  Criminal background check. The owner or operator shall conduct criminal background checks on all prospective tenants. The criminal background check must include the following: 
(1)  A state-wide (Minnesota) criminal history check of all prospective tenants covering at least the last three years; the check must be done utilizing the most recent update of the state criminal history files; 
(2)  A state-wide (Minnesota) criminal and civil court records check of all prospective tenants covering at least the last three years including all misdemeanor, gross misdemeanor, and felony convictions; 
(3)  A state-wide criminal history check of any prospective tenant in their previous states of residence, if available, covering the last three years if they have not resided in Minnesota for three years or longer; 
(4)  The owner or operator must maintain a current register of tenants and other persons who have a lawful right to occupancy of a rental unit. The register of tenants must include full name, dates of birth, and the most current phone number available. The tenant register along with proof of background check(s) must be available for review by the city upon request. 
(d)  Minnesota Crime-free Multi-Housing Program. The city has established a rental owner educational program consistent with the Minnesota Crime-Free Multi-Housing Program. This educational program does include, but is not limited to information such as: applicant screening, rental agreements, identification of illegal activity, eviction process, the roles of working with the police, crime prevention, code enforcement and public health, licensing and inspections, and active property management. The following are requirements of the program: 
(1)  Owners or operators of two or more rental units must complete the crime-free multi-housing seminar offered by the city's police department or a similar program approved by the city's police department within two years of the issuance of a new rental housing license. 
(2)  Owners or operators of two or more rental units must complete the crime-free multi-housing seminar, or refresher course, offered by the city's police department or a similar program approved by the city's police department every six years before the license for a unit is renewed and thereafter every six years as long as the dwelling continues to be a rental unit. 
(3)  Owners or operators of one rental unit in the City of Maple Grove must attend the mandatory training if there is a violation of the crime-free/drug-free lease addendum required by subsection (e), or there are three instances of disorderly conduct on the property as set forth in subsection (f), in which case the owner or operator must complete the mandatory training before the dwelling license may be renewed. 
(4)  Program attendees will be required to pay a participation fee set forth in section 16-81 of City Code. 
(e)  Crime-free/drug-free lease requirements. 
(1)  Lease addendum. All tenant leases signed following the enactment of this section, except for state-licensed residential facilities and subject to all preemptory state and federal laws, shall contain the following crime-free multi-housing addendum language or equivalent language: 
a.  Tenant, any members of the tenant's household or a guest or other person affiliated with tenant shall not engage in criminal activity, including drug-related criminal activity, on or near the premises. 
b.  Tenant, any member of the tenant's household or a guest or other person affiliated with tenant shall not engage in any act intended to facilitate criminal activity, including drug-related criminal activity, on or near the premises. 
c.  Tenant, any member of the tenant's household or a guest or other person affiliated with the tenant shall not permit the dwelling to be used for, or to facilitate criminal activity, including drug-related criminal activity, regardless of whether the individual engaging in such activity is a member of the household, or a guest. 
d.  Tenant, any member of the tenant's household or a guest, or other person affiliated with the tenant shall not engage in the unlawful manufacturing, selling, using, storing, keeping, or giving of a controlled substance on or near the premises. 
e.  VIOLATION OF THE ABOVE PROVISIONS SHALL BE A MATERIAL AND IRREPARABLE VIOLATION OF THE LEASE AND GOOD CAUSE FOR IMMEDIATE TERMINATION OF TENANCY. 
(2)  Non-exclusive remedies. The crime-free/drug-free addendum is in addition to all other terms of the lease and do not limit or replace any other provisions. 
(3)  Incorporation. The crime-free/drug-free addendum shall be incorporated with all new and renewed leases for a tenancy beginning two months after code adoption. 
(f)  Conduct on rental property. 
(1)  Disorderly conduct. It is the responsibility of the owner or operator to ensure that persons occupying a rental dwelling, whether as tenants or guests, conduct themselves in such a manner as not to cause the premises to be disorderly. For purposes of this section, disorderly conduct means conduct on or near the premises that is prohibited by any of the following regulations: 
a.  Minnesota Statutes, §§ 609.75 through 609.76, which prohibit gambling. 
b.  Minnesota Statutes, §§ 609.321, 609.322, and 609.324, which prohibit prostitution and acts relating thereto. 
c.  Minnesota Statutes, §§ 152.01 through 152.025, and § 152.027, Subdivisions 1 and 2, which prohibit the unlawful sale or possession of controlled substances. 
d.  Minnesota Statutes, § 340A.401, which prohibits the unlawful sale of alcoholic beverages. 
e.  Sections 20-81, 20-82, 20-88, 20-89, and 20-91 of this Code, which prohibit noise and noisy assemblies. 
f.  Minnesota Statutes, §§ 97B.021, 97B.045, 609.66 through 609.67 and 624.712 through 624.716, and section 20-63 of this Code, which prohibit the unlawful possession, transportation, sale or use of a weapon. 
g.  Minnesota Statutes, § 609.72, which prohibits disorderly conduct, when the violation disturbs the peace and quiet of the occupants of at least one unit on the licensed premises or other premises, other than the unit occupied by the person(s) committing the violation. 
h.  Failure to comply with potentially dangerous dog requirements in violation of section 6-13 of this Code and dangerous dog requirements in violation of section 6-14 of this Code or Minn. Stats. ch. 347. 
i.  Indecent exposure in violation of Minn. Stats. § 617.23. 
j.  Assault, as defined by Minn. Stats. §§ 609.221, 609.222, 609.223, 609.2231 and 609.224, excluding domestic assaults. 
k.  Public nuisance, as defined by sections 14-31 and 14-32 of this Code or Minn. Stats. §§ 609.7-609.745. 
l.  The unlawful sale, furnishing, use, or possession of intoxicating liquor or non-intoxicating malt liquor in violation of Minnesota law or chapter 4 of this Code. 
m.  Criminal damage to property in violation of Minn. Stats. § 609.595. 
n.  The unlawful sale or possession of small amounts of marijuana in violation of Minn. Stats. § subd.4. 
o.  The unlawful possession or use of drug paraphernalia in violation of Minn. Stats. § 152.092. 
p.  Contributing to the delinquency of a juvenile. 
q.  Minnesota Statutes § 609.50 which prohibits interference with a police officer. 
r.  Minnesota Statutes § 609.713 which prohibits terroristic threats. 
s.  Minnesota Statutes § 609.78 which prohibits interfering with "911" phone calls. 
t.  Minnesota Statutes § 609.229 (crime committed for benefit of a gang). 
The following actions shall not be considered disorderly conduct: (1) where there is a report of "domestic abuse" between "family or household members" as defined in Minn. Stats., § 518B 01, subd. 2; and (2) when there is an "emergency call" as defined in Minn. Stats. § 609.78, subd. 3 resulting from a tenant, a member of a tenant's household, or guest seeking emergency assistance protected by Minn. Stats. § 504B.205. 
(2)  Determining disorderly conduct. A determination that disorderly conduct as described in subsection (f)(1) has occurred shall be made by the police department when there is probable cause to support such a determination. It shall not be necessary that criminal charges are brought to support a determination of disorderly conduct, nor shall the fact of dismissal or acquittal of such a criminal charge operate as a bar to adverse license action under this section. 
(3)  First instance of disorderly conduct. Upon determination by the police department that disorderly conduct, as described in subsection (f)(1) of this section, has occurred, the city administrator or designate shall give notice to the owner and operator of the violation and direct the owner or operator to take steps to prevent further violations. Notice may be personally served on the owner and operator, sent by certified mail to the owner and operator's last known address, or, if neither method of service effects notice, by posting on a conspicuous place on the rental unit. 
(4)  Second instance of disorderly conduct. If a second instance of disorderly conduct as determined by the police department occurs at the same rental unit or in relation to the same tenant within the 12-month period following an incident for which a notice was sent pursuant to subsection (f)(3), the city administrator or designate shall notify the owner and operator of the violation and must also require the owner or operator to submit a written report of the actions taken, and proposed to be taken to prevent further disorderly use. This written report must be submitted to the city administrator or designate within 15 business days of receipt of the second notice of disorderly conduct that details all actions taken by the owner or operator in response to all notices of disorderly conduct within the preceding 12 months. If no written report is received, the city administrator or designate may cause the rental license to be revoked, suspended, or not renewed pursuant to City Code section 10-353. Any strikes previously issued to a rental unit shall be exonerated if the tenant occupying the rental unit at the time the strikes were issued vacates the rental unit, the vacating tenant does not relocate to another rental unit owned by the owner or operator, and the owner or operator enters into a new lease with tenants who have not previously caused an incident of disorderly conduct in a rental unit owned by the owner or operator in the previous 12 months. 
(5)  Third instance of disorderly conduct. If a third instance of disorderly conduct as determined by the police department occurs at the same rental unit or in relation to the same tenant within the 12-month period following any two previous instances of disorderly conduct for which notices were given pursuant to subsections (f)(3) or (4), the city administrator or designate shall notify the owner and operator of the violation and must also require the owner or operator to submit a written report to the city administrator or designate within 15 business days of the third notice of disorderly conduct that details the action taken in response to the third instance of disorderly conduct and whether the offending tenant(s) will be vacating or continuing to occupy the rental unit. If no written report is received or the offending tenant(s) are or will continue to occupy the rental unit, the city administrator or designate may cause the rental license to be revoked, suspended, or not renewed pursuant to City Code section 10-353. Any strikes previously issued to a rental unit shall be exonerated if the tenant occupying the rental unit at the time the strikes were issued vacates the rental unit, the vacating tenant does not relocate to another rental unit owned by the owner or operator, and the owner or operator enters into a new lease with tenants who have not previously caused an incident of disorderly conduct in a rental unit owned by the owner or operator in the previous 12 months. 
(6)  Postponing license action. No adverse license action shall be imposed where the third instance of disorderly conduct occurred during the pendency of eviction proceedings (unlawful detainer) or within 30 days of notice given to a tenant to vacate the premises where the disorderly use was related to conduct by that tenant or by other occupants or guests of the tenant's unit. Eviction proceedings are not a bar to adverse license action if the owner or operator does not diligently pursue the eviction. 
(7)  Notice of register update. If the police department receives information that a tenant is allowing person(s) to occupy, live, or establish residency in a rental unit without the consent of the owner or operator then the city administrator or designate shall in his discretion cause notice to be made to the owner or operator to include the unlawful tenant(s) full name, date of birth, last known address, and if possible their relation to the tenant, to the register required by subsection (c)(4). 
(Ord. No. 13-14, § 1, 6-3-2013; Ord. No. 14-01, § 1, 5-19-2014) 
Secs. 10-359-10-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - RIDING STABLES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Insurance requirements for riding stables, § 16-439. 

Sec. 10-411. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Licensee means the person having a city license in full force and effect issued under this article for a riding stable. 
    Riding stable means any premises in or on which animals are used for transporting persons either directly by the person riding the animal or indirectly by the animal moving an apparatus upon which persons are riding and for which a charge or fee is made either directly or indirectly. 
(Code 1984, § 460:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-412. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Code 1984, § 460:40) 
Sec. 10-413. - License required; fee. 
    No person shall construct, operate or maintain a riding stable within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license as provided in this article and paying the required license fee as duly established by the council from time to time as set forth in section 16-81. 
(Code 1984, § 460:05) 
Sec. 10-414. - Application for license. 
    Applications for licenses issued under this article shall be made upon blank forms prepared and made available by the clerk and shall contain the following statements: 
(1)  The applicant's name and home address and the proposed riding stable address. 
(2)  The number and types of animals and number and types of apparatus to be pulled by animals which the riding stable is designed to accommodate. 
(3)  The proposed hours of operation for the riding stable. 
(4)  The names, addresses and number of employees and attendants. 
(5)  Such other information as the city shall find reasonably necessary to effectuate the purpose of this article and to arrive at a fair determination of whether the terms of this article have been complied with. 
(Code 1984, § 460:10) 
Sec. 10-415. - Submission of plat or drawing. 
    Each application for a license under this article shall be accompanied by a plat or drawing of the riding stable and the premises upon which it is to be located showing the following information and data: 
(1)  Location, size and capacity of the premises. 
(2)  Location and size of entrances and exits. 
(3)  Kind of ground surface. 
(4)  Location, size and construction of all structures on the premises. 
(5)  Location, size and construction of all walls, fences or barriers surrounding the premises. 
(Code 1984, § 460:15) 
Sec. 10-416. - Insurance requirements. 
    Insurance requirements under this article shall be as provided in chapter 16, article XII. 
(Code 1984, § 460:20) 
Sec. 10-417. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    The council shall have the authority to revoke or suspend a license issued under this article when it finds the licensee is operating in violation of this article or any other governing law, ordinance or regulation or is operating so as to constitute a nuisance, or has failed to provide facilities necessary to the health of the patrons and animals upon the premises. 
(Code 1984, § 460:30) 
Sec. 10-418. - Investigations and inspections. 
    The city shall be permitted at any reasonable time, without notice to the licensee, to examine the premises of the riding stable or investigate the licensee and the riding stable operation. The licensee shall cooperate with the city's investigator in making any inspection or investigation when done at reasonable times. 
(Code 1984, § 460:35) 
Sec. 10-419. - Standards for operation. 
    A licensee under this article shall comply with the following requirements and standards of operation: 
(1)  Conduct. Quiet and good order of the licensed premises shall be maintained and loitering shall not be permitted thereon. 
(2)  Sanitary facilities. Adequate and proper sanitary facilities approved by the city shall be provided by the licensee. 
(3)  Facilities for animals. Adequate and proper facilities approved by the city for the care and treatment of animals kept or used upon the premises shall be provided by the licensee. 
(4)  Sale of food, beverages or other merchandise. Any sale of soft drinks, confections or other articles of merchandise shall be governed by the laws and ordinances governing such business and shall require the same license as if such sales were conducted elsewhere. 
(5)  Littering. No person shall place, throw or deposit any food, beverage, paper, bottle or other waste materials upon the premises except in containers provided therefor, nor shall any licensee permit such conduct. 
(Code 1984, § 460:25) 
Secs. 10-420-10-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 36. 

Sec. 10-441. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, or as further defined in Webster's Third New International Dictionary of the English Language, Unabridged, copyright 1993: 
    Adult body painting studio means an establishment or business which provides the service of applying paint or other substance, whether transparent or non-transparent, to or on the body of a patron when such body is wholly or partially nude in terms of specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult bookstore means an establishment or business which barters, rents or sells items consisting of printed matter, pictures, slides, any virtual reality device, records, audio tapes, compact discs, CD-ROMs, videotapes, motion picture film, or any other audio or visual media and either alone or when combined with adult motion picture rental or sales and adult novelty sales within the same business premises has either 15 percent or more of its stock in trade or 15 percent or more of its floor or display area containing items which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult cabaret means an establishment or business which provides dancing or other live entertainment, if such dancing or other live entertainment is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the presentation, display, depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult companionship establishment means an establishment or business which provides the service of engaging in or listening to conversation, talk or discussion between an employee of the establishment and a customer, if such service is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult conversation/rap parlor means an establishment or business which provides the service of engaging in or listening to conversation, talk, or discussion, if such service is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult health/sport club means an establishment or business which excludes minors by reason of age and is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult hotel or motel means a hotel, motel, boardinghouse, lodginghouse, or lodging room from which minors are specifically excluded from patronage and wherein material is presented which is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult mini-motion picture theater means a building or portion of a building with a capacity for less than 50 persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult modeling studio means an establishment or business which provides to customers, figure models who engage in specified sexual activities or display specified anatomical areas while being observed, painted, painted upon, sketched, drawn, sculptured, photographed, or otherwise depicted by such customers. 
    Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted or invited wherein coin-operated or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled or operated still or motor picture machines, projectors or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time, and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting of describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Such machines, projectors, or devices shall not be considered amusement machines for purposes of article II of this chapter. 
    Adult motion picture rental or sales means an establishment or business which barters, rents or sells audio tapes, CD-ROMs, virtual reality devices, videotapes, motion picture film, or any other visual media and either alone or when combined with adult bookstore or adult novelty sales within the same business premises has either 15 percent or more of its stock in trade or 15 percent or more of its floor area containing items which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult motion picture theater means a building or portion of a building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult novelty sales means an establishment or business which sells devices which stimulate human genitals or devices which are designed for sexual stimulation and either alone or when combined with adult bookstore and adult motion picture rental or sales has either 15 percent or more of its stock in trade or 15 percent or more of its floor area containing such items and other items which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult sauna/bathhouse/steam room means an establishment or business which excludes minors by reason of age and which provides a steam bath or heat bathing room if the service provided by the sauna is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Nude, in addition to its normally understood meaning, means any display of any specified anatomical area. 
    Premises means any lot, building, room, or portion thereof under the exclusive control or use of the owner or operator of a sexually oriented business. 
    Sexually oriented business means adult bookstores, adult motion picture theaters, adult motion picture rental, adult mini-motion picture theaters, adult steam room/bathhouse/sauna facilities, adult companionship establishments, adult rap/conversation parlors, adult health/sport clubs, adult cabarets, adult novelty businesses, adult motion picture arcades, adult modeling studios, adult hotels/motels, and adult body painting studios, and, in addition, all other premises, enterprises, establishments, businesses or places at or in which there is an emphasis on the presentation, display, depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas which are capable of being seen by members of the public. The term "sexually oriented business" shall not be construed to include: 
(1)  Professional offices or schools of licensed physicians, chiropractors, psychologists, physical therapists, teachers or similar licensed professionals performing functions authorized under the licenses held; 
(2)  Establishments or businesses operated by or employing licensed cosmetologists or barbers, performing functions authorized under licenses held; 
(3)  Businesses or individuals licensed in accordance with article VII of this chapter; or 
(4)  The sale of clothing. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities means: 
(1)  Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral-anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of any specified anatomical area, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship, and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sodomy, and zooerasty; 
(2)  Clearly depicted human genitals in the state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence; 
(3)  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; 
(4)  Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, or female breast; 
(5)  Situations involving a person or persons, any of whom are nude, clad in undergarments or in any costume revealing any specified anatomical area, and who are engaged in activities involving the flagellation, torture, fettering, binding or other physical restraint of any such persons; 
(6)  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexually oriented contact with an animal by a human being; or 
(7)  Human excretion, urination, menstruation, or vaginal or anal irrigation. 
(Code 1984, § 427:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-442. - Penalty. 
    Every person who commits or attempts to commit, conspires to commit or aids or abets in the commission of any act constituting a violation of this article or any rule promulgated thereunder, whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons or as principal, agent, or accessory shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. Every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or willfully induces, causes, coerces, permits or directs another to violate any of the provisions of this article, or any rule promulgated thereunder, is likewise guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1984, § 427:36) 
Sec. 10-443. - License required. 
    No person shall operate a sexually oriented business without first having obtained a license to do so from the city. 
(Code 1984, § 427:03) 
Sec. 10-444. - Application for license. 
(a)  Every application for a license under this article shall be made on a form supplied by the city and shall be filed with the director of community and economic development. Such application shall contain the following information, and failure to complete or supply such information may cause an application for a license to be denied: 
(1)  The true name, address, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The address and legal description of the land containing the premises to be licensed, and a floor plan of the premises. 
(3)  Whether the applicant is licensed in this or any other city or has had a license suspended or revoked, or has been denied a license, or has been the subject of any other license-related discipline, in connection with any of the activities required to be licensed under this article or under article VII of this chapter or chapter 4, and if so, when and where the applicant is or was so licensed or disciplined, has had a license suspended or revoked, or has been denied a license. 
(4)  A specific statement as to the specific type and nature of sexually oriented business to be licensed. 
(5)  The name of the manager or proprietor or other agent in charge of the business to be licensed. 
(6)  If the applicant is a natural person: 
a.  The applicant's place and date of birth. 
b.  Whether the applicant has ever used or has been known by a name other than the applicant's true name, and, if so, such name and information concerning the dates and places where used. 
c.  The name of the business if it is to be conducted under a designation, name or style other than the full individual name of the applicant; in such case, a certified copy of the certificate as required by Minn. Stats. ch. 333 shall be attached to the application. 
d.  The street address and city at which the applicant has lived during the preceding five years. 
e.  The kind, name and location of every business or occupation the applicant has been engaged in during the preceding five years. 
f.  The names and addresses of the applicant's employers and partners, if any, for the preceding five years. 
g.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of any felony, crime or violation of any provisions of this Code or state law other than traffic violations. If so, the applicant shall furnish information as to the time, place and offense for which convictions were had, except as to petty misdemeanors and those matters set forth in Minn. Stats. § 364.04 (records of arrest not followed by a valid conviction, convictions which have been, pursuant to law, annulled or expunged, and misdemeanor convictions for which no jail sentence can be imposed). 
h.  If the applicant is married, the name of the applicant's spouse. The applicant shall provide for the spouse the information required in subsections (a)(1) and (3) of this section and in subsections (a)(6)a, b, and d through g of this section. 
i.  The name and address of each person, other than the applicant, who has any ownership, in whole or in part, in the business, buildings, premises, or stock in trade of the business to be licensed; the nature of such ownership; the amount thereof; and the terms for payment or other reimbursement. 
j.  Such other information as the city council may require to determine the applicant's true identity, character, veracity, or ability to conduct a sexually oriented business in a manner that minimizes adverse secondary effects thereof. 
(7)  If the applicant is a partnership: 
a.  The names, addresses and interest of all partners and all information concerning each partner as is required of an individual applicant in subsection (a)(6) of this section. 
b.  The name of the manager or proprietor or other agent in charge of the business to be licensed and all information concerning such person as is required in subsection (a)(6) of this section. 
c.  A true copy of the partnership agreement, which shall be submitted with the application. If the partnership is required to file a certificate as to a trade name under the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 333, a certified copy of such certificate shall also be attached. 
d.  Such other information as the city council may require to determine the applicant's true identity, character, veracity, or ability to conduct a sexually oriented business in a manner that minimizes adverse secondary effects thereof. 
(8)  If the applicant is a corporation or other organization: 
a.  The name and, if incorporated, the state of incorporation. 
b.  A true copy of the certificate of good standing no more than 30 days old, articles of incorporation or association agreement, and bylaws, which shall be attached to the application. If a foreign corporation, a certificate of authority, as described in Minn. Stats. ch. 303, shall also be attached. 
c.  A list of all persons who are officers or directors of the corporation or organization or who control or own an interest in excess of five percent in such corporation or organization, and all information concerning such persons as is required in subsection (a)(6) of this section. 
d.  Such other information as the city council may require to determine the applicant's true identity, character, veracity, or ability to conduct a sexually oriented business in a manner that minimizes adverse secondary effects thereof. 
(b)  All applications shall be signed and sworn to in the presence of a notary public. If the applicant is a natural person, it shall be signed and sworn to by such person; if by a corporation, by an officer thereof; if by a partnership, by one of the partners; and if by an unincorporated association, by the manager or managing officer thereof. 
(c)  The applicant and licensee shall have a continuing duty to immediately disclose to the city any change in the information supplied in the application. 
(Code 1984, § 427:06) 
Sec. 10-445. - Fees. 
(a)  License fee. Each application for a license under this article (whether original or renewal) shall be accompanied by payment in full of the required license fee as specified in section 16-81. Upon rejection of any application for a license, the city shall refund the amount paid. Unless otherwise specifically provided by ordinance, no other refunds shall be made. 
(b)  Investigation fee. At the time of each application for a license (whether original or renewal) there shall be paid in full an investigation fee in the amount specified in section 16-81. No investigation fee shall be refunded. 
(c)  Proration of fee. Pro rata licenses may be issued to new licensees for a partial year. Any period of less than one month that the license is in effect shall be considered and computed as one month for the payment of a pro rata fee. 
(d)  License for premises where construction has not been completed. 
(1)  In the case of licenses granted for premises wherein construction is not yet completed, the council may grant the license, but the clerk shall not issue the license until the construction is completed in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the council or until a temporary certificate of occupancy has been granted by the city for a portion of the premises, whichever occurs first. 
(2)  If the license is issued as the result of a temporary certificate of occupancy, the licensed activity may take place only in that portion of the premises to which the temporary certificate of occupancy applies and only until a final certificate of occupancy has been issued for the entire premises or for a period of six months, whichever occurs first. 
(3)  A full year's license fee shall accompany the application for a license pursuant to this subsection (d), but the actual license fee shall be prorated from the time the license is issued, and any difference shall be refunded. 
(4)  All provisions of this article shall apply to any license issued as the result of a temporary certificate of occupancy. Issuance of a license under such conditions is not intended to relax any of the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 427:09) 
Sec. 10-446. - Processing of license application. 
(a)  Investigation of applicant. Complete applications for licenses under this article shall be referred to the chief of police and to such other city departments as the city shall deem necessary for verification and investigation of the facts set forth in the application. Every individual or person having an interest in the license shall be investigated. 
(b)  Investigation of premises. 
(1)  Each application for a new license or a renewal of a previously issued license shall be investigated as is deemed necessary by the fire chief and building official to establish that the business operation and structure to be licensed or permitted is in full compliance with all building and fire codes, laws and regulations of the state and the city. 
(2)  When the building official and fire chief have found the proposed licensed or permitted operation and premises to be in full compliance with the building and fire codes, laws and regulations, they shall each so indicate in an appropriate place on the application by endorsement thereon. 
(3)  No license or permit shall be issued or renewed pursuant to this article until there is such full compliance and the building official and fire chief have caused their endorsement to be affixed upon the application, or until any conditions designed to achieve such compliance and deemed acceptable to the city council are attached to the license. 
(4)  In the event of the fire chief or building official being unavailable as needed pursuant to this section, an individual within the appropriate department may be duly designated and authorized by the fire chief or building official to fulfill the requirements in this section and affix the appropriate endorsement upon the application. 
(c)  Recommendation; publication of notice of hearing. Within 45 days of the filing of a complete application, the chief of police and any other consultants shall make a written recommendation to the city council as to the issuance or non-issuance of the license, setting forth the facts upon which the recommendation is based. Upon receipt of the written report and recommendation by the chief of police and within 20 days thereafter, the city shall cause to be published in the official newspaper notice of hearing to be held by the city council. The notice shall be published at least ten days in advance of the hearing, and it shall set forth the day, time and place when the hearing will be held, the name of the applicant, the location where the business is or will be conducted, the nature of the business, and such other information as the council may direct. 
(d)  Mailing of notice of hearing. 
(1)  At least 15 days before a public hearing on an original application for a license, the city shall send by mail notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing to all owners and occupants of property within 750 feet of the lot on which the establishment to be licensed is located, and to all community organizations that have previously registered with the city clerk. 
(2)  Prior to the hearing date, the city council shall receive a list of the names and addresses of each person or organization to whom notice was sent, and certification of such list by the clerk shall be conclusive evidence of such notice. 
(3)  The failure to give mailed notice to such owners or occupants within 350 feet, or defects in the notice, shall not invalidate a license provided a bona fide attempt to comply with this subsection has been made. A bona fide attempt is evidenced by a notice addressed to "owner" and to "occupant" of the listed address. 
(e)  Action by council. The city council shall afford the applicant and all interested parties a public hearing no later than 75 days after the filing of a complete application, and shall have the discretion to consider granting, denying, renewing, or declining to renew a license at that hearing any matter including, but not limited to, provisions of this Code deemed by the city council to be relevant to protection of the public's health, safety and welfare and minimization of the adverse secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses. The deadline for the public hearing may be extended upon the written request of the applicant. 
(f)  Notification of decision. The city shall immediately notify the applicant of the council's decision and, in case of denial, the reason therefor. 
(Code 1984, § 427:12; Ord. No. 03-18, § 1, 7-7-2003) 
Sec. 10-447. - Ineligibility for license. 
    No license shall be issued under this article when any of the following conditions exist, which conditions may also serve as reason for suspension or revocation of a license: 
(1)  The applicant or licensee is less than 18 years of age or under a legal disability. 
(2)  The application is incomplete or contains false, fraudulent, deceptive, or untruthful information supplied by the applicant or licensee. 
(3)  The applicant or licensee, or any principal officer, manager, director, shareholder, or owner (if a corporation or association), or any partner (if a partnership) has been convicted of any crime relating to the operation of a sexually oriented business and has not shown competent evidence of sufficient rehabilitation and present fitness to perform the duties and responsibilities, as provided in Minn. Stats. § 364.03, subd. 3. 
(4)  The applicant, or any principal officer, manager, director, shareholder, or owner (if a corporation or association), or any partner (if a partnership) has within two years been denied a license under this section or within the period has been disciplined under or has had revoked or suspended any license issued under this article. 
(5)  The premises to be licensed or sexually oriented business to be operated does not meet all of the requirements of chapter 36 or any other provision of this Code or is a health or safety hazard. 
(6)  The premises to be licensed or sexually oriented business to be operated is currently licensed in accordance with article VII of this chapter, or is currently licensed to sell alcoholic beverages in accordance with chapter 4. 
(7)  The applicant failed to supply all of the information requested on the license application, or the applicant or the sexually oriented business does not meet or has not met all of the requirements of this article or any other relevant portion of this Code. 
(Code 1984, § 427:15) 
Sec. 10-448. - Term of license. 
(a)  All licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be valid for one year or part thereof and shall expire on January 31. Complete renewal applications shall be filed with the city clerk before January 1 on forms provided by the city together with payment in full of the fees as required for the original license. 
(b)  When a licensee makes application for renewal of a current license and pays the required fee to the issuing authority on or before the termination date, the licensee is authorized to operate until final action by the council upon the licensee's renewal application, unless prohibited by council resolution made after a denial. 
(Code 1984, § 427:18) 
Sec. 10-449. - Appeals. 
    An applicant for an initial or renewal license may appeal denial of such a license in accordance with the procedures specified in section 1-14. The council may order and conduct such additional investigation as it deems necessary. 
(Code 1984, § 427:21) 
Sec. 10-450. - License conditions. 
(a)  Posting. A license issued under this article must be posted in a conspicuous place in the premises for which it is issued. 
(b)  Area for conducting business. A license issued under this article is only effective for the compact and contiguous space specified in the approved license application. 
(c)  Transfer. 
(1)  Each license shall be issued to the applicant only and shall not be transferable to another holder or location. No licensee shall loan, sell, give or assign a license to another person or location. Any change in the persons named as partners as the application as required in section 10-444(a)(7), and any change in the persons who are named in the application as required in section 10-444(a)(8)c, shall be deemed a transfer for purposes of this section. 
(2)  Any such change and any transfer or sale of a sexually oriented business shall be reported by the existing licensee immediately to the city. Any new owner or operator wishing to continue operating a sexually oriented business must immediately apply for and obtain a license under this article and may not operate until such license is issued. 
(3)  If the licensee is a limited partnership, a change in the limited partners of less than 25 percent cumulatively over the license period shall not be deemed a transfer. The change in or addition of a vice-president, secretary, or treasurer of a corporate licensee shall not be deemed a transfer; however all other changes shall be considered a change in ownership. 
(Code 1984, § 427:24) 
Sec. 10-451. - Suspension or revocation of license; civil fine. 
    The city council may suspend a license issued under this article for up to 60 days, or revoke a license, or impose a civil fine of up to $2,000.00, upon a finding of one or more grounds for suspension or revocation listed in this section. Except as otherwise provided in this section, any such suspension, revocation, or fine shall be conducted following the procedures specified in sections 10-7 and 10-8, and following a public hearing. In addition, the council may, without any notice, suspend any license pending a hearing on revocation for a period not exceeding 30 days, which suspension shall be communicated to the licensee personally or by leaving the notice at the licensed premises with the person in charge thereof. Any one of the following shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of a license: 
(1)  Failure to comply with any of the ordinances of the city, rules promulgated thereunder, or state law, including, but not limited to, Minn. Stats. § 617.241 (obscenity), Minn. Stats. § 617.247 (pictorial representations of minors), and Minn. Stats. §§ 617.293 and 617.294 (disseminate/display/exhibit to minors). 
(2)  Control or possession by the owner, manager, lessee or any employee of the licensed business of any alcoholic beverages on the premises, or control or possession thereon of narcotic drugs or controlled substances, possession of which is illegal as defined by state statutes or city ordinances. 
(3)  Conviction of the owner, manager, lessee, or any employee of the licensed business of a violation of any ordinance or state statute or any rule promulgated under either, arising on the premises to which the license was granted under this article, subject to the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 364. 
(4)  Conviction of the owner, manager, lessee or any employee of the licensed business of prostitution or any other crime or violation involving moral turpitude or sexual misconduct. 
(5)  Failure to promptly notify the director of community and economic development of any change in the information or facts required to be submitted in connection with an application for a license. 
(6)  Failure of the premises to comply with any health, safety and building regulations of the city, county, or state. 
(7)  Presence of the licensed business being found to be detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of the city. Evidence of any such detrimental effect would include, but not be limited to, increased policing or related service calls. 
(8)  Evidence of a material variance, without prior approval of the city council, in the actual plan and design of the premises from the plan submitted pursuant to section 10-444 or from the original design of the premises when initially licensed. 
(Code 1984, § 427:30) 
Sec. 10-452. - Operation of business. 
(a)  Hours. No business licensed under this article shall be open for business, and no customers shall be permitted on the premises, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. During such hours no person other than the owner, licensee, his agents or servants, or employees may be and remain therein and thereon, and such persons may remain therein only for the purpose of cleaning, necessary repairs, or other work in connection therewith, or as security personnel. 
(b)  Admission of persons under 18 years of age. No licensee shall permit or allow any person under the age of 18 years to enter the licensed premises. The licensee shall request proof of age of all persons the licensee believes to be under the age of 18 years. Proof of age may be established only by one of the following: 
(1)  A valid driver's license or identification card issued by the State of Minnesota, another state, or a province of Canada, and including the photograph and date of birth of the licensed or identified person. 
(2)  A valid military identification card issued by the United States Department of Defense. 
(3)  In the case of a foreign national from a nation other than Canada, a valid passport. 
(c)  Partitions. A licensee shall not allow any partition between a subdivision, portion, or part of the licensed premises having an aperture which is designed or constructed to facilitate sexual intercourse, sodomy, or fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region or pubic hair, buttocks, or female breast between persons on either side of the partition. 
(d)  Enclosed booths. 
(1)  A licensee shall not allow or have on the licensed premises or adjoining areas any booths, stalls, or partitions used for the viewing of motion pictures or other forms of entertainment that have doors, curtains, or portal partitions, unless such booths, stalls, or partitions have at least one side open to an adjacent public room so that the area inside is visible to persons in the adjacent public room. 
(2)  Such areas shall be lighted in a manner such that the persons in the area used for viewing motion pictures or other forms of entertainment are visible from the adjacent public rooms. 
(3)  For purposes of this section, the term "doors, curtains, or portal partitions" means nontransparent closure devices through which a person outside the enclosure cannot entirely see or view activity taking place within the enclosure. 
(4)  For purposes of this section, the term "open to an adjacent public room so that the area inside is visible to persons in the adjacent public room" means the absence of any door, curtain, or portal partition, and may include a device which is made of clear, transparent material such as glass, plexiglass, or other similar material meeting building code and safety standards, which device permits the activity inside the enclosure to be entirely viewed or seen by a person outside the enclosure. 
(5)  Seating or reclining surfaces inside any booths, stalls, or partitions used for the viewing of motion pictures or other forms of entertainment, including but not limited to live entertainment, shall be prohibited. Any such booths, stalls, or partitions of a room or individual rooms used for such purposes shall not be occupied by more than one person at a time. 
(e)  Health inspections. The city shall have the authority to inspect or cause to be inspected the licensed premises and adjoining areas in order to ascertain the source of infection or reduce the spread of communicable diseases. The city shall have the authority to issue orders to the licensee regarding health and sanitation. 
(f)  Visibility of products from outside. No product, service, merchandise or item offered for sale or rental at the licensed premises or any activities which occur inside the licensed premises, or any depiction of such items or services, shall be visible from any point outside the licensed premises. 
(g)  Discrimination. No licensee shall discriminate on grounds of race, creed, color, sex, national origin or ancestry in performing services offered by the licensee. 
(h)  Authority to impose additional conditions. Where a reasonable basis is found by the city council to impose other reasonable restrictions upon a license, taking into consideration one or more of the facts or circumstances set forth in this article, the city council may upon issuance or renewal of a license impose such additional reasonable conditions and restrictions on the manner and circumstances under which the licensed activity shall be conducted to minimize any adverse secondary effect of the sexually oriented business and to preserve the public peace and protect and promote the public's health, safety, welfare, good order and security. 
(i)  Illegal activities. The licensee is responsible for the conduct of himself, his business and his employees and shall not allow any illegal activity to take place on or adjacent to the licensed premises. Specifically, but not by way of limitation, a licensee under this article shall supervise the licensed premises and prevent any specified sexual activities, and shall not allow any person to engage in prostitution, indecent exposure, or disorderly conduct, or to sell or use illegal drugs on the licensed premises or in any area adjoining the licensed premises. 
(j)  Maintenance and cleanliness of premises. The licensee shall engage in practices designed to ensure health, cleanliness and good repair of the licensed premises and which are designed to resist anything detrimental to the public's health, safety or welfare. Good repair shall mean compliance with the property maintenance code adopted pursuant to chapter 8, article V, as well as lack of corrosion, breaks, cracks, chips, pitting, excessive wear and tear, leaks, obstructions, and similar defects so as to constitute a good and sound condition. Cleanliness shall include, but not be limited to, the absence of dirt, grease, rubbish, garbage, semen, bodily excretions, and other offensive, unsightly, or extraneous matter. 
(k)  Adult saunas, bath houses, and steam rooms. 
(1)  All steam rooms and bathrooms shall be constructed of smooth and easily cleanable materials which are impervious to moisture, bacteria, mold, or fungus growth. The floor-to-wall and wall-to-wall joints shall be constructed to provide a sanitary cove with a minimum radius of one inch. 
(2)  Separate restrooms shall be provided for each sex. Each restroom shall be provided with ventilation as required pursuant to the building code in force in the city pursuant to chapter 8, article II, a minimum of 15 footcandles of illumination as measured 30 inches from the floor, a handwashing sink equipped with hot and cold running water under pressure, and sanitary towels and a soap dispenser. Waste shall be removed from each restroom at least daily. 
(3)  Floors, walls, equipment, ceilings, water closets, handwashing sinks, and urinals shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, as described in subsection (10) of this section, at all times. Linens and other materials shall be stored at least six inches off the floor. Sanitary towels, washcloths, hand-cleaning agents, and toilet tissue must be made available at all times. 
(4)  Adequate refuse receptacles shall be provided and emptied at least daily. 
(Code 1984, § 427:27) 
Sec. 10-453. - Inspections; identification of employees. 
    During any hours in which any person is present on the licensed premises, all businesses licensed under this article shall be open to inspection by public health authorities and city building and license inspectors and police officers. Upon demand by any police officer, any person engaged in providing services in any licensed premises shall provide his true legal name and correct address. Failure to allow an unimpeded inspection or failure to provide true name and address information shall be a violation of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 427:33) 
Secs. 10-454-10-480. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - SIGN HANGERS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Insurance requirements for sign hangers, § 16-440; signs, ch. 24; sign hanger's license, § 24-5. 

Sec. 10-481. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of erecting, altering, extending, repairing, or maintaining signs or sign structures within the corporate limits of the city without first having procured a license therefor. 
(Code 1984, § 465:00) 
Sec. 10-482. - Term of license; license fee. 
    The applicant for a sign hanger's license shall pay a license fee in the amount duly established by the council from time to time as set forth in section 16-232, and the license shall run from May 1 to April 30 of the following year. 
(Code 1984, § 465:05) 
Sec. 10-483. - Bond. 
(a)  No license issued under this article shall take effect until the licensee shall file with the clerk a license bond with corporate surety in the form approved by the city attorney in the penal sum of $10,000.00 conditioned that the licensee will pay any and all permit fees required under this article, will pay any fees imposed upon him for violation thereof, and will conform to all provisions of this article. 
(b)  The surety bond shall be written with an insurance company having a minimum Best's Key Rating Guide of A-VII, or as approved by the city's insurance agent. 
(Code 1984, § 465:10) 
Sec. 10-484. - Insurance requirements. 
    Insurance requirements under this article shall be as provided in chapter 16, article XII. 
(Code 1984, § 465:15) 
Sec. 10-485. - Exemptions. 
    The owner, lessee, or occupant of the property upon which a sign is located or to be located may perform the actual work himself without procuring a license or public liability insurance therefor, provided he has acquired a permit for the sign and is not engaged in the business of erecting signs. 
(Code 1984, § 465:20) 
Secs. 10-486-10-510. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - TAXICABS AND PRIVATE AUTO LIVERIES[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Insurance requirements for taxicab operators, § 16-441; traffic, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, Minn. Stats. § 412.221, subd. 20. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-511. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operator means any person owning or having control of the use of one or more taxicabs used for hire upon the streets or engaged in the business of operating a taxicab within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Private auto livery means an automobile used to carry persons for hire other than by solicitation of business by cruising about the streets. 
    Street means any street, alley, avenue, court, bridge, lane or public place in the city. 
    Taxicab means any motor vehicle engaged in the carrying of persons for hire, whether over a fixed route or not, and whether the vehicle be operated from a street stand or subject to calls from a garage, or otherwise operated for hire, except private auto liveries, but the term shall not include vehicles subject to control and regulation by the public utilities commission of the state department of public service or vehicles regularly used by undertakers in carrying on their business. 
    Taxicab driver means any person who drives a taxicab, whether such person be the owner of such taxicab or be employed by a taxicab owner or operator. 
    Taxicab stand means any place along the curb or street or elsewhere which is exclusively reserved by the city for the use of taxicabs. 
    Taximeter means any mechanical instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically calculated, whether by distance traveled or waiting time or by both, and upon which such charge shall be indicated by figures. 
(Code 1984, § 475:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-512. - Private auto liveries. 
    Private auto liveries and their drivers may be licensed as such at the same rates and under the same regulations as taxicabs, except that a private auto livery need not have any designation of the character of the vehicle painted thereon, nor shall the driver be required to wear any metal plate or designation on his cap, nor shall such private auto liveries be required to be equipped with a taximeter. 
(Code 1984, § 475:80) 
Secs. 10-513-10-530. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 10-531. - Taxicab license required; application; qualifications. 
(a)  No operator shall maintain or garage or station for and operate a taxicab within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a taxicab license therefor under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Each applicant for a taxicab license shall apply to the clerk for such license upon a form to be provided by the clerk and must comply with the following provisions to the satisfaction of the council: 
(1)  Be a citizen of the United States or a lawful resident alien. 
(2)  Be of the age of 21 years or over if a natural person, and in the case of any copartnership, firm or corporation, be authorized to operate taxicabs and carry on business in accordance with the laws of the state. 
(3)  Fill out upon the blank form provided by the clerk a statement covering each vehicle to be so licensed, giving the full name and address of the owner; the class and passenger-carrying capacity of each vehicle for which a license is desired; the length of time the vehicle has been in use; the make of car; the engine number; the serial number and the state license number; whether the vehicle is mortgaged; the name of the mortgagee and the amount of the mortgage; and the holder of legal title to the motor vehicle if other than the applicant; or whether the vehicle is leased, licensed, or under any form of contract or is permitted to be used and operated by some other person than the one holding legal title thereto, and what person collects the revenues from the operation of the taxicab and pays the expenses of operating the taxicab. 
(c)  If such application is made by an individual owner, it shall be signed and sworn to by such owner; if it is by a partnership, then it shall be signed and sworn to by one of the partners; and if by a corporation, then it shall be signed and sworn to by one of the duly elected officials of the corporation. 
(Code 1984, § 475:05) 
Sec. 10-532. - Taxicab license fees; transfer of taxicab license. 
    The applicant applying for a taxicab license shall, before being issued the license, pay the required license fee, as duly set by the council from time to time as set forth in section 16-81, for each and every vehicle to be so licensed; provided that, if the license is denied for any reason, the fee shall forthwith be returned to the applicant. All licenses issued under this article shall expire on March 31 in each year. Any license may be transferred during any year only upon the additional payment of a proportional part of the fee by the transferee in addition to the regular fee paid by the transferrer when the license was issued, and upon approval of the council of such transfer. 
(Code 1984, § 475:10) 
Sec. 10-533. - Examination of taxicabs. 
(a)  The police chief, or some other employee in behalf of the city designated by the police chief, or some other person designated by the police chief, shall thoroughly and carefully examine each taxicab before a license is obtained to operate the taxicab. No taxicab shall be licensed which does not comply with the following: 
(1)  It must be in a thoroughly safe condition for the transportation of passengers. 
(2)  It must be clean and of good appearance and well painted and varnished. 
(b)  Such other examinations and tests of licensed taxicabs may be ordered by the police chief from time to time as he may deem advisable and the police chief shall maintain a constant vigilance to see that all taxicabs are kept in fitness for public service. In his discretion, the police chief may require that each taxicab be examined periodically as set forth in this section and the licensee thereof be required to present to the police chief a certificate of inspection and approval. A license shall be refused to any vehicle found to be unfit or unsuited for public patronage, and the license of any such unfit or unsuitable vehicle shall be revoked. 
(Code 1984, § 475:15) 
Sec. 10-534. - Issuance of taxicab license. 
    If the council is satisfied that the public convenience and good order will be served thereby, it may grant a license to any applicant under this article. Each license granted shall contain a number and an adequate description of the taxicabs licensed thereunder. 
(Code 1984, § 475:20) 
Sec. 10-535. - Identification of taxicabs and drivers. 
    Every taxicab which shall solicit or accept business on the streets of the city, or stand or wait for hire, shall have some designation of the character of the vehicle painted in plain, visible letters on each side thereof. Every taxicab shall have its license prominently displayed so that it is visible to the occupant of the taxicab. 
(Code 1984, § 475:25) 
Sec. 10-536. - Taxicab cards. 
    The operator of any taxicab shall cause to be printed in plain, legible letters displayed inside the taxicab a card giving the number of the license, the rates of fare to be charged, and a statement that any package or article left in the taxicab must be returned by the taxicab driver to the clerk's office, where it may be identified and claimed. The card shall also contain the statement, "Ask the Driver for Bill and Receipt," in bold type. 
(Code 1984, § 475:30) 
Sec. 10-537. - Taximeters; rates of fare. 
(a)  Every licensed taxicab shall be equipped with a taximeter which shall at all times be kept accurate and in working condition and shall be in plain view of the passenger. 
(b)  All taximeters shall be approved by the chief of police or designee and each taximeter shall be sealed with case and gear intact. 
(c)  No operator or taxicab driver shall charge any passenger a rate in excess of rates posted on the taxicab card. 
(d)  Every passenger shall receive a receipt when he pays his fare. 
(e)  The requirement for a meter may be waived by resolution adopted by the council. 
(Code 1984, § 475:35) 
Sec. 10-538. - Taxicab stands; solicitation of passengers. 
(a)  The council may from time to time designate certain parking areas as taxicab stands and set forth rules and regulations governing their use as such taxicab stands. By acceptance of a license, the licensee is agreeing to be bound by the rules and regulations adopted. 
(b)  No taxicab driver shall solicit passengers as fares except when traveling around the streets or at a regularly designated stand. 
(c)  No driver shall dismount from his taxicab at any time for the purpose of soliciting passengers, provided that this shall not prohibit any driver from dismounting from his cab to assist a passenger entering his taxicab or dismounting therefrom. 
(d)  No taxicab shall park within 30 feet of any crosswalk unless this portion of the street has been designated as a taxicab stand. 
(e)  Only licensed taxicabs under this chapter shall be permitted to park at any taxicab stand. 
(Code 1984, § 475:40) 
Sec. 10-539. - Driver's license required; drivers licensed to operate in other municipality. 
(a)  Driver's license. No person shall drive a taxicab and no person shall permit an employee to drive a taxicab within the corporate limits of the city without such driver having a valid Minnesota driver's license of a class which allows the driver to carry passengers for hire. 
(b)  License from another municipality. Any driver licensed to operate in another municipality of this state may carry passengers from such municipality where so licensed to any place or point within the city and may freely enter and travel upon the streets and thoroughfares for that purpose, and may receive passengers for carriage to the municipality where the driver of such vehicle is so licensed, and in such case it shall not be deemed necessary for the driver of such vehicle to pay the license fee provided for in this article, but such driver shall not be permitted to solicit business on the streets of the city or to otherwise operate within the city without being licensed under the provisions of this article. While within the corporate limits of the city the driver of such vehicle from another municipality of the state shall have with him the license certificate for the vehicle and display the certificate to any person upon demand. 
(Code 1984, § 475:45) 
Sec. 10-540. - Application for driver's license. 
(a)  Each applicant for a taxicab driver's license must comply with the following to the satisfaction of the council: 
(1)  Be a citizen of the United States or a lawful resident alien. 
(2)  Be of the age of 21 years or over. 
(3)  Be of sound physique and good eyesight and not subject to epilepsy, vertigo, heart trouble or any other infirmity of body or mind which might render him unfit for the operation of a taxicab. 
(4)  Be clean in dress and person and not addicted to the use of alcohol or drugs. 
(5)  Fill out a form to be provided by the clerk a statement giving his full name, residence, place of residence for five years previous to moving to his present address, prior license number, age, height, color of eyes, and year and place of birth; place of previous employment; whether he has ever been convicted of a felony, gross misdemeanor or misdemeanor, or whether he has ever had his driver's license suspended or revoked; whether he has been a party to a lawsuit; whether he has previously been licensed as a taxicab driver, and if so when and where; and whether his taxicab license has ever been revoked and for what cause, which statement shall be signed and sworn to by the applicant and filed with the police chief as a permanent record. 
(b)  All applications for license under the provisions of this section shall be investigated under the supervision of the police chief, and when such investigation is completed the application shall be forwarded by the police chief to the clerk; provided, however, that a temporary license may be issued by the city pending such investigation for not to exceed 20 days. 
(c)  Each applicant for a driver's license must file with his application two recent photographs and two fingerprints of himself of a size which may be easily attached to his license. One of such photographs shall be attached to his license when issued and prominently displayed over or in front of the driver's seat by the driver when driving a taxicab and the other photograph and the fingerprints shall be filed, together with the application, with the police chief. The photograph shall be so attached to the license that it cannot be removed and another photograph substituted without detection. 
(d)  The applicant applying for a driver's license shall, before being issued the license, pay a license fee in the amount duly established by the council from time to time as set forth in section 16-81. 
(Code 1984, § 475:46) 
Sec. 10-541. - Issuance and renewal of driver's license; driver's badge and cap. 
(a)  Taxicab driver's licenses shall be issued or renewed as of April 1 of each and every year and shall expire on March 31 next succeeding. 
(b)  The police chief may cause the renewal of licenses to be given appropriate endorsement of the police chief upon the application for renewal and payment of an annual fee in the amount duly established by the council from time to time as set forth in section 16-81. The driver, in applying for a renewal of his license, shall make application on a form to be furnished by the police chief, which form shall be filled out with the full name and address of the applicant, together with a statement of the date upon which his original license was granted and the number thereof, and shall provide such other information as requested by the chief. 
(c)  There shall be delivered to each licensed driver of a taxicab a metal badge of such form and style as the police chief may prescribe, with his license number thereon, which must, under penalty of revocation of the license, be constantly and conspicuously displayed on the driver's cap when he is engaged in his employment, and shall only be worn by the person to whom the badge is issued. 
(d)  Each driver of a taxicab shall also wear a uniform cap upon the front of which shall be printed the name of the licensee or taxicab company by whom he is employed, or, if employed by a member of an association operating under the same name and colors, the name of such association. 
(Code 1984, § 475:48) 
Sec. 10-542. - Insurance requirements. 
    Insurance requirements under this article shall be as provided in chapter 16, article XII of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1984, § 475:50) 
Sec. 10-543. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  All taxicab drivers shall be courteous at all times and the cab shall be clean, orderly and free of debris. 
(b)  No driver of any licensed taxicab shall carry any other than the passenger first employing a taxicab without the consent of such passenger. 
(c)  No person shall charge or attempt to charge any passenger a greater rate of fare than that posted on the taxicab card. 
(d)  No taxicab driver shall deceive any passenger who may ride with him, or who may desire to ride in any such vehicle, as to his destination or the distance traveled or to be traveled. 
(e)  Every taxicab shall be provided with windows in the passenger compartment of sufficient number, size and tint that at all times persons may be readily seen through such window with sufficient distinctness to identify such person. 
(Code 1984, § 475:55) 
Secs. 10-544-10-570. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - TOBACCO[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Use or possession of tobacco on school property, § 20-1. 
State Law reference- Municipal cigarette licenses, Minn. Stats. §§ 461.12-461.15. 

Sec. 10-571. - Purpose. 
    Because the city recognizes that many persons under the age of 18 purchase or otherwise obtain, possess, and use tobacco, tobacco products, and tobacco-related devices in violation of state law, and because smoking has been shown to be the cause of several serious health problems which subsequently place a financial burden on all levels of government, this article is intended to regulate the sale, possession, and use of tobacco, tobacco products, and tobacco-related devices for the purpose of enforcing and furthering existing laws, to protect minors against the serious effects associated with the illegal use of tobacco, tobacco products, and tobacco-related devices, and to further the public policy of the state in regard to preventing young people from starting to smoke as stated in Minn. Stats. § 144.391. 
(Code 1984, § 421:00) 
Sec. 10-572. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Child-resistant packaging is defined as set forth in Code of Federal Regulations, title 16, section 1700.15(b)(1) as in effect on January 1, 2015, when tested in accordance with the method described in Code of Federal Regulations, title 16, section 1700.20, as in effect on January 1, 2015. 
    Compliance check means the system used by the city to investigate and ensure that those authorized to sell tobacco, tobacco products, and tobacco-related devices are following and complying with the requirements of this article and state statutes. Compliance checks may involve the use of minors as authorized pursuant to this article. 
    Individually packaged means the practice of selling any tobacco or tobacco product wrapped individually for sale. Individually wrapped tobacco and tobacco products shall include, but not be limited to, single cigarette packs, single bags or cans of loose tobacco in any form, and single cans or other packaging of snuff or chewing tobacco. Cartons or other packaging containing more than a single pack or other container as described in this definition shall not be considered individually packaged. 
    Loosies is the plural form of any single or individually packaged cigarette. 
    Minor means any natural person who has not yet reached the age of 18 years. 
    Movable place of business means any form of business which does not operate from a lawfully constructed building with a permanent address, including, but not limited to, a truck, van, automobile, or other type of vehicle or transportable shelter without a fixed address. 
    Retail establishment means any licensed place of business where any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device is available for sale to the general public. Retail establishments include, but are not limited to, grocery stores, convenience stores, and restaurants. 
    Sale means any transfer of any tobacco, tobacco product, or tobacco-related device as a free sample, or for money, trade, barter, or other consideration.
