(6)  Any insect and/or pest that threatens the health of the shade trees, including, but not limited to, the gypsy moth, Asian long-horned beetle, and emerald ash borer. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to permit any public nuisance as defined in subsection (a) of this section to remain on any premises owned or controlled by that person within the city. Such nuisance may be abated in the manner prescribed in either this article or section 14-34. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-158. - Reporting discovery of shade tree pest. 
    Any owner or occupier of land or any person engaged in tree trimming or removal who becomes aware of the existence of a public nuisance caused by a shade tree pest as defined under section 14-157 shall report the same to the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-159. - Licensing of tree care firms. 
(a)  No person shall engage in tree care, without being licensed under this article, except that residents or owners of a subject property and persons holding refuse collector's licenses pursuant to chapter 26, article IV of this Code shall be excluded from the provisions of this article if they are engaged solely in the removal or hauling away of trees or parts thereof. 
(b)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of tree care shall apply to the city clerk for a license. The application shall state the name and address of the applicant; whether applicant is an individual, partnership, firm or corporation; the number, make and style of vehicles to be used by the applicant in carrying on the business of tree care; and, if the licensee will apply chemicals, including, but not limited to, herbicides, pesticides or fertilizer, the names of the individual or individuals possessing the certification or educational degree required pursuant to subsection (c) below, and such application shall be accompanied by payment of the license fee established in chapter 16. 
(c)  All licensees that will apply chemicals, including, but not limited to, herbicides, pesticides or fertilizer, shall employ or contract with an individual (for purposes of this section referred to as the "designated individual") who possesses current certification as an arborist from the International Society of Arboriculture (ISA) or holds a post-secondary degree in urban forestry, arboriculture, or an equivalent area of study, from an accredited institution of higher learning before a license will be issued to the applicant. The designated individual shall be responsible for property and tree protection, provide supervision of tree care, and comply with all applicable American National Standards for Arboricultural (ANSI) standards. A single designated individual may contract with no more than four licensed tree care firms at one time and the licensed tree care firms that contract with a single designated individual may have a combined total of no more than 20 employees or workers who perform tree care at job sites. The number of tree care firms and employees and workers for such tree care firms outside of the city that a designated individual contracts with for licensing purposes shall be included in the aggregate maximum levels provided for pursuant to this article. If a designated individual owns or is employed by a tree care firm, that firm and its employees and workers shall not be included in the aggregate maximum levels unless that same individual is also the designated individual for the company pursuant to this article. A licensed tree care firm with more than 20 job site employees or workers may comply with the requirements of this article by employing or contracting with a designated individual who shall not serve as the designated individual for any other licensee. The designated individual and the license holder or license applicant shall be available for and respond to inquiries and record requests from the city clerk for the purpose of establishing compliance with this subsection. In the event of a major storm or other tree emergency, the city clerk may, upon request by the director of public works, exempt tree care servicers who are under contract with the city to provide removal of diseased or infested trees and stumps from the requirements of this section for services completed under such contracts. 
(d)  Any person, firm, or corporation that provides tree care, tree trimming, or removal of trees, limbs, branches, brush, or shrubs for hire must be registered with the Minnesota Commissioner of Agriculture under Minn. Stats. § 18G.07. 
(e)  No license or renewal shall be granted until the applicant shall first have filed with the city clerk an insurance policy or certificate thereof issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Minnesota, insuring said applicant for at least $100,000.00 against liability for bodily injuries or death of any person not covered by workmen's compensation law, for at least $300,000.00 against liability for bodily injuries or death to more than one person from one accident, and for at least $100,000.00 against liability for damage to or destruction of property in connection with or by reason of any type of tree care. Said policy shall provide that it may not be canceled by the insurer except after 30 days' written notice to the city clerk, and if such insurance is so canceled and the licensee shall fail to replace the same with another policy conforming to the provisions of this chapter, said license shall be automatically suspended until such insurance shall have been replaced. In addition, each license applicant shall also supply a certificate of insurance of workmen's compensation when such insurance is required by state statute. 
(f)  At the time a license is issued, the applicant shall be furnished with a license certificate for each self-propelled vehicle used in tree care. Such certificate shall be permanently and prominently affixed and displayed on the upper half of the driver's side door at all times. In addition, no self-propelled vehicle may be used in tree care unless such vehicle shall have the licensee's name, address and telephone number affixed in a prominent manner on the outer sides of the vehicle in letters of not less than two inches in height. 
(g)  All licenses issued under this chapter shall expire on February first of each year. 
(h)  An application for a license under this article may be denied or a license issued under this article may be revoked or suspended for a violation of this chapter as determined by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017; Ord. No. 18-04, § 1, 3-5-2018) 
Sec. 14-160. - Inspection and application of control measures. 
(a)  The forester shall inspect all premises and places within the city as often as practicable to determine whether any condition described in section 14-157 exists thereon. The forester shall investigate all reported incidents of infestations by any disease or pest cited in section 14-157. The forester is authorized to take all reasonable measures to prevent the maintenance of public nuisances and may enforce the provisions relating to abatement in this article. Diagnosis of shade tree pests may be by the presence of commonly recognized symptoms; by tests as may be recommended by the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Agriculture or the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources; or other reliable means. 
(b)  Except in situations of imminent danger to human life and safety, the forester shall not enter private property for the purpose of inspecting or preventing maintenance of public nuisances without the permission of the owner, resident, or other person in control of the property, unless the forester has obtained a warrant or order from a court of competent jurisdiction authorizing the entry. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-161. - Abatement of shade tree pest nuisances. 
(a)  In abating a nuisance, defined by ordinance under section 14-157, the organism, condition, plant, tree, wood, or material identified as injurious to the health of shade trees shall be removed or effectively treated so as to destroy and prevent as fully as possible the spread of the shade tree pest. Such abatement procedures shall be carried out in accordance with current technical and expert opinions and plans as may be designated by the commissioner of the state department of agriculture. 
(b)  Whenever the forester determines that any tree wood within the city is infected with a disease or pest, which disease or pest may be eradicated or controlled by chemical application of an insecticide, the forester may treat all nearby trees with said chemical insecticide. Spraying activities authorized shall be conducted in accordance with technical and expert opinions and plans of the commissioner of the state department of agriculture and under the supervision of the commissioner and his agents whenever possible. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-162. - Standard abatement procedure. 
    Except as provided in section 14-164, whenever a forester determines with reasonable certainty that a public nuisance, as described by this article, is being maintained or exists on premises in the city, the forester is authorized to abate a public nuisance according to the procedures in this section. 
(1)  The forester will notify in writing the owner of record or occupant of the premises that a public nuisance exists and order that the nuisance be terminated or abated. The notice may be given in person or by mail to the last known address of the owner as available from the property tax records. Failure of any party to receive the mail does not invalidate the service of the notice. A copy of the notice shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(2)  The notice of abatement shall state that unless the public nuisance is abated by the owner or occupant, it will be abated by the city at the expense of the owner or occupant. The notice shall specify the control measures to be taken to abate the nuisance, and provide a reasonable amount of time to abate the nuisance. The notice will also state that the owner or occupant has the right to appeal the determination that a public nuisance exists by submitting a request in writing to the city clerk within seven days after mailing or personal delivery of the notice, or before the date by which abatement must be completed, whichever comes first. 
(3)  If no timely appeal is submitted, and the control measures prescribed in the notice of abatement are not complied with within the time provided by the notice or any additional time granted, the forester or designated person shall have the authority to obtain permission or appropriate court order or warrant, enter the property, and carry out abatement in accordance with the notice of abatement. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-163. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)  If the city clerk receives a written request for a hearing on the question of whether a public nuisance exists, the director of public works shall hold a hearing within 20 calendar days following receipt by the city clerk of the written request. At least three days' notice of the hearing shall be given to the person who made the written request for the hearing. The director of public works may affirm or modify the abatement notice or extend the time by which abatement must be completed. Each owner, agent of the owner, and occupant of the subject property or properties in attendance, if any, shall be given the opportunity to present evidence at the hearing. 
(b)  The provisions of section 1-14 shall not apply to this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-164. - Abatement procedure in event of imminent danger. 
    If the forester determines that the danger of infestation to other shade trees is imminent, and delay in control measures may put public health, safety, or welfare in immediate danger, the forester may provide for abatement without following section 14-162. The forester must reasonably attempt to notify the owner or occupant of the affected property of the intended action and the right to appeal the abatement and any cost recovery. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Sec. 14-165. - Collection of costs incurred by city. 
(a)  The owner of property on which abatement or removal procedures are performed under this article shall be personally liable for the cost of any such service. As soon as the service has been completed and the cost determined, the city clerk shall prepare a bill and mail it to such owner and thereupon the bill shall be immediately due and payable at the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  On or before September 1 of each year, the city clerk shall list the total unpaid charges for each type of such service against each separate lot or parcel to which they are attributable under this article. After notice and hearing, as provided in Minn. Stats. § 429.061, the council may spread the charges against property benefitted, together with a certification processing fee in the amount set forth in section 16-32, as a special assessment under Minn. Stats. § 429.101 and other pertinent statutes for certification to the county auditor and collection along with current taxes the following year or in annual installments, not exceeding five, as the council may determine in each case. 
(Ord. No. 17-03, § 1, 2-6-2017) 
Secs. 14-166-14-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EROSION AND SEDIMENT CONTROL 

Sec. 14-191. - Title; purpose; scope. 
(a)  This article shall be known as the "Maple Grove Grading, Erosion and Sediment Control Ordinance" and may be so cited. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to safeguard property, and to preserve and enhance the natural environment, including, but not limited to, water quality, by regulating clearing and grading on public and private property. 
(c)  This article sets forth rules and regulations to control land disturbances, land fill, soil storage, and erosion and sedimentation resulting from such activities and establishes procedures for issuance, administration and enforcement of a permit. Unless otherwise specifically provided in this article or elsewhere in this Code, this article does not apply to the activities regulated by article V of this chapter. 
(d)  This section is adopted pursuant to the authorization and policies contained in Minn. Stats. Chs. 103B and 462; Minnesota Rules, Parts 6120.2500-6120.3900, Minnesota Rules Chapters 8410, 8420 and 70510.0210. 
(e)  The ordinance codified in this article is intended to meet the current construction site erosion and sediment control and post-construction stormwater management regulatory requirements for construction activity and small construction activity and small construction activity (NPDES permit) as defined in 40 CFR pts. 122.26(b)(14)(x) and (b)(15), respectively. 
(Code 1984, § 441:00; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-192. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means any person who submits an application to the city for a permit pursuant to this article. 
    As graded means the surface conditions existing on completion of grading. 
    Bedrock means in-place solid rock. 
    Bench means a relatively level step excavated into earth material. 
    Best management practices means a technique or series of techniques which, when used in an erosion control plan, is proven to be effective in controlling construction-related runoff, erosion and sedimentation. 
    Borrow means earth material acquired from an off-site location for use in grading on a site. 
    Civil engineer means a professional engineer registered in the state to practice in the field of civil works. 
    Civil engineering means the application of the knowledge of the forces of nature, principles of mechanics and the properties of materials to the evaluation, design and construction of civil works for the beneficial uses of mankind. 
    Compaction means the densification of a fill by mechanical means. 
    Drainageway means a natural or manmade channel which collects and intermittently or continuously conveys stormwater runoff. 
    Earth material means any rock, natural soil or fill or combination thereof. 
    Engineering design standards means a stormwater design manual set forth by the city for the land disturbing activities that occur within the city boundary. These standards are created within the city boundary to preserve, protect and manage its water resources as well as to meet federal, state and watershed stormwater regulations. 
    Engineering geologist means a geologist experienced and knowledgeable in engineering geology and certified by the state to practice engineering geology. 
    Engineering geology means the application of geologic knowledge and principles in the investigation and evaluation of naturally occurring rock and soil for use in the design of civil works. 
    Erosion means the wearing away of the ground surface as a result of the movement of wind, water or ice. 
    Erosion and sediment control plan otherwise known as a stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP) which is a set of plans prepared by or under the direction of a licensed professional engineer or certified contractor indicating the specific measures and sequencing to be used to control the sediment and erosion on a project site during and after construction. 
    Final erosion and sediment control plan and final plan mean a set of best management practices or equivalent measures designed to control surface runoff and erosion and to retain sediment on a particular site after all other planned final structures and permanent improvements have been erected or installed. 
    Grade means the vertical location of the ground surface. 
(1)  Existing grade means the grade prior to grading. 
(2)  Finished grade means the final grade of the site which conforms to the approved plan. 
(3)  Rough grade means the stage at which the grade approximately conforms to the approved plan. 
    Grading means any land disturbance or land fill, or combination thereof. 
    Impaired or special waters means waters identified as impaired by the Agency, and approved by the USEPA, pursuant to section 303(d) of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. § 303(d)). 
    Impervious area means those surfaces that cannot effectively infiltrate rainfall (e.g., building rooftops, pavement, sidewalks, gravel, driveways, swimming pools, etc.). 
    Interim erosion and sediment control plan means a set of best management practices or equivalent measures designed to control surface runoff and erosion and to retain sediment on a particular site during the period in which pre-construction and construction-related land disturbances, fills and soil storage occur, and before final improvements are completed. 
    Issuing authority means the city engineer and his duly authorized designees. 
    Key means a designed compacted fill placed in a trench excavated in earth material beneath the toe of a proposed fill slope. 
    Land disturbance and land disturbing activities mean any moving or removing by manual or mechanical means of the soil mantle or top six inches of soil, whichever is more shallow, including, but not limited to, excavations. 
    Land fill means any human activity depositing soil or other earth materials. 
    Linear project means construction or reconstruction of roads, trails, sidewalks, and rail lines that are not part of a common plan of development or sale. Mill, overlay and other resurfacing projects are not considered to be reconstruction. 
    Maintenance agreement means document recorded against the property which provides for long-term maintenance of stormwater treatment practices. 
    Manual of standards means a compilation of technical standards and design specifications adopted by the issuing authority as being proven methods of controlling construction-related surface runoff, erosion and sedimentation. This includes the Erosion and Sediment Control Manual as developed by the Hennepin Conservation District, 1989, and subsequent amendments thereto, the city's comprehensive stormwater management plan (which includes, but is not limited to, adoption of best management practices (BMPs) of the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency (MPCA), The Walker PONDNET model, and the Shingle Creek, West Mississippi, and Elm Creek Watershed Management Plans) and, with regard to stormwater ponds, those Environmental Protection Agency national urban runoff program design standards resulting in a minimum of 60 percent efficiency of phosphorus removal. 
    New development means nonlinear developments that create more than one acre of new impervious surface on sites that are not classified as redevelopment. 
    Permittee means a person or persons, firm, or governmental agency or other institution that signs the application for a valid permit and is responsible for compliance with the terms and conditions of this permit. 
    Redevelopment means nonlinear projects with one acre or greater of impervious at the beginning of construction, and plans to reconstruct greater than 15 percent of the existing impervious surfaces. 
    Sediment means earth material deposited by water or wind. 
    Site means a parcel of real property owned by one or more than one person which is being or is capable of being developed as a single project. 
    Slope means the incline of a ground surface expressed as a ratio of horizontal distance to vertical distance. 
    Soil means naturally occurring superficial deposits overlying bedrock. 
    Soils engineer means a civil engineer experienced and knowledgeable in the practice of soils engineering. 
    Soils engineering means the application of the principles of soil mechanics in the investigation, evaluation and design of civil works involving the use of earth materials and the inspection and testing of the construction thereof. 
    Stormwater management plan means a set of drawings or other documents submitted by a person as a prerequisite to obtaining a grading or construction permit, which contains all of the required grading permit and watershed approval information and specifications pertaining to stormwater management. 
(Code 1984, § 441:02; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-193. - Penalty. 
    Any person, acting as principal, agent, employee or otherwise, who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. 
(Code 1984, § 441:56) 
Sec. 14-194. - Remedies cumulative. 
    The procedures for enforcement of a permit, as set forth in this article, are cumulative and not exclusive. 
(Code 1984, § 441:62) 
Sec. 14-195. - Compliance with other laws. 
    Neither this article nor any administrative decision made under it exempts the permittee or any other person from other requirements of this Code (such as, but not limited to, chapter 36, article VII, division 5) and the city's engineering design standards or from procuring other required permits or complying with the requirements and conditions of such a permit, or limits the right of any person to maintain, at any time, any appropriate action, at law or in equity, for relief or damages against the permittee or any other person arising from the activity regulated by this article. 
(Code 1984, § 441:04; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-196. - Permit required for land disturbing or land filling activity. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person may grade, fill, excavate, store or dispose of soil or earth materials or perform any other land disturbing or land filling activity, including, but not limited to, lot preparation associated with new home construction, without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(b)  The permit required for lot preparation associated with new home construction shall be the building permit required pursuant to chapter 8, article II. The permit shall not be issued until the certificate of survey referred to in section 8-32 and section 14-204 is approved by the issuing authority. There shall be no fee for the permit other than the required fee for the building permit, and the permit shall not be assignable. 
(c)  The certificate of survey, when approved by the issuing authority, will have noted thereon erosion control measures approved by the issuing authority. Later, as conditions require, such measures may be modified by the issuing authority, and the issuing authority may also require additional such measures. Erosion control measures must be maintained as approved or modified by the issuing authority in an effective condition at all times after land disturbing activity commences and until the earliest of the following events: 
(1)  Until a permanent certificate of occupancy is issued for the dwelling; 
(2)  Until a permanent lawn is established on the lot; or 
(3)  Until otherwise ordered or modified in writing by the issuing authority. 
(d)  Failure of the permittee or its agent or any person identified pursuant to section 14-193 to install or maintain approved erosion control measures in an effective condition as required in subsection (c) of this section shall be a misdemeanor punishable as described in section 14-193. Upon any such failure, the city may also proceed pursuant to section 14-221 and may choose either or both means of addressing any such failure. 
(e)  The remaining portions of this article will not apply to this type of permit except those referred to in this article and except for the definitions. 
(Code 1984, § 441:06; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-197. - Exemptions from permit requirement. 
    The following activities are exempt from the permit requirements of this article: 
(1)  An excavation below finished grade for basements and footings of a building, retaining walls or other structures authorized by a valid building permit. This shall not exempt any fill made with the material from such excavation or exempt any excavation having an unsupported height greater than five feet after the completion of the structure. 
(2)  Digging and filling of graves at a cemetery. 
(3)  Refuse disposal sites controlled by other governmental regulations. 
(4)  Excavations for tunnels, wells and utilities, and all public works projects undertaken by the city. 
(5)  Mining, quarrying, excavating, processing, and stockpiling of rock, sand, gravel, aggregate or clay where established and provided for by law, provided such operations do not affect the lateral support or increase the stresses in or pressure upon any adjacent or contiguous property. This exemption includes, but is not necessarily limited to, those activities regulated by article V of this chapter. 
(6)  Exploratory excavations under the direction of a soil engineer or an engineering geologist. 
(7)  Routine agricultural crop management practices. 
(8)  Emergencies posing an immediate danger to life or property or substantial flood or fire hazards. 
(9)  Any activity where the total volume of material disturbed, stored, disposed of or used as fill does not exceed 50 cubic yards and which does not obstruct a drainageway. 
(Code 1984, § 441:08) 
Sec. 14-198. - General standards for work. 
(a)  All land disturbing or land filling activities or soil storage, whether pursuant to this article or otherwise, and including, but not limited to, lot preparation associated with new home construction, shall be undertaken in a manner designed to minimize surface runoff, erosion and sedimentation and to safeguard the public welfare. Whenever the city engineer determines that any grading on any private property has become a hazard or endangers property, or adversely affects the safety, use or slope and soil stability of a public way, publicly controlled wetland or waters of the state, or drainage channel, the owner of the property upon which the grading activity is located, or other person or agent in control of the property, upon receipt of notice in writing from the issuing authority, shall within the period specified therein repair or eliminate such conditions and begin conformance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The city engineer's regulations may include requirements of this article. 
(c)  Exempt activities under section 14-197 are also subject to the provisions of this section. If the city incurs costs to enforce the provisions of this section because of any activity listed in section 14-197, reimbursement of city costs associated with the correction work completed by the city must occur prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or the city may choose to assess such costs pursuant to section 14-123. 
(Code 1984, § 441:10) 
Sec. 14-199. - Manual of standards adopted. 
    The standards and specifications contained in the manual of standards are hereby incorporated into this article and made a part of this article by reference for the purpose of delineating procedures and methods of operation under approved site development, erosion and sedimentation control plans. In the event of conflict between provisions of the manual and of this article, this article shall govern. A copy of the manual and amendments shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1984, § 441:12) 
Sec. 14-200. - Items to be submitted with application for permit. 
    The application for a permit under this article must include all of the following items: 
(1)  Application on a city-approved form. 
(2)  Site map and grading plan. 
(3)  Interim erosion and sediment control plan. 
(4)  Final erosion and sediment control plan, where required. 
(5)  Soil engineering report, where required. 
(6)  Engineering geology report, where required. 
(7)  Work schedule, where required. 
(8)  Application fees. 
(9)  Performance bond or other acceptable security (see section 14-210). 
(10)  Any supplementary material required by the issuing authority. 
(11)  Unless otherwise exempted by this ordinance, an application for stormwater management approval shall include the following as a condition for its consideration: 
a.  A stormwater management plan; 
b.  A maintenance agreement. 
The stormwater management plan shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 14-203 of this article; the maintenance agreement shall be prepared to meet the requirements of section 14-222 of this article. In lieu of preparation of a stormwater management plan, minor land disturbing projects may install a raingarden or similar stormwater treatment practice, with approval from the city. 
(12)  Any construction activity that disturbs one or more acres is also required to obtain a separate NPDES construction site permit. A copy of this permit and erosion and sediment control plan shall be submitted to the city engineer. No permit to allow land disturbing activities shall be issued until the city engineer has approved this plan. 
(Code 1984, § 441:14; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-201. - Contents of application for permit. 
    The following information is required on the application form for a permit under this article: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of any and all contractors, subcontractors or persons actually doing the land disturbing and land filling activities and their respective tasks. 
(3)  Name, address, and telephone number of the person responsible for the preparation of the site map and grading plan. 
(4)  Name, address, and telephone number of the person responsible for the preparation of the final erosion and sediment control plan. 
(5)  Name, address, and telephone number of the registered engineer responsible for the preparation of the soil engineering and engineering geology reports, where required. 
(6)  A vicinity map showing the location of the site in relationship to the surrounding area's watercourses, water bodies, roads and other significant geographic features and significant structures. 
(7)  Date of the application. 
(8)  Signature of the owner of the site or of an authorized representative. 
(Code 1984, § 441:16) 
Sec. 14-202. - Site map and grading plan. 
    The site map and grading plan required by this article shall contain all the following information. Specifications shall contain information covering construction and material requirements. 
(1)  Existing and proposed topography of the site taken at a contour interval sufficiently detailed to define the topography over the entire site. Ninety percent of the contours shall be accurate within one-half contour interval of the true location. 
(2)  Contour lines that extend a minimum of 100 feet off the site, or sufficient to show on- and off-site drainage. 
(3)  The site's property lines shown in true location with respect to the plan's topographic information. 
(4)  Location and graphic representation of all existing and proposed natural and manmade drainage facilities. 
(5)  Detailed plans of all surface and subsurface drainage devices, walls, cribbing, dams and other protective devices to be constructed with or as a part of the proposed work, together with a map showing the drainage area and the estimated runoff of the area served by any drain. 
(6)  Location and graphic representation of proposed excavations and fills, of on-site storage of soil and other earth material, and of on-site disposal. 
(7)  Location of proposed final surface runoff and erosion and sediment control measures. 
(8)  Quantity of soil or earth material in cubic yards to be excavated, filled, stored or otherwise utilized on-site. 
(9)  Outline of the methods to be used in clearing vegetation, and in storing and disposing of the cleared vegetative matter. 
(10)  Proposed sequence and schedule of excavation, filling and other land disturbing and filling activities, and soil or earth material storage and disposal. 
(11)  Location of any buildings or structures on the property where the work is to be performed and the location of any buildings or structures on land of adjacent owners which are within 15 feet of the property or which may be affected by the proposed grading operations. 
(Code 1984, § 441:18) 
Sec. 14-203. - Stormwater management plan. 
    All projects resulting in site disturbance that creates one or more acres of new impervious surface or fully reconstructs one or more acres of impervious surface will be required to develop a stormwater management plan that meets the requirements of the city's engineering design standards. In lieu of preparation of a stormwater management plan, all land disturbing activities within the city that require a permit only required to follow the construction site stormwater runoff control requirements of section 6 and are encouraged to incorporate the requirements of the city's engineering design standards. 
(Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Editor's note- With the inclusion of stormwater management plan provisions adopted by Ord. No. 18-08 and set out as § 14-203, subsequent §§ 14-203-14-220 have been renumbered accordingly. 
Sec. 14-204. - Certificate of survey. 
    The certificate of survey required by this article shall contain all the following information: 
(1)  Scale of the drawing and a thorough legal description of the property. 
(2)  Names of all abutting streets, dimensions of all lot lines, and dimensions and locations of all easements of record. 
(3)  Locations of all existing buildings on the subject lots. 
(4)  Location of sanitary and storm manholes, hydrants, catchbasins, power poles, telephone boxes and curblines. 
(5)  Location, including front and side yard setback dimensions to buildings located on adjacent lots. 
(6)  Location, including front, side and rear yard setback dimensions to the proposed structure. 
(7)  Outside dimensions of proposed structures. 
(8)  The type of building. 
(9)  Location of stakes established by the surveyor along each side lot line at the proposed front and rear building line. 
(10)  Benchmark description, elevation and location. 
(11)  Grade of elevations to meet sea level datum (1929 NVGD) at the following points: 
a.  Existing and proposed at each lot corner. 
b.  Crown of street at each lot line extended or top of curb. 
c.  Existing and proposed of all major corners of proposed structure. 
d.  Proposed lowest floor. 
e.  Proposed garage floor. 
f.  Proposed top of foundation. 
g.  The top and toe of all other slopes. 
h.  The proposed midpoints or proposed critical points along each property line. 
i.  Any break in grade on adjoining lots within 25 feet of the property line of the subject lot. 
j.  Existing proposed elevations at any point along the property line intersected by an adjoining property line. 
k.  Top of foundation of any existing buildings located on adjacent lots. 
(12)  Proposed retaining walls to be constructed as part of the final grading, including top and bottom elevations. 
(13)  The proposed disposal of drainage and surface water indicating direction of surface water drainage by arrows. 
(14)  Garage notation, driveway location and percent slope of driveway. 
(15)  Proposed slope or grades of ground for a distance of no less than 25 feet in front of and in back of the proposed structure. 
(16)  All existing wetlands, ponds, streams and lakes. 
(17)  Proposed erosion control measures. 
(18)  Signature of registered surveyor. 
(19)  Registration number of surveyor. 
(Code 1984, § 441:19; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-205. - Interim plan. 
(a)  All the following information shall be provided with respect to conditions existing on the site during land disturbing or filling activities or soil storage: 
(1)  Maximum surface runoff from the site, using the method of calculation approved by the issuing authority and maintained in the manual of standards, or any other method proven to the issuing authority to be as or more accurate. 
(2)  A delineation and description of the measures to be undertaken to retain sediment on the site, including, but not limited to, the designs and specifications for sediment detention basins and traps, and a schedule for their maintenance and upkeep. 
(3)  A delineation and description of the surface runoff and erosion control measures to be implemented, including, but not limited to, types and method of applying mulches, and designs and specifications for diverters, dikes and drains, and a schedule for their maintenance and upkeep. 
(4)  A delineation and description of the vegetative measures to be used, including, but not limited to, types of seeds and fertilizer and their application rates, the type, location and extent of pre-existing and undisturbed vegetation types, and a schedule for maintenance and upkeep. 
(b)  The location of all the measures listed by the applicant under subsections (a)(2), (3) and (4) of this section shall be depicted on the grading plan or, at the discretion of the issuing authority, on a separate plan. 
(c)  An estimate of the cost of implementing and maintaining all interim erosion and sediment control measures must be submitted in a form acceptable to the issuing authority. 
(d)  The applicant may propose the use of any erosion and sediment control techniques in the interim plan provided such techniques are proven to be as or more effective than the equivalent best management practices contained in the manual of standards. 
(Code 1984, § 441:20; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-206. - Final plan. 
(a)  All the following information shall be provided with respect to conditions existing on the site after final structures and improvements (except those required under this section) have been completed and where these final structures have not been covered by an interim plan (see section 14-216): 
(1)  Maximum runoff from the site, which shall be calculated using the method approved by the issuing authority and maintained in the manual of standards, or any other method proven to the issuing authority to be as or more accurate. 
(2)  A description of and specifications for sediment retention devices. 
(3)  A description of and specifications for surface runoff and erosion control devices. 
(4)  A description of vegetative measures. 
(5)  A graphic representation of the location of all items listed in subsections (a)(2), (3) and (4) of this section (see subsection 14-202(7)). 
(6)  An estimate of the costs of implementing all final erosion and sediment control measures, submitted in a form acceptable to the issuing authority. 
(b)  The applicant may propose the use of any erosion and sediment control techniques in the final plan provided such techniques are proven to be as or more effective than the equivalent best management practices contained in the manual of standards. 
(Code 1984, § 441:22; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-207. - Soil engineering report. 
    A soil engineering report, when required by the issuing authority, shall be based on adequate and necessary test borings, and shall contain all the following information. Recommendations included in the report and approved by the issuing authority shall be incorporated in the grading plans or specifications: 
(1)  Data regarding the nature, distribution, strength, and erodibility of existing soils. 
(2)  Data regarding the nature, distribution, strength, and erodibility of soil to be placed on the site, if any. 
(3)  Conclusions and recommendations for grading procedures. 
(4)  Conclusions and recommended designs for interim soil stabilization devices and measures and for permanent soil stabilization after construction are completed. 
(5)  Design criteria for corrective measures when necessary. 
(6)  Opinions and recommendations covering adequacy of sites to be developed by the proposed grading. 
(Code 1984, § 441:24; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-208. - Engineering geology report. 
    An engineering geology report, when required by the issuing authority, shall be based on adequate and necessary test borings and shall contain the following information. Recommendations included in the report and approved by the issuing authority shall be incorporated in the grading plans or specifications: 
(1)  An adequate description of the geology of the sites. 
(2)  Conclusions and recommendations regarding the effect of geologic conditions on the proposed development. 
(3)  Opinions and recommendations covering the adequacy of sites to be developed by the proposed grading. 
(Code 1984, § 441:26; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-209. - Work schedule. 
    The applicant for a permit under this article may be required to submit a master work schedule showing the following information: 
(1)  Proposed grading schedule. 
(2)  Proposed conditions of the site on the 15th of each month between and including the months of April through October. 
(3)  Proposed schedule for installation of all interim erosion and sediment control measures, including, but not limited to, the stage of completion of erosion and sediment control devices and vegetative measures on each of the dates set forth in subsection (2) of this section. 
(4)  Schedule for construction of final improvements, if any. 
(5)  Schedule for installation of permanent erosion and sediment control devices where required. 
(Code 1984, § 441:28; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-210. - Financial securities. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit under this article shall provide security for the performance of the work described and delineated on the approved grading plan in an amount deemed necessary by the issuing authority given the nature of the site, the work to be done, and the public interest to be protected. The form of security shall be one or a combination of the following to be determined by the issuing authority: 
(1)  A deposit, either with the city or a responsible escrow agent or trust company at the option of the city, of money, negotiable bonds of the kind approved for securing deposits of public monies, or other instrument of credit from one or more financial institutions subject to regulation by the state or federal government wherein the financial institution pledges funds are on deposit and guaranteed for payment; or 
(2)  Cash in U.S. currency. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide security for the performance of the work described and delineated in the interim plan in an amount to be determined by the issuing authority, but not less than 100 percent of the approved estimated cost of performing the work. The form of the security shall be as set forth in subsection (a)(1) or (2) of this section. 
(c)  The applicant shall provide security for the performance of the work described and delineated in the final plan in an amount to be determined by the issuing authority, but not less than 100 percent of the approved estimated cost of performing the work. The form of the security shall be as set forth in subsection (a)(1) or (2) of this section. 
(Code 1984, § 441:30; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-211. - Permit fees. 
    Fees for the permit required in section 14-196 are to be paid pursuant to the schedule set forth in section 16-179. 
(Code 1984, § 441:32; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-212. - Decision on permit. 
(a)  The issuing authority shall review all documents submitted pursuant to this article to determine their compliance with the manual of standards and other requirements of this article. If deemed by the issuing authority to be necessary, he may request additional data, clarification of any submitted data or correction of any defective submission within ten working days after the date of submission. 
(b)  An application that is deemed by the issuing authority to be incomplete shall result in automatic denial of the permit. 
(c)  The issuing authority shall notify applicant of his decision on the permit within 20 days of receipt of decisions by all other affected permitting authorities having jurisdiction and within three working days of his decision. 
(d)  The applicant may waive the deadlines set forth in this section. However, failure of the issuing authority to meet any such deadline shall not create a right to a permit. 
(Code 1984, § 441:34; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-213. - Term of permit. 
    Permits issued under this article shall be valid for the period during which the proposed land disturbing or filling activities and soil storage takes place or are scheduled to take place, whichever is shorter, but in no event shall such a permit be valid for more than one year. The permittee shall commence permitted activities within 60 days of the scheduled commencement date for grading or the permittee shall resubmit all required application forms, maps, plans, schedules and security to the issuing authority, except where an item to be resubmitted is waived by the issuing authority. The issuing authority may require additional fees, as provided in chapter 16. 
(Code 1984, § 441:36; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-214. - Appeals. 
    The applicant for a permit under this article may appeal a permit denial pursuant to the provisions of section 1-14. 
(Code 1984, § 441:38; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-215. - Assignment of permit. 
    A permit issued pursuant to this article may be assigned, provided all the following requirements are met. The issuing authority shall set forth in writing the reasons for his approval or disapproval of an assignment: 
(1)  The permittee notifies the issuing authority of the proposed assignment. 
(2)  The proposed assignee: 
a.  Submits an application form pursuant to section 14-201; 
b.  Agrees in writing to all the conditions and duties imposed by the permit; 
c.  Agrees in writing to assume responsibility for all work performed prior to the assignment; 
d.  Provides security pursuant to section 14-210; and 
e.  Agrees to pay all applicable fees. 
(3)  The issuing authority approves the assignment. 
(Code 1984, § 441:40; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-216. - Requirements when no improvements are planned. 
    Where an applicant for a permit under this article does not plan to construct permanent improvements on the site, or plans to leave portions of the site graded but unimproved, the applicant must comply with all the following requirements: 
(1)  Meet all the requirements of this article, except that an interim plan designed to control runoff and erosion on the site for the period of time during which the site, or portions thereof, remains unimproved must be submitted in lieu of a final plan. 
(2)  Submit an executed contract as defined in section 14-221 after completion of grading. 
(Code 1984, § 441:42; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-217. - Issuance of permit; conditions. 
    The issuing authority shall issue a permit upon approval of a grading plan and interim plan and, where required, final plan, soil engineering report, and engineering geology report, deposit of appropriate security and payment of fees. A permit shall be issued subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The permittee shall maintain a copy of the permit, approved plans and reports required under section 14-219 on the work site and available for public inspection during all working hours. 
(2)  The permittee and all persons identified pursuant to subsection 14-201(2) and section 14-193 shall at all times be in conformity with the approved grading plan, interim plan and final plan, and this article. Failure to do so shall be a violation of this article. 
(3)  A permit shall be valid for one site, as defined by the site map and grading plan, and shall apply to both excavation and fill activities conducted thereon. 
(Code 1984, § 441:44; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-218. - Tampering with, removing, or failing to maintain erosion control device. 
    No person shall, without the permission of the issuing authority, tamper with, modify, destroy, or remove or fail to maintain an erosion control device, or allow any of such acts, with regard to any erosion control device placed in conformance with an approved grading or erosion control plan, or any such device placed by the city in a public easement or right-of-way. All site maintenance activities shall be performed to the requirements within the city's engineering design standards. No development, utility or street construction will be allowed and no building permits will be issued unless the development is in full compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 441:46; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-219. - Duties of permittee. 
    In addition to performing as required under section 14-217, a permittee under this article shall also comply with all other provisions of this article, including, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Unless this requirement is waived by the issuing authority, the permittee shall notify the issuing authority within 72 hours of: 
a.  The beginning of the permitted activity; 
b.  The completion of rough grading; 
c.  The completion of finished grading; 
d.  The installation of all erosion control devices and the completion of planting requirements; and 
e.  Readiness of the site for final inspection, including, but not limited to, finished grading, installation of drainage devices and final erosion control measures. 
(2)  The permittee shall submit reports to the issuing authority under the following circumstances and shall submit recommendations for corrective measures, if necessary and appropriate, with such reports unless the recommendation requirement is waived by the issuing authority: 
a.  There are delays in obtaining materials, machinery, services or manpower necessary to the implementation of the grading, interim or final plan as scheduled. 
b.  There are any delays in land disturbing or filling activities or soil storage. 
c.  The work is not being done in conformance with the approved grading, interim or final plan. 
d.  There are any departures from the approved grading plan which may affect implementation of the interim or final plan as scheduled. 
e.  There are any delays in the implementation of the interim or final plan. 
f.  There are any other departures from implementation of the interim or final plan. 
(3)  The permittee shall cause all grading material and soil, however placed on a grading site, to remain within the limits of the grading site and not travel onto adjacent property, streets, or other public or private property as dust, mud, chunks, or otherwise, unless approved by all affected adjacent property owners and the city. 
(4)  With regard to fill the permittee shall follow, if required by the issuing authority, a soil monitoring program approved by the city council for imported soils. 
(5)  The permittee must inspect the construction project as detailed in the engineering design standards. 
(Code 1984, § 441:48; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-220. - Modification of plans; inspections; additional reports after completion of work. 
(a)  The issuing authority shall review all reports submitted by a permittee under this article and may require the permittee to modify the grading plan, interim plan or final plan, and maintenance methods and schedules. The issuing authority shall notify the permittee in writing of any such requirement and specify a reasonable period of time within which the permittee must comply. All modifications are subject to the issuing authority's approval. 
(b)  The issuing authority may inspect the site, including a site for which erosion control measures pursuant to a certificate of survey are required to be maintained: 
(1)  Upon receipt of a report by permittee under the provisions of section 14-219; 
(2)  To verify completion of modifications required under subsection (a) of this section; 
(3)  During and following any rainfall; and 
(4)  At any other time, at the issuing authority's discretion. 
(c)  Upon completion of the rough grading work and at the final completion of the work, the issuing authority may require the following reports and drawings and supplements thereto: 
(1)  An as-graded grading plan prepared by the civil engineer including original ground surface elevations, as-graded ground surface elevations, lot drainage patterns and locations and elevations of all surface and subsurface drainage facilities. The engineer shall provide written approval that the work was done in accordance with the final approved grading plan; 
(2)  A soil grading report prepared by the soil engineer including locations and elevations of field density tests, summaries of field and laboratory tests and other substantiating data and comments on any changes made during grading and their effect on the recommendations made in the soil engineering investigation report. The engineer shall provide written approval as to the adequacy of the site for the intended use; and 
(3)  A geologic grading report prepared by the engineering geologist including a final description of the geology of the site including any new information disclosed during the grading and the effect of such information on recommendations incorporated in the approved grading plan. The engineer shall provide written approval as to the adequacy of the site for the intended use as affected by geologic factors. 
(Code 1984, § 441:50; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-221. - Post-grading requirements. 
(a)  Upon completion of final grading and permanent improvements, where such permanent improvements are planned at the time grading is performed, the permittee shall inspect and maintain all erosion control facilities in conformance with the grading and erosion control plan for a period of two years or until the permittee's obligations are released by the city as a result of adequate turf establishment. 
(b)  The permittee(s) must ensure final stabilization of the site after the completion of construction activities and prior to the termination of the permit. Final stabilization is not complete until all of the requirements within the city's engineering design standards are complete that are intended to prevent discharge of pollutants associated with stormwater discharges from the project. 
(Code 1984, § 441:52; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-222. - Maintenance agreement. 
    For projects that require permanent stormwater management, the permittee shall enter into a maintenance agreement with the city that documents all responsibilities for operation and maintenance of all stormwater treatment practices. Such responsibility shall be documented in a maintenance plan and executed through a maintenance agreement. The maintenance agreement shall be executed and recorded against the parcel. The stormwater maintenance agreement shall be in a form approved by the city shall describe the inspection and maintenance obligations of this section and shall, at a minimum: 
(1)  Designate the responsible party, which shall be permanently responsible for maintenance of the structural or nonstructural measures. 
(2)  Pass responsibility for such maintenance to successors in title. 
(3)  Grant the city and its representatives the right of entry for the purposes of inspecting all stormwater treatment practices. 
(4)  Allow the city the right to repair and maintain the facility, if necessary maintenance is not performed after proper and reasonable notice to the responsible party. 
(5)  Include a maintenance plan that contains, but is not limited to the following: 
a.  Identification of all stormwater treatment practices. 
b.  A schedule for regular inspection, monitoring, and maintenance for each practice. Monitoring shall verify whether the practice is functioning as designed and may include, but is not limited to quality, temperature, and quantity of runoff. 
c.  Identification of the responsible party for conducting the inspection, monitoring, and maintenance for each practice. 
(6)  Identify a schedule and format for reporting compliance with the maintenance plan to the city. 
(7)  Records of installation and maintenance activities. The responsible party shall make records of the installation and of all maintenance and repairs of the stormwater treatment practices, and shall retain the records for at least three years. These records shall be made available to the city during inspection of the stormwater treatment practice and at other reasonable times upon request. 
(8)  Failure to maintain practices. If a responsible party fails or refuses to meet the requirements of the maintenance agreement, the city, after reasonable notice, may correct a violation of the design standards or maintenance needs by performing all necessary work to place the stormwater treatment practice in proper working condition. In the event that the stormwater treatment practice becomes a danger to public safety or public health, the city shall notify the responsible party in writing. Upon receipt of that notice, the responsible party shall have 30 days to perform maintenance and repair of the facility in an approved manner. After proper notice, the city may specially assess the owner(s) of the stormwater treatment practice for the cost of repair work and any penalties; and the cost of the work shall be assessed against the property and collected along with ordinary taxes by the city. 
(Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Editor's note- With the inclusion of the maintenance agreement plan provisions adopted by Ord. No. 18-08 and set out as § 14-222, all subsequent sections have been renumbered accordingly. 
Sec. 14-223. - Suspension of revocation of permit. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, the issuing authority shall first have resorted to the procedures set forth in this section before any other enforcement procedure set forth in this article. 
(b)  The issuing authority shall suspend the permit and issue a stop work order, and the permittee shall cease all work on the work site, including, but not limited to, work pursuant to a building permit, except work necessary to remedy the cause of the suspension, upon notification of such suspension when: 
(1)  The issuing authority determines that the permit was issued in error or on the basis of incorrect information supplied, or in violation of any ordinance or regulation or the provisions of this article; 
(2)  The permittee fails to submit reports when required under section 14-219 and subsection 14-220(c); 
(3)  Inspection by the issuing authority under subsection 14-220(b) reveals that the work or the work site: 
a.  Is not in compliance with the conditions set forth in section 14-217; 
b.  Is not in conformity with the grading plan, interim or final plan, or certificate of survey as approved or as modified under subsection 14-220(a), or the erosion control measures required pursuant to subsection 14-196(c); or 
c.  Is not in compliance with an order to modify under subsection 14-220(a) or the erosion control measures required pursuant to subsection 14-196(c); or 
(4)  The permittee fails to comply with an order to modify within the time limits imposed by the issuing authority (see subsection 14-220(a) and, as to erosion control measures, subsection 14-196(c)). 
(c)  If permittee fails or refuses to cease work as required under subsection (b) of this section after suspension of the permit and receipt of a stop work order and notification thereof, the issuing authority shall revoke the permit and issue a stop work order, and the permittee shall cease work. 
(d)  The issuing authority shall reinstate a suspended permit upon the permittee's correction of the cause of the suspension. 
(e)  The issuing authority shall not reinstate a revoked permit. 
(Code 1984, § 441:54; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-224. - Action against financial security. 
(a)  The issuing authority may act against the appropriate security if there exist any of the conditions listed in subsections (a)(1) through (4) of this section. The issuing authority shall use funds from the appropriate security to finance remedial work undertaken by the city or a private contractor under contract to the city, and to reimburse the city for all direct costs incurred in the process of the remedial work, including, but not limited to, staff time and attorneys' and consultants' fees. 
(1)  The permittee ceases land disturbing activities and/or filling and abandons the work site prior to completion of the grading plan. 
(2)  The permittee fails to conform to the interim plan or final plan as approved or as modified under subsection 14-220(a) and has had his permit revoked under section 14-223. 
(3)  The techniques utilized under the interim or final plan fail within one year of installation, or before a final plan is implemented for the site or portions of the site, whichever is later. 
(4)  The issuing authority determines that action by the city is necessary to prevent excessive erosion from occurring on the site. 
(b)  If the city determines that remedial action on a private site is necessary, the permittee by making application and accepting the permit grants the city the right to enter the premises for purpose of the remedial work. No warranty is guaranteed in such work. 
(Code 1984, § 441:58; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-225. - Release of security. 
    Security deposited with the city for faithful performance of the grading and erosion control work and to finance necessary remedial work shall be released when there exists one of the following conditions: 
(1)  Securities held against the successful completion of the grading plan and the interim plan, except for interim plans described in section 14-216, shall be released to the permittee at the termination of the permit, provided no action against such security is filed prior to that date. 
(2)  Securities held against the successful completion of the final plan and an interim plan described in section 14-216 shall be released to the permittee either one year after termination of the permit or when a final plan is submitted for the unimproved site, whichever is later, provided no action against such security has been filed prior to that date. 
(Code 1984, § 441:60; Ord. No. 18-08, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Secs. 14-226-14-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXCAVATIONS, MINING AND GRAVEL PITS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Insurance requirements for excavations, mining and gravel pits, § 16-442; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 28. 

Sec. 14-251. - Purpose. 
(a)  Commercial mining, stripping, excavating and extracting activities are now being and for some time have been conducted in certain places within the corporate limits of the city, in order to remove from the ground black dirt, sand, gravel and other minerals or substances existing on, in or under such place. 
(b)  The city finds that the extraction of minerals by surface mining is a basic and essential activity making an important contribution to the economic well-being of the city. The economical availability of sand, gravel, rock, soil and other materials is vital to the continued growth of the region and the city. The city further finds that it is not practicable to extract minerals required by society without disturbing the surface of the earth and producing waste materials. The danger exists that noncompatible land uses could unnecessarily deny the benefit of these materials to society in the future. It is further found that the character of mining may create undesirable land and water conditions which can be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare and property rights of the citizens of the city. However, if properly regulated and if rehabilitation of surface mined lands is required, mining can take place within the city in such a manner that undesirable side effects of the operation may be restricted to an acceptable level. 
(c)  The purposes of this article are to provide for the economical availability of sand, gravel, rock, soil and other materials vital to the continued growth of the region and the city, to establish reasonable and uniform limitations, safeguards and controls in the city for the future production of such minerals, and to control and minimize pollution caused by erosion or sedimentation, all in furtherance of the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1984, § 440:00) 
Sec. 14-252. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Active gravel pit and active excavation mean: 
(1)  The terms "active gravel pit" and "active excavation" mean any artificial excavation of the earth dug, excavated or made by the removal of the natural surface of the earth, whether sod, soil, sand, gravel, stone, or other matter, creating a depression or depressions exceeding in any one place 1,000 square feet of surface area, the bottom or lowest point of which shall be one foot or more below or lower than the level of the adjoining unexcavated land, in which depression, pit or excavation water may fall, gather, collect or remain stagnant, putrid or polluted, or which depression may be or become dangerous from the standpoint of public safety or health, or to children playing therein or thereby, or which depression may become a public nuisance or deteriorate the value of the adjacent property. 
(2)  The terms "active gravel pit" and "active excavation" also mean any area where the topsoil or overburden has been removed for the purpose of mining earthly deposits or minerals, yet the area has remained idle since the topsoil removal. 
(3)  The terms "active gravel pit" and "active excavation" also mean any area that is being used for stockpiling, storage, or processing or recycling of sand, gravel, soils, or other materials or products derived from gravel mining, even if such materials did not originate or were not produced on the premises. Such operations may include, but are not limited to, concrete mixing, concrete block production, asphalt production (also governed by chapter 10, article III), the grinding and/or crushing of concrete or asphalt, and the processing of petroleum-contaminated soil being managed pursuant to state pollution control agency approval, so long as the processing or recycling does not violate any federal or state law or any of the requirements of any of the agencies referred to in section 14-260(7). 
(4)  Depressions, pits, and excavations made for the purpose of a foundation, cellar, or basement of some immediately pending structure to be created, built or placed thereon contemporaneously with or immediately following such excavating and covering, or to cover such excavated pit or depression when completed, are excluded from the definition of an active gravel pit or active excavation if a building permit has been issued. 
    Impounded waters means any and all liquid substances kept on public or private property in such a manner that more than 500 gallons are above the natural surface of the surrounding ground. 
    Inactive gravel pit and inactive excavation mean all that area for which a conditional use permit or annual license has been obtained for gravel pit or excavation purposes from the city and has not had the topsoil or overburden removed. No actual excavations or mining may take place and no stockpiling, storage, or processing of materials is allowed in an inactive gravel pit or inactive excavation area. The land has the potential to be changed to an active classification at any future date during the annual permit renewal process. 
    License fee means a fee charged annually for a permit as required in this article. The terms "license" and "permit" may be used interchangeably in this article. 
    Minerals and earthly deposits mean soil, clay, stone, sand and gravel and any other similar solid material or substance to be excavated from natural deposits. 
    Operator means any person, including every public or governmental agency, engaged in active or inactive excavation or the processing of sand, gravel, rock, other soils or derived products. 
    Overburden means the earth, rock and other materials that lie above a natural deposit of mineral. 
    Reclamation, restoration and rehabilitation mean to renew land to a self-sustaining longterm use which is compatible with contiguous land uses and compatible with the city's comprehensive land use plan. Reclamation, restoration or rehabilitation is to be in accordance with the standards set forth in this article, including the re-establishment of vegetative cover and soil stability and the establishment of safe conditions appropriate to the intended use of the land. 
    Restoration area means all land areas wherein conditional use permits or excavation permits have been granted by the city in the past and for which permits are no longer requested or issued. Once a land area is classified as a restoration area, it cannot be reclassified or converted back to an active area unless a new conditional use permit is obtained. 
(Code 1984, § 440:05) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-253. - Permit required; additional permits. 
    No person shall open, operate or maintain either directly or indirectly any form of active or inactive excavation or process any sand, gravel, rock, other soils, or derived products unless such person shall first have obtained from the council any and all permits required by section 36-10, an excavation (mining) permit as required in this article, and any other permit required by this Code, including, but not limited to, chapter 10, article III. 
(Code 1984, § 440:10) 
Sec. 14-254. - Application for permit. 
    Application for a permit under this article shall be made in writing to the council on such form as the council may from time to time designate, and shall include the following information: 
(1)  The correct legal description of the premises where pursuant to this article the excavation, removal, processing, recycling, storage or other handling of rock, sand, dirt, gravel, clay or derived products does or shall occur. 
(2)  The names and addresses of the applicant, operator and owner of the land. 
(3)  The primary highways, streets or other public ways within one mile of the boundaries of the pit within the city upon and along which the material excavated or removed shall be transported in normal operation. 
(4)  A map of the proposed pit or excavation area to a scale of one inch equals 200 feet showing the presently excavated area, the area proposed to be excavated during the permit period, and the minimum and maximum elevations of the area, and showing a minimum of 100 feet of the adjacent land on all sides of the proposed excavation area. 
(5)  A rehabilitation or restoration plan providing for the orderly and continuing rehabilitation of all excavated land. 
a.  Such plan shall illustrate, using appropriate photographs, maps, and surveys drawn to a scale of one inch equals 200 feet and with a five-foot contour interval satisfactory to the engineer, the following: 
1.  The removal or planned contours of the land when the mineral removal operations are completed. 
2.  The estimated period of time that the pit will be operated and a schedule setting forth the timetable for excavation and rehabilitation of land lying within the active, inactive and restoration areas. 
3.  Those areas of the site currently used for storage of topsoil and overburden. 
4.  The depth of all water bodies, the slopes of all slopes after rehabilitation and a description of the type and quantity of plantings where re-vegetation is to be established. 
b.  Such plan shall also provide for a hydrogeological study when restoration activities will or may involve the filling of any groundwater excavation. No groundwater excavation shall be filled, in whole or in part, without prior council approval. The hydrogeological study shall include the following: 
1.  Description of each groundwater excavation (size, shape and location). 
2.  Description of the proposed fill activity (grain size distribution, quantity, and placement procedures). 
3.  Description of the aquifer characteristics in the area of each groundwater excavation to be affected by proposed fill activity (aquifer thickness and general geological setting). 
4.  Description of the impacts of the proposed fill activity on groundwater flow regimes. 
5.  Such other information as the city may from time to time require. 
(6)  Location of any and all existing wells and the size and depth thereof. 
(7)  Such other information as the city may from time to time require, including, but not limited to, the location or anticipated location of all stockpiles of aggregate-based construction debris material on the land for which the permit is desired. 
(Code 1984, § 440:15) 
Sec. 14-255. - Bond. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit under this article shall post a bond acceptable to the city in an amount based upon an assessment by the city engineer for an amount per acre or portions thereof for active areas for which a permit is granted, executed by a corporate surety company authorized to do business in the state, conditioned upon full performance of the terms and conditions of this article by the applicant and/or the owner of the premises described in the application, such bond to remain in full force and effect for a minimum period of time of one year after expiration of the permit, which bond shall guarantee the required restoration as well as the other requirements of this article. 
(b)  The surety bond shall be written with an insurance company having a minimum Best's Key Rating Guide of A-VII, or as approved by the city's insurance agent. 
(Code 1984, § 440:25) 
Sec. 14-256. - Insurance requirements. 
    Insurance requirements under this article shall be as provided in chapter 16, article XII. 
(Code 1984, § 440:30) 
Sec. 14-257. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Annual fee required. An annual permit fee in an amount duly established by ordinance as set forth in section 16-81 for each active or inactive gravel pit or excavation operated by the applicant shall be paid by each applicant for a permit and shall be paid at the time of making the application. If the permit is not granted, the fee shall be refunded to the applicant. The permit period shall run from March 1 to March 1 of the following year. 
(b)  Calculation of annual fee. The total annual permit fee shall equal the sum of an active pit fee plus an inactive pit fee, minus a restoration credit, all as calculated pursuant to the following formulas and subject to a minimum total annual permit fee as set forth in section 16-81: 
(1)  Active pit fee: (Acreage of land under active classification) × (Fee per acre established by ordinance). 
(2)  Inactive pit fee: (Acreage of land under inactive classification) × (Fee per acre established by ordinance). 
(3)  Restoration area credit: (Acreage of land which has been completely restored during the previous license year) × (Credit per acre established by ordinance). The restoration credit shall cease once the land is in conformance with the approved restoration or rehabilitation plan. 
Land areas for permit purposes shall be calculated by totaling acreage of parcels of land or portions thereof that have been geometrically divided by straight lines in order to facilitate area calculations. 
(c)  One-time surcharge. 
(1)  In addition to the annual permit fee set forth in section 16-81, each applicant who is to be issued a permit pursuant to this article after July 15, 1987, shall pay, prior to issuance of the permit, a one-time license surcharge in an amount set forth in section 16-81. The surcharge is intended to reimburse the city for the cost of preparing the city's gravel mining area plan which was done pursuant to the city's police power function of regulating the commercial mining, stripping, excavating and extracting activities occurring therein and which was also prepared to further the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(2)  Immediate payment may, at the city's discretion, be substituted with a written agreement between the applicant and the city, secured by a surety satisfactory to the city whereby payment of the surcharge could be made in annual installments extending over a period of up to five years and which installments would be collected together with interest due on March 1 of each year. To be accepted as a substitute for immediate payment of the surcharge, any such agreement must be executed prior to issuance of the permit. 
(3)  Interest shall accrue on the surcharge at the rate of 81/2 percent per annum. Interest not paid in advance shall be compounded annually. 
(4)  If one or more of the annual surcharge installments to be made pursuant to such a written agreement is not paid by an applicant, the city may collect the surcharge by drawing upon the applicant's surety.
