(a)  There is hereby continued in the city a firefighters relief association, whose function is to manage service pension benefits for paid-on-call firefighters, which are authorized under state statutes, and to provide other services to paid-on-call firefighters of the city fire department as deemed appropriate by members of the association. 
(b)  Any proposed change to the association's bylaws or articles of incorporation which will affect the benefits paid from the association's special fund shall not be effective until ratified by the city council. 
(c)  Beginning October 16, 2001, no person hired or employed by the city to fill a position governed by city personnel policies other than paid-on-call firefighter shall be eligible for membership in the firefighters relief association. Any present member of the association who on or after such date is hired by the city to fill any other such position governed by city personnel policy shall not remain a member of the association, nor shall they remain as a paid-on-call firefighter as they will be required to leave the service of the fire department, and any applicable pension benefits shall be handled pursuant to the association's bylaws. Persons who already are both city employees and association members on October 16, 2001, shall not be affected by this section with regard to their status at that time. 
(Code 1984, § 210:20) 
Sec. 18-37. - Emergency operations. 
    The fire department shall utilize an incident command system to effectively and safely conduct emergency incident operations. The first arriving fire officer shall be in command of fire department response functions at the scene of any emergency incident until command is transferred to another officer. The fire department commander on the scene of any emergency incident shall coordinate with other emergency response agencies to ensure safe and efficient operations. 
(Code 1984, § 210:25) 
Sec. 18-38. - Authority at emergency scenes. 
(a)  The fire chief or any fire officer or firefighter in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency involving the protection of life or property shall have the authority to direct such operations as may be necessary to limit or mitigate the threat of injury to persons, or damage to property or the environment, extinguish or control any fire, perform any rescue operation, investigate the existence of suspected or reported fires, gas leaks or other hazardous conditions or situations, or taking any other action necessary in the reasonable performance of duty. In the exercise of such power, the fire chief or any other fire officer or firefighter is authorized to prohibit any person, vehicle, vessel, aircraft, or thing from approaching the scene and is authorized to remove or cause to be removed, towed, or kept away from the scene any person, vehicle, vessel, aircraft, or thing which may impede or interfere with the operations of the fire department. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of an offense punishable as a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The fire chief or any fire officer or firefighter in charge at the scene of an emergency is authorized to place ropes, guards, barricades, or other obstructions across any street, highway, alley, place or private property in the vicinity of such operation so as to prevent accidents or interference with the lawful efforts of the fire department to manage and/or control the situation. 
(Code 1984, § 210:30) 
Sec. 18-39. - Investigation of emergency incidents. 
    The fire chief shall investigate or cause to be investigated the cause, origin, and circumstances of each and every fire occurring within the city pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 299F. 
(Code 1984, § 210:35) 
Sec. 18-40. - Mutual aid. 
    The fire chief or his designee is authorized to respond to requests for mutual aid assistance in the form of fire department resources from any political subdivision within the state, agencies of the state, and federal agencies, for assistance within the state, pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 12, provided the emergency response needs of the city are not compromised and the city administrator or his respective designee is notified when city fire department personnel and/or resources shall be committed to the mutual aid response in excess of 12 hours. 
(Code 1984, § 210:40) 
Sec. 18-41. - Service fees. 
(a)  Establishment. The city council may, by ordinance, as set forth in chapter 16, establish fees for fire protection service and/or emergency response, which are not otherwise specified by contract. Such fees may be established at a fixed rate for certain specific types of incidents or for actual costs incurred by the fire department in responding to the incident. The fire chief shall make a recommendation annually to the city administrator for approval by the city council regarding the fee to be charged for each service noted in this section. 
(b)  False alarms. Fees for response to false fire alarms may be charged to the property owner or tenant for any incident after the second call to the property within any 12-month period. 
(c)  Chemical/hazardous materials spills. 
(1)  Fees incurred by the city for response to chemical spills on roadways, and at fixed private facilities within the city, or in other cities when personnel and equipment from the city may be requested to respond, will be charged to the owner of the chemical, the owner of the vehicle in which the chemical is being shipped, and/or the owner of the facility where the spill occurred. 
(2)  Fees shall include, but shall not be limited to, actual costs for all personnel who respond to the incident for a minimum of one hour and the cost on a per-hour basis for each piece of city apparatus and equipment that responds to the incident for a minimum of one hour. Vehicle and equipment costs shall conform to the most recent cost schedules published by the Federal Emergency Management Agency for disaster recovery, or, if a piece of equipment is not listed on the schedule, it shall be billed at a rate of one percent of its replacement cost for each hour of service. 
(3)  In addition, the bill for service shall include any cost of cleanup of any contaminated equipment and/or repair of any equipment damaged during the incident or its replacement, along with replacement of any disposable equipment, supplies, and/or communication equipment, and administrative costs to be established at ten percent of the total bill. 
(d)  Responsibility for payment; lien for unpaid charges. Each owner of the premises receiving fire department service for the occurrence of a false fire alarm or a hazardous materials spill shall be deemed to have agreed and any delinquencies in the payment for the fire department service to the premises shall be a lien and charge against the premises so served regardless of whether the premises are a homestead or not. In case of a delinquency, the lien, including a certification processing fee in an amount set forth in section 16-291, may be certified to the county auditor with taxes against such property, in the same manner as special assessments on real estate for street improvements, and shall be collected in the same manner as taxes against real estate. 
(e)  Impoundment of vehicles and property. The fire chief or his designate is authorized to impound vehicles or property related to a fire and/or hazardous materials release to be held in a secure location until such time as payment is received for fire department response to the incident pursuant to subsection (c) of this section and/or the vehicle or property may be transported without further risk of injury to the public or damage to the environment. 
(Code 1984, § 210:45) 
Secs. 18-42-18-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- State fire code, Minn. Stats. § 299F.011. 

Sec. 18-71. - 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code adopted. 
(a)  The 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code, as adopted pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, is hereby adopted as the Fire Code for the City of Maple Grove for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life or property from fire, hazardous materials, or explosives. The provisions of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code, appendices B, C, E, F, and G thereto, the International Fire Code published by the International Code Council Inc., (Falls Church, Virginia, December 1999) and any and all amendments and changes thereto adopted by the Minnesota Commissioner of Public Safety through the Division of Fire Marshal and set forth in Minnesota State Rules and Regulations of the Department of Public Safety, Fire Marshal Division, chapter 7510, except as modified or amended by this article, are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article as if set forth herein. One copy of this code shall be marked as the official copy and shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  The director of fire and building inspection services, the fire marshal, and the fire chief shall prepare fire prevention policies for the interpretation and efficient administration of this code. Said policies shall not required approval of the city council. A copy of said policies shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk, fire prevention bureau, and the office of the chief. 
(c)  If there is a conflict between or among any of the provisions or policies of the above mentioned codes, standards or policies, the following orders of precedence shall apply: 
(1)  City's 2003 fire prevention code. 
(2)  Minnesota State Fire Code. 
(3)  Standards of the National Fire Protection Association or other nationally recognized fire-safety standards as are approved by the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-72. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context indicates otherwise, the following words and phrases shall be interpreted as herein defined: 
(1)  Wherever the word "jurisdiction" is used in the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code, it shall mean the City of Maple Grove. 
(2)  Whenever the term "this code" is used in 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code or in chapter 18, article III of this Code of Ordinances, it shall mean the code adopted pursuant to chapter 18, article III, Fire Prevention Code, of this Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  Wherever the word "chief" is used in the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code or in chapter 18, article III, Fire Prevention Code, it shall mean the fire chief of the city fire department or the fire chief's representative(s). Wherever the word "code official" is used, it shall mean fire chief of the city fire department. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-73. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this code or standards hereby adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall fail to comply with such an order as affirmed or modified by the city council or by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein or therein, or who shall build in violation of any detained statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken, shall be guilty of an offense punishable as a misdemeanor for each and every such violation and non-compliance respectively. 
(b)  Notice of violations shall be given in writing and shall contain a reasonable time to comply as well as a statement explaining the right to appeal. 
(c)  The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and when not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  The application of the above penalties shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-74. - Enforcement. 
    Section 103 of the Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  General. The fire chief and each representative of the fire chief is authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-75. - Fire prevention bureau. 
    Section 103 of the Minnesota State Fire Code "General" is hereby amended to read as follows: 
(1)  A fire prevention bureau is hereby continued within the City of Maple Grove. The fire prevention bureau shall be assigned to the department of fire and building inspection services with associated personnel under the direction of the director of fire and buildings inspections services department. the fire chief, in consultation with the director of the fire and building inspection services department, shall be responsible for general administrative policy of the fire prevention bureau as it pertains to the interpretation of the fire code and acceptance of alternate methods and materials. 
(2)  The fire chief may detail such representatives of the fire prevention bureau as may be necessary to administer and enforce the provisions of chapter 18 the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-76. - Negligent fires. 
    Section 104.10 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding a new section 104.10.2 to read: 
(1)  It shall be an offense punishable as a misdemeanor to negligently or carelessly start or cause to be started a fire which endangers the property of another or to negligently or carelessly allow a fire to extend beyond the limits of one's property or property within one's control. The term "property" shall include real and personal property. 
(2)  It shall be an offense punishable as a misdemeanor to negligently or carelessly start or cause to be started a fire without a permit. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-77. - Permits. 
    Section 105 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code "Application for Permit" is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  Permit required. No person shall engage in any activity, operation, practice or function listed below without first having obtained a permit from the fire chief through the fire and building inspection services department of the City of Maple Grove. 
a.  Installation and removal of all fire protection systems. 
b.  Installation and removal of underground or aboveground tanks for the storage or use of flammable or combustible liquids, or gas or any hazardous material. 
c.  Cleaning of kitchen grease hoods and duct work. 
d.  Temporary heating using L.P. gas. 
e.  Spray booths or spray areas involving spraying or dipping operations utilizing flammable or combustible liquids. Spray booths involving the application of powders by powder spray guns, electrostatic powder spray guns, fluidized beds, or electrostatic fluidized beds. 
f.  Refinishing and resurfacing operations utilizing flammable and combustible liquids. 
g.  Tents, canopies, and temporary membrane structures. A permit is required for tents and membrane structures having an area over 200 square feet, and canopies in excess of 400 square feet, or when heat sources, cooking equipment, spark/ember producing processes or open flame are contained within or near the tent, canopy, or structure. 
h.  Carnivals, fairs, and other special events open to the public. 
i.  Smoke removal systems as required by the fire code. 
j.  Storage of explosives, black powder, and blasting agents as in city fire prevention bureau policy. 
k.  Use of explosives as set forth in city fire prevention bureau policy. Application for a permit shall be initially made at the police department. 
l.  Fireworks displays and pyrotechnic special effects material. 
(2)  The fees for such permits shall be in an amount set forth in chapter 16, article VI of the Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  A permit for any open burning or recreational fire shall be obtained from the fire chief through the fire department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-78. - Appeals. 
    Section 108 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby replaced to read as follows: 
(1)  Pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 299F.011, subd. 3, section 108 [of the Minnesota State Fire Code], a board of appeals is hereby continued for the City of Maple Grove. The board of appeals shall consist of five members and up to two alternate members appointed by the city council and shall include the fire chief or the fire chief's designated representative who shall serve as an ex-officio member. The board of appeals shall consider issues related to disapproval of an application or permit issuance, claims of misapplication or misinterpretation of the code, or determine the suitability of alternate materials and requests for variances from orders issued under this code. Requests for appeals shall be made within ten days of the date of decision of the fire chief or issuance of orders. 
(2)  Notwithstanding anything stated to the contrary in section 108 of the Maple Grove Ordinance Code [Minnesota State Fire Code], the provisions of said section 108 shall be available to pursue appeals from decisions of the board of appeals. 
(3)  No appeal to the board, the city council, the state fire marshal pursuant to Minn. Stats., § 299F.011, subd. 3, section 108 [of the Minnesota State Fire Code], or to any other body or court of law, shall relieve the appealing party from obeying any order or regulation arising out of or referred to in chapter 18 of the Code of Ordinances until and unless the order or regulation is reversed or otherwise modified by the city, the state fire marshal, a court of law, or some other superior entity having jurisdiction in these matters. Failure to obey any such order or regulation while it is being appealed shall be a violation of chapter 18. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-79. - Fire or barbecues on balconies or patios. 
    Section 307.5 of the 2003 Minnesota Fire Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and is replacing the following: 
(1)  In any structure two or more stories in height and containing 15 or more residential units, no person shall kindle, maintain, cause, or use any fire, open flame or electric heating element on any balcony or deck above the ground; nor shall such activity occur on any patio set in and level with the ground unless such activity occurs at least 15 feet from all portions of all such units in such a structure. 
(2)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall keep or use any charcoal, nor any lighter fluid, natural gas, fuel, torch, barbecue grill or other similar heating or lighting chemical or device in any place, structure, property, lot, or premises that is any part of a location where fire, open flame or electric heating element is prohibited in subsection (1) above. Charcoal barbecue grills devoid of all flammable materials may be kept in a garage. 
(3)  Barbecue grills that burn natural gas are prohibited in any place where prohibited in subsections (1) and (2) above unless such a grill is devoid of fuel containers and all flammable materials and kept in a garage, or unless such a grill is permanently mounted, plumbed to the structure's natural gas supply, and set at least six feet at all points from all combustibles and all portions of all such residential units. 
(4)  It shall be a violation of this section for a person to conduct or allow any of the activities prohibited therein. The term "person" shall include, but not be limited to, the owner of real property described in subsections (1) through (3) above, the owner's agent, and any tenant of such real property. 
Exception: In buildings that are protected throughout with an approved NFPA 13 fire sprinkler system and having dry sidewalls protecting each individual combustible or non-combustible deck or patio, barbecue grills are allowed when approved by the building owner. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-80. - Premises identification. 
    Section 505 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  General. 
a.  Approved numbers or addresses in compliance with the requirements of the Maple Grove Ordinance Code shall be placed on all new and existing buildings in such a position as to be plainly visible and legible from the street or road fronting the property. Said numbers shall contrast with their background. Buildings, which have a range of addresses for one building, shall display the range of numbers or addresses from lowest to highest as required above. 
b.  Buildings with multiple tenants/addressees shall place approved numbers or addresses on front and rear doors identifying each address in the manner required in subsection (1)a. of this section. 
c.  Buildings that are remote/auxiliary from the main building shall display approved numbers or addresses on each building in the manner required in subsection (1)a. of this section and in such a manner as to be visible from either direction of travel on the road or street fronting the property. 
d.  If any building is too remote from the fronting road or street to make it unreasonable to be seen from the fronting road or street, a sign or post with visible and legible approved numbers or addresses, or range of numbers or addresses from lowest to highest, shall be placed at the driveway entrance in such a manner that the numbers or addresses are visible from either direction of travel on said road or street. 
e.  Approved numbers of addresses shall be placed on all construction sites in such a position as to be plainly visible and legible from the street or road fronting the property. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-81. - Fire hydrant systems. 
    Section 508.5.1 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
Where a portion of the facility or building hereafter constructed or moved into or within the jurisdiction is more than 150 feet from a hydrant on a fire apparatus road, as measured by an approved route around the exterior of the facility or building, on site fire hydrants and mains shall be provided where required by the code official. 
a.  For buildings equipped throughout with an approved fire sprinkler system installed in accordance with NFPA 13 or NFPA 13R, the distance requirement shall be one fire hydrant within 100 feet of the fire department connection and 600 feet for all other fire hydrants. 
b.  In buildings with high piled combustible storage or buildings that are inherently hazardous in nature because of hazardous processes or which store, use, or handle flammable, combustible or hazardous materials, additional fire hydrants may be required by the code official. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-82. - Hydrants. 
    Sections 508.5.5 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
A five-foot clear space shall be maintained around the circumference of fire hydrants except as otherwise required or approved. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-83. - Fire flow and fire hydrants. 
    Appendix C, section C103.1 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
Number of fire hydrants. The minimum number of fire hydrants available to a building shall not be less than that listed in table C105.1 unless the required fire flow can be obtained from fewer hydrants. This fire flow shall be demonstrated using flow-testing procedures as approved by the fire marshal. The number of fire hydrants available to a complex or subdivision shall not be less than that determined by spacing requirements listed in table C105.1 when applied to fire apparatus access roads and perimeter public streets from which fire operations could be conducted. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-84. - Considerations of existing fire hydrants. 
    Appendix C, section C104.1 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
Existing fire hydrants on public streets are allowed to be considered as available. Existing fire hydrants on adjacent properties shall not be considered available unless fire apparatus access roads extend between properties and easements are established to prevent obstruction of such roads. Hydrants on public streets must be on the same side of the street to be considered as available. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-85. - Identification. 
    Sections 510.1 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
Fire-protection equipment shall be clearly identified in a manner approved by the fire chief to prevent obstruction by parking and other obstructions. Rooms containing controls for air-conditioning systems, sprinkler risers and valves, smoke control/exhaust systems, or other fire detection, suppression, or control elements shall be identified for the use of the fire department. Approved signs required to identify fire protection equipment and equipment locations, shall be constructed of durable materials, permanently installed and readily visible. A sign, plainly visible from the street or road fronting the property, shall be placed on all exterior doors to identify the location of the fire department sprinkler riser and shall read: "Fire Department Sprinkler Riser." Rooms containing smoke exhaust system controls shall read: "Fire Department Smoke Exhaust Control Room." 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-86. - Maintenance of fire protection systems and equipment. 
    Sections 901.6 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  Maintenance. Fire sprinkler systems, fire hydrant systems, standpipe systems, fire alarm systems, portable fire extinguisher, smoke and heat ventilators, smoke-removal systems, coiling fire doors, and other fire-protective or extinguishing systems or appliances shall be maintained in an operative condition at all times and shall be replaced or repaired when defective. 
(2)  Inspection, testing and reporting. Reports of tests and inspections completed by a competent person, or a licensed contractor in connection with fire alarm systems or automatic sprinkler and standpipe systems, shall be delivered by such person or by the owner of the property on which any such system is located to the Maple Grove Fire Prevention Bureau annually for each system and sub-system thereof located on said property. Exception: NFPA 13D systems and NFPA 13R systems not related to residential buildings with common egress or gathering areas. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-87. - Problematic systems and systems out of service. 
    Sections 901.7 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
The fire prevention bureau shall be notified before any required fire-protection system is out of service and upon on restoration of service. In the event of a failure of a fire-protection system or an excessive number of accidental activations, the fire department or fire prevention bureau is authorized to require the building owner or occupant to provide firewatch personnel in accordance with fire prevention bureau policy until the system is repaired. When a firewatch is provided by fire department personnel or fire prevention bureau personnel the fees shall be in the amount set forth in chapter 16 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-88. - Protection of commercial cooking operations. 
    Sections 904.11.6 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  Shutoffs, valves, or switches for automatic power, fuel and ventilation shutoff shall be of the type that requires manual operation to reset. Permanent signage for the manual reset switch shall be installed next to the said switch and shall contain the following language for automatic fire sprinkler systems in a visible legible form using words, which contrast with the background of the sign. Said sign shall read as follows: 
MANUAL RE-SET WARNING: 


Before resetting: Turn-off all gas valves. 
After resetting: Light gas pilots before turning on burner control valves.  
Gas Manual Reset  
The gas manual re-set warning sign shall be installed at the reset button locations. 
Electrical Kitchen Appliance Manual Re-set  
The electrical kitchen manual re-set warning sign shall be installed at re-set button or circuit breaker locations. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-89. - Operations and maintenance. 
    Section 904.11.6.3 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  Hoods, grease-removal devices, fans, ducts, and other appurtenances shall be cleaned at frequent intervals, as specified by the fire marshal. Cleanings shall be recorded, and records shall state the extent, time, and date of cleaning. Such records shall be maintained on the premises. 
(2)  The hoods, grease-removal devices, fans, ducts, and other appurtenances shall be cleaned to bare metal. There shall be no grease or carbonized grease left in the hood, duct system, or fan assembly. No coatings shall be sprayed or applied on to the clean ductwork after cleaning. All ductwork access panels/doors, fire rated shafts and listed fire rated duct wrap enclosure systems shall be properly reassembled to its original listing after cleaning is completed. If any equipment is damaged or missing parts, the cleaning company shall notify the fire inspector at the time of inspection. 
(3)  Pursuant to the authority set forth in section 904.11.6.3 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code identified in section 18-82 of the Code of Ordinances, the fire prevention bureau is hereby authorized to conduct inspections of kitchen grease hoods and ducts and fire extinguishing equipment for their protection to determine compliance with section 904.11.6.3 of said fire code. 
(4)  The fire prevention bureau may charge a fee for such inspections, which fee shall be as set forth in chapter 16 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-90. - Mechanical smoke exhaust. 
    Subp. 34, section 910.4.3 and subp. 36, section 910.5.3 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
A five-minute delay shall be provided between the sprinkler water flow signal and activation of the exhaust fans. The exhaust fans shall shut off/reset after 60 minutes. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-91. - Restricted districts for certain fire hazards. 
    Section 2206.2.7 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language. 
(1)  Storage or dispensing of flammable, combustible, or hazardous liquids and flammable and combustible liquid motor vehicle fuel-dispensing stations in any outside aboveground tank is prohibited under any of the following conditions: 
a.  Within 300 feet of any lake, pond, stream, wetland, or residentially zoned property. 
b.  If the tank volume or aggregate volume of aboveground tanks on the property exceeds or will exceed 6,000 gallons. 
c.  If the tank is used for retail sales of motor fuels or contains motor fuels used for other than private and/or fleet purposes. 
(2)  Design and construction-General. When approved by the fire chief, the dispensing of class I and class II liquids from a fuel dispensing systems supplied by exterior aboveground tanks may be permitted under the following conditions: 
a.  Where more than one tank is used, all aboveground tanks shall be protected by an approved fire protection system when required by the chief. 
b.  All tanks shall be placed on a concrete pad. Said pad shall be provided with anchors to attach the tank. If dispensing will be provided, concrete pad shall extend to the vehicle parking area. Concrete pad shall be designed to accommodate the largest size vehicle that will be fueled. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-92. - Liquefied petroleum gas. 
    Chapter 38, table 3.2.2.2 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
Where the maximum aggregate capacity of any one installation exceeds 1,000 gallons, a separation distance of 300 feet shall be provided from any residential property line. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-93. - Definition. 
    Chapter 38, section 1.7 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following definition: 
Line of adjoining property, which may be built upon. Wherever in said Fire Code the phrase "line of adjoining property which may be built upon" or similar language is used, "line" referred to shall be the boundary line of the adjoining property or the opposite side of a public way and not any other line such as a setback line. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-94. - Storage of portable liquefied petroleum gases (L.P. gas). 
    Chapter 38, section 5.3.1 and 5.3.2 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended by adding the following language: 
(1)  The storage of portable containers containing liquefied petroleum gases inside buildings is prohibited. 
(2)  Portable containers (whether empty, partially full or full) shall be stored outside of buildings in an approved locking enclosure protected against tampering. 
(3)  L.P. gas enclosures required in subsection (2) of this section shall not be located within ten feet of any exit doorway, window, crawlspace opening, stairway, or in a location that would impede egress, or within 15 feet of any intake to a direct-vent gas appliance, intake to a mechanical ventilation system, or any external source of ignition such as, but not limited to, open flame, compressor, or central air conditioning compressor. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-96. - Manufacturing of fireworks. 
    Section 7801.3.1.1 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended and should read as follows: 
The manufacturing of fireworks is prohibited within the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Sec. 18-97. - Storage for sale, display, expose for sale, and retail and wholesale sale of legal consumer fireworks. 
    Section 7801.3.1.4 of the 2003 Minnesota State Fire Code is hereby amended and should read as follows: 
Fireworks shall mean both "legal consumer fireworks" and "fireworks" as defined by Minn. Stats. § 624.20. 
Legal consumer fireworks shall mean those items listed in Minn. Stats. § 624.20, subd. 1(c), as not included in the term fireworks, but does not include string poppers, party poppers, and snappers. 
It shall be unlawful to store for sale, display, expose for sale and to sell fireworks within the boundaries of the city in violation of Minn. Stats. §§ 624.20-624.25 and the Code of Ordinances. 
Legal consumer fireworks may be sold upon issuance of a license issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-11, § 1, 4-7-2003) 
Secs. 18-98-18-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS FOR FIRE PREVENTION SYSTEMS 

Sec. 18-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire protection system. The definition of the term "fire protection system" as set forth in Minn. Stats. § 429.011, subd. 14, is hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth in this section. Fire protection systems shall also include, but are not limited to, sprinkler systems, underground water mains for sprinkler systems, fire hydrants, fire alarm systems, special suppression systems, and smoke removal systems in affiliation with high-piled storage. 
    Improvement means the construction, reconstruction, installation, alteration, extension, operation, maintenance, and promotion of a fire protection system in an existing building, regardless of its use as a residence, business, institution, or other category of use. 
(Code 1984, § 361:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-122. - Petition; conditions. 
(a)  Whenever all owners of real property named as the location of any contemplated improvement shall petition the city council to construct the improvement and to assess the entire cost against the property, the council may, without a public hearing, adopt a resolution determining such fact and ordering the improvement. 
(b)  Except as may otherwise be provided in this article, the petition, its consideration, and all activities taken pursuant to petition shall comply with the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 429, as they apply to fire sprinkler systems and improvements. 
(c)  The city will not accept any petition requesting that the city own and install a fire protection system. 
(d)  The petition shall contain the plans and specifications for the improvement and the estimated cost of the improvement. 
(e)  Unless warranted by special circumstances, all petitions for the special assessment of the project must be received and acted upon by the city council prior to the start of any improvement. 
(1)  Consideration of any petition is subject to a determination by the city council in its sole discretion that sufficient city funds are available for the project. City staff shall periodically advise the council with regard to the availability of appropriate funds. 
(2)  The petition will not be approved unless the improvement is a permanent built-in fire protection feature. 
(3)  The city shall not approve the petition until it has reviewed and approved the plans, specifications, and cost estimates contained in the petition. 
(f)  The owners shall be responsible for contracting for the actual installation of a fire protection system. However, the city shall have the final right to disapprove of any contractor selected by the owner. 
(g)  At or before the time a contract is signed for the installation of a petitioned fire protection system, all the following shall occur: 
(1)  The contractor shall furnish the city a performance and payment bond as security for the faithful performance and payment of all its obligations under the contract. Such bond shall be in a sum equal to the construction estimate contained in the petition, shall name the city as obligee, shall be in a form approved by the city, and shall be with a surety company authorized to do business in the state. 
(2)  The petitioners (all the owners of the real property) shall provide the city with a surety in a form satisfactory to the city, in the amount of at least 25 percent of the construction estimate, the city's administrative costs, and interest charges. The surety shall be a guarantee that special assessment installments are timely paid to enable the city to pay the required debt service payment relating to the construction of the fire protection system. The city may draw on the surety for cash flow purposes to supplement the owner's payments when the owners are delinquent in the payment of the special assessments. 
(3)  The petitioners must waive all rights to a public hearing and any appeal of the special assessment adopted by the city council, including, but not limited to, those set forth in Minn. Stats. § 429.031, subd. 3, and Minn. Stats. § 429.081. 
(h)  Prior to the start of any improvement, the petitioner must obtain at the petitioner's expense all permits and approvals required by the city and any other governmental authority having jurisdiction in the matter. 
(i)  No payments shall be made by the city for any installation until the work is completed, reviewed, inspected, tested, and finally approved by the city and the assessment adopted. Any payment made shall be payable to the petitioners (property owners) and the contractor who supplies the payment and performance bonds required in subsection (g)(1) of this section. 
(j)  The amount to be specially assessed for the project shall not exceed the amount of the construction estimate contained in the petition, plus any city administrative costs and interest charges. The petitioners shall be responsible for any construction costs exceeding the amount of the construction estimate. 
(k)  No special assessments will be made for a period of more than ten years, except as otherwise determined by the council. 
(l)  If the petitioners request the abandonment of the special assessment project, all city costs incurred must be reimbursed by the petitioners. Abandonment may not be requested once any contract has been awarded in connection with the project. 
(Code 1984, § 361:05) 
Sec. 18-123. - Financing. 
(a)  At any time after an improvement is ordered, the city council may issue obligations in such amount as it deems necessary to defray in whole or in part the expense incurred and estimated to be incurred in making the improvement, including every item of cost of the kinds authorized in Minn. Stats. § 475.65. 
(b)  The council may, by resolution adopted prior to the sale of obligations, pledge the full faith, credit, and taxing power of the city for the payment of the principal and interest (improvement bonds), or may choose not to pledge the full faith and credit of the city, but rather promise to pay solely out of the proper special fund pledged to the payment of such obligations (revenue bonds). The effect of each such obligation shall be as set forth in Minn. Stats. § 429.091, subd. 2. 
(c)  The financing of the improvement shall be governed further by the provisions of Minn. Stats. § 429.091. 
(Code 1984, § 361:10) 
Secs. 18-124-18-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - UNDERGROUND LIQUID STORAGE TANKS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 14. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building is defined as set forth in section 36-3. 
    Building code means the Minnesota State Building Code adopted pursuant to chapter 8, article II. 
    Cathodic protection means the use of sacrificial anodes on a steel or other metallic tank for the purpose of protecting the host tank from corrosion. 
    Fiberglass includes, in addition to its normal meaning, fiberglass reinforced plastic. 
    Hydrostatic test means a procedure designed to assess the tightness of a tank by means of pressure applied at not less than three pounds per square inch and not more than five pounds per square inch for a period of 30 minutes. 
    Lot is defined as set forth in section 36-3. 
    Pump island area means the raised platform containing flammable liquid dispensing equipment and the immediate environs of any such platform. 
    Resident agent means a person who resides within the Minnesota counties of Hennepin, Ramsey, Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Scott, Washington, Sherburne or Wright and who is presumed to have custody and control of the underground liquid storage tank, and who is responsible for any work done thereon. 
    Underground liquid storage tank, underground storage tank and tank mean a tank constructed of steel or fiberglass located wholly or partially below the ground surface and used or designed for use as storage for liquids, together with all pipes, vents and equipment necessary for its proper operation, but does not include septic tanks. 
    Uniform Fire Code means that certain code and standards adopted pursuant to article III of this chapter. 
(Code 1984, § 380:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-152. - Violations. 
    After March 4, 1987, no underground liquid storage tank shall be installed in violation of this division, nor shall any tank installed after March 4, 1987, be altered, repaired or allowed to remain in the city in violation of this division. It shall be a violation of this division to permit, allow, aid, advise or cause a person to perform an act which is in violation of this division or to fail to perform an act required by this division. 
(Code 1984, § 380:05) 
Sec. 18-153. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to any underground liquid storage tank already installed or in the process of being installed on March 4, 1987, or to tanks installed after such date so as to create on a parcel of property a maximum capacity of 500 gallons or less for the storage of home heating fuel, which fuel is used to provide heat to a dwelling as defined in section 36-3. 
(Code 1984, § 380:10) 
Sec. 18-154. - Permit required for installation, alteration or repair. 
(a)  The installation, alteration, and repair of any underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall require permits issued pursuant to the provisions of the Uniform Fire Code, the building code, and any other applicable code, ordinance, statute or rule. 
(b)  The provisions of chapter 10, article I, and chapter 16, article V, pertaining to permit fees, shall apply to permits issued pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1984, § 380:15) 
Sec. 18-155. - Application for permit; transfer; changes in information. 
(a)  The application for any permit required by this division shall contain as a minimum, and in addition to any further information the city may require, the following: 
(1)  The address and legal description of the property on which the underground liquid storage tank is or will be located. 
(2)  The name and address of each owner of the property. 
(3)  The name and address of each owner of the underground liquid storage tank for which a permit is desired. 
(4)  The name and address of the resident agent who will be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the underground storage tank and who is legally constituted and empowered to receive service of notice of violation of the provisions of city ordinances, to receive orders, to institute remedial action to affect such orders, to accept all service of process pursuant to law and to be available to be contacted by the city in the case of an emergency. The fire marshal shall be notified immediately in writing of any change of required resident agent information. 
(5)  The actual or anticipated contents of the underground liquid storage tank. 
(6)  The purpose for which the permit is requested. 
(7)  The name and address of the applicant and his relationship to the owners of the underground liquid storage tank. 
(8)  The location of any records required to be maintained pursuant to this division. 
(9)  The resin composition used in the manufacture of the fiberglass tank, if fiberglass, together with a listing of compatible product types. 
(b)  If any of the information contained in the application required by subsection (a) of this section shall change before the granting or expiration of the permit, the applicant or permittee, as the case may be, shall notify the city of any such change. 
(c)  No permit issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable to another person, location or underground liquid storage tank. Every permittee shall respond in writing to the fire marshal within 72 hours of his inquiry concerning the ownership or control of any underground liquid storage tank, the land on which it is located, or the activity for which the permit was granted. Such notice shall include the name and address of any and all persons succeeding the permittee to the ownership or control of such properties or activities, if any. 
(Code 1984, § 380:20) 
Sec. 18-156. - Qualifications of permittee. 
(a)  The fire marshal and building official or their designates may investigate applicants and applications for all permits required by this division. 
(b)  The installation, alteration or repair of any underground liquid storage tank shall be performed by a person approved by the fire marshal and building official. Such officials may deny a permit to persons not capable of performing pursuant to ordinance requirements. 
(c)  The person actually performing work pursuant to a permit required by this division shall provide the city a bond in an amount established by the building official, which bond shall guarantee performance of the work for which the permit is granted and that such performance will be done in compliance with city ordinances and all state and federal laws and administrative rules applicable to the work. 
(d)  The fire marshal or building official may require letters of recommendation from manufacturers of underground liquid storage tanks or others who install, alter or repair such tanks if he is not familiar with the applicant for a permit. 
(e)  The fire marshal and building official may require other qualifications they deem appropriate prior to the issuance of any permit. 
(Code 1984, § 380:25) 
Sec. 18-157. - Tank and installation requirements. 
(a)  The installation, use, alteration and repair of all underground liquid storage tanks installed after March 4, 1987, shall comply with all codes, statutes, ordinances and rules that may be applicable thereto, including, but not limited to, article II of chapter 8, the Uniform Fire Code, and Minn. Stats. § 116.49, subd. 2. Wherever there is a conflict of requirements, the more restrictive shall govern so as to further the purpose of this division in protecting the public's health, safety and welfare from the dangers of leakage of tank contents. 
(b)  For any installation, alteration or repair of an underground liquid storage tank, five sets of plans and specifications and pertinent explanatory data, including, but not limited to, health and safety features, shall be submitted to the city for approval by the fire marshal, building official and director of public works relative to design, operation, maintenance, installation, repair, and alteration of any underground liquid storage tank. Such plans shall show, in addition to any other information deemed appropriate by the city, the following in a scale of not smaller than one inch to equal 20 feet: 
(1)  A layout of the entire lot on which the underground liquid storage tank is or is to be located together with adjacent properties, distances from the lot lines to the underground liquid storage tank, the location of other features which may be affected by the underground liquid storage tank, including, but not limited to, other such tanks on the lot, water supply systems, buried sewers and sewage systems, utilities, and other features that could be contaminated within 50 feet of the tank. 
(2)  All dimensions of the underground liquid storage tank. 
(c)  Each underground liquid storage tank, appurtenances, and complementary features shall be constructed in conformity with the approved plans. Deviations from the plans must be approved by the fire marshal, building official and director of public works before construction and after the filing of a supplementary plan covering that portion of the work involved and conforming to the provisions of this division. 
(d)  Location and installation of the underground liquid storage tank and each part thereof shall be such that it will function in a sound manner and will not create a nuisance or endanger the safety of any water supply or utility or create any other health hazard. In determining a suitable location for the underground liquid storage tank, consideration shall be given to the size and shape of the lot, slope of natural and finished grade, soil permeability, depth to groundwater, geology, proximity to existing or future water supplies and other utilities, accessibility for maintenance and possible expansion. 
(e)  Contents of an underground liquid storage tank shall not be discharged to the ground surface, abandoned wells or bodies of surface water, or into any rock formation, or into any well or any other excavation in the ground which does not comply with all the requirements of this division. 
(f)  Underground liquid storage tanks shall not be installed in any area deemed by the city to pose a threat to the public's health, safety or welfare, such as low, swampy areas, or areas which may be subject to flooding or other conditions, soil or otherwise, which could create the potential for violation of the conditions of this division, without the installer providing proof acceptable to the city that any such condition present or likely to be present will not pose such a threat or will be neutralized so as to substantially eliminate such a threat. 
(g)  The bottom of the trench in which an underground liquid storage tank is located shall be not less than four feet above the highest known or calculated water table. 
(h)  All underground liquid storage tanks constructed of steel shall comply with the requirements of Standard No. STI-P3 of the Steel Tank Institute or its equivalent approved by the city council, one copy of which shall be maintained. All underground liquid storage tanks constructed of fiberglass shall comply with specifications approved by the fire marshal, building official and director of public works, one copy of which specifications shall be maintained. 
(i)  Underground liquid storage tanks shall be installed pursuant to the National Fire Protection Association Code, the Minnesota State Fire Code, Standard No. STI-P3 of the Steel Tank Institute or its equivalent approved by the city council (for steel tanks), specifications approved for fiberglass tanks by the fire marshal, building official and director of public works, one copy of which shall be maintained, and such other requirements as requirements as the city may deem appropriate. 
(j)  Each underground liquid storage tank shall have a containment system consisting of a double-wall fiberglass or STI-P3 (type 2) steel tank, or a single-wall STI-P3 steel tank or fiberglass tank with a liner constructed to conform to subsections (1), (2), and (3) of this subsection. Double-wall tanks shall have a double-wall distribution system known as enviroflex or an equivalent system approved pursuant to section 18-163, and shall also have a leak detection system certified by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for the interstitial space between tank walls. Both the double-wall and single-wall tanks shall be constructed to conform to subsections (4), (5), (6), and (7) of this subsection. 
(1)  The tank, along with all the distribution and venting piping, shall be placed on top of a minimum of 30 mils of fuel-resistant polyethylene or its equivalent. If the underlying soil has a permeability greater than 1 × 10 -7 centimeters per second, then a clay layer being a minimum of two feet in depth must be placed underneath the polyethylene liner. If the distribution and venting system is constructed with the enviroflex system, the liner is not required below the piping and venting. 
(2)  The liner shall be sloped such that it drains to one end of the containment system, where a monitoring well shall be located. Another well shall be located opposite this well to be used as a flushing and testing well. 
(3)  The observation well should be constructed of eight-inch-diameter (minimum) PVC or ductile iron pipe. At the bottom of the observation well a tee shall be placed with lateral perforated pipe extended from the tee to a length equal to the trench width minus two feet. The perforated pipe shall be wrapped with a fuel-resistant filter fabric. 
(4)  All tanks shall be anchored by using straps and deadmen, or by using an anchor system which is an equal approved by the director of public works. If fiberglass tanks are to be installed, a certification from a licensed mechanical or structural engineer shall be submitted certifying that the fiberglass tank can withstand the stress and/or strain caused by the buoyancy forces caused by the containment system filling with water and the straps holding the tank down. 
(5)  All tanks shall be backfilled with sand or pea gravel, dependent upon the tank manufacturer's requirements. 
(6)  All fiberglass tanks shall have a deflector plate installed within the tank beneath any fill lines, vent lines, and access manholes, or any other access area to the tank. 
(7)  Fiberglass tanks shall only be used for the storage of liquids that will not adversely affect the integrity of the tank by chemically breaking down the fiberglass material. 
(k)  Overfill protection systems shall be provided, including, but not limited to, the placement of a concrete or equivalent impervious surface around the pump island area. 
(l)  All piping and venting capable of being corroded and connected to and associated with an underground storage tank shall be protected from corrosion in the same manner, as nearly as possible, as the tank itself. 
(1)  All such piping and venting shall be, as a minimum, coated, wrapped, and furnished with sufficient anodes to provide cathodic protection, approved by the director of public works. 
(2)  For single-wall storage tanks with a liner, all piping and venting which is not approved double-walled material as described in subsection (j) of this section shall be contained within trenches designed to prevent movement of spills of tank contents into the surrounding groundwater. Underneath the product line, the trenches shall be lined with the same polyethylene sheeting as the tank liner or such other lining as the director of public works may require. The polyethylene sheeting shall be sloped to drain and be extended into the tank liner. 
(3)  All such piping and venting shall be isolated from the tank so as to prevent the corrosion of one from affecting the other. 
(m)  No underground storage tank shall be located within ten feet of any lot line or building. 
(Code 1984, § 380:30) 
Sec. 18-158. - Inspections generally. 
(a)  The installation, use, repair and alteration of any underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall be inspected by a designated city official pursuant to such schedules as such official deems appropriate or as designated in the codes, statutes, ordinances and rules governing such activity. 
(b)  No permit required by this division shall be issued unless the permittee agrees in an application to permit inspections. 
(c)  If any permittee refuses or directs refusal of free access and entry to the premises where an underground liquid storage tank is located, the permit for the activity to be inspected shall be subject to immediate revocation for such refusal and the city may seek a court order authorizing inspection. In addition, for violation of this section, the permittee shall be subject to the misdemeanor criminal penalties referred to in section 1-13. 
(d)  The city shall have authority to inspect activities authorized by the permit at any reasonable time during the construction of an underground liquid storage tank and thereafter to determine whether or not the provisions of this division are being complied with. 
(Code 1984, § 380:35) 
Sec. 18-159. - Final inspection and approval. 
(a)  An underground liquid storage tank may be filled upon installation, but no contents shall be drained or dispensed therefrom until after its final inspection and approval by the fire marshal. The permittee shall request the final inspection and approval. Such approval shall be withheld until the following as a minimum shall have been accomplished: 
(1)  After completion of the installation, repair or alteration of the underground liquid storage tank, a trained corrosion inspector approved by the fire marshal shall energize the system and adjust it for optimum operation so as to ensure its proper installation and operation. A sufficient number of readings, as determined by the fire marshal, shall be obtained to ensure that all metal surfaces are receiving adequate cathodic protection. 
(2)  Upon completion of all necessary adjustments, the corrosion inspector shall conduct a final test and inspection of the cathodic protection system, which procedure shall be conducted no sooner than 28 days after installation of the anode system and immediately after energizing of the system. 
(3)  The corrosion inspector shall file with the fire marshal a report of his final testing, which report shall include, as a minimum, the following: 
a.  Structure to soil protection measures (current applied). 
b.  Anode current-output to structure. 
c.  Soil resistivity of the lot. 
d.  Additional comments and suggestions by the inspector. 
e.  Such other information as the fire marshal may require. 
(4)  Thereafter, the cathodic protection system shall be inspected and tested by a corrosion inspector approved by the fire marshal as frequently as the hydrostatic testing procedure required pursuant to section 18-160. 
(Code 1984, § 380:40) 
Sec. 18-160. - Detection of leaks. 
(a)  Reconciliation of contents. 
(1)  The owner of each underground liquid storage tank installed after March 4, 1987, shall cause the contents of each tank to be reconciled at least monthly. 
(2)  The owner shall keep records of such reconciliations for inspection by the fire marshal. Any such record more than three years of age may be discarded. 
(3)  The records shall be maintained within the area in which the resident agent must reside and shall be available for inspection by the city's authorized representative and be available at other reasonable times for his inspection. 
(b)  Monitoring of sump area. 
(1)  The sloped and angled liner required at the base of the trench containing an underground liquid storage tank shall lead to a sump area to collect liquid, which area shall be accessible by a monitoring well through which the liquid in the sump area can be checked. 
(2)  The owner of each underground storage tank shall cause the sump area to be maintained in such condition as is necessary to ensure it will correctly function. 
(3)  The owner of each underground storage tank shall cause the sump area to be checked for water and contents of the underground liquid storage tank either monthly or each time the tank receives further contents, whichever event occurs first. 
(4)  The owner shall maintain a record of tests conducted of the sump area, which record shall be maintained for inspection pursuant to the same conditions as the required monthly reconciliations. 
(5)  At lease once each month, and only after the testing procedures set forth in subsection (b)(3) of this section, the owner shall cause the sump area to be pumped free of water. 
(6)  The fire marshal shall check the sump area of each underground liquid storage tank at least once each year using the same method as that used by the owner in the compilation of his required records. 
(c)  Hydrostatic tests. 
(1)  At least once every five years, as measured from the date of the final installation, inspection and approval of a newly installed underground liquid storage tank, the owner of each such tank shall cause the tank to be subjected to a hydrostatic test or other similar testing procedure approved by the fire marshal and designed to assess the tightness of the tank. The test shall be performed annually beginning 20 years after the final installation inspection and approval of a newly installed underground liquid storage tank. 
(2)  The test must be performed by a person who demonstrates to the satisfaction of the fire marshal knowledge in the testing of liquid storage tanks and equipment. 
(3)  The owner shall cause the results of the test to be filed with the city within ten days of the test. 
(d)  Report of loss of fuel. Any apparent loss of liquid fuel shall be immediately reported to the fire marshal and any other appropriate authority by the tank owner or his resident agent. A written notice of such loss shall be delivered to the fire marshal within three days of such report. 
(Code 1984, § 380:45) 
Sec. 18-161. - General operational requirements. 
(a)  Information to be provided to city. The information required pursuant to section 18-155(a) shall be made available to the city by the owner of an underground liquid storage tank or the property in which it exists when requested by the city. The owner of the tank or the property on which it is located shall notify the city of any change in information supplied pursuant to such a request. 
(b)  Nuisance or dangerous conditions. 
(1)  Prohibited conditions. No underground liquid storage tank installed after March 4, 1987, shall be used, kept, maintained, or operated if such use, keeping or maintaining or operation shall be the occasion of any nuisance or shall be dangerous to life or detrimental to health. 
(2)  Right of entry. The owner of any underground liquid storage tank and the owner of the property on which it is located shall give, and the holder of any permit granted in connection with any such tank is deemed to have given, to any representative of the city permission to: 
a.  Enter upon such property at all reasonable times, and inspect any such property and tank and records required to be kept in conjunction therewith to ascertain whether there has been compliance with this division. 
b.  Enter upon such property for the purpose of correcting violations and conditions described in subsections (b)(3) and (4) of this section and remaining unabated. 
(3)  Immediate abatement. If there is found to be any condition or violation of this division that poses an imminent danger of loss of life or property or immediately jeopardizes the health, safety or welfare of the general public, the city may immediately enter upon the property for the purpose of abating the violation or condition pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c)(3) of this section after attempting such notice as is reasonably calculated to reach the resident agent or an owner of the tank or property. 
(4)  Abatement after notice. 
a.  If there is found to be any condition or violation of this division under any other circumstances, the city shall specify by written notice to the resident agent or an owner of the tank or property on which it is located corrections necessary to abate the violation or condition. 
b.  The notified party shall cause the abatement to be completed within ten days of the delivery or mailing of such notice. 
c.  If the abatement is not completed within the ten-day period, the city may proceed to abate the nuisance pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c)(3) of this section. 
(c)  Abandoned tanks. 
(1)  Any underground liquid storage tank which remains empty or from which none of its contents are withdrawn for the purpose for which the contents are stored, or which remains unrepaired or unrestored for eight successive months, commencing after March 4, 1987, shall be deemed abandoned unless a variance is granted by the council pursuant to section 18-162. 
(2)  The owner of an abandoned underground liquid storage tank or the property on which it is located shall cause the portions of the underground liquid storage tank above ground to be dismantled and shall further cause the tank to be completely drained and either filled with sand or removed and the resulting trench filled with sand, which procedures shall be witnessed by the fire marshal or his designee. 
(3)  Failure of the property owner to comply with the provisions of subsection (c)(2) of this section shall result in removal of the nuisance pursuant to such procedures as the city deems appropriate, including, but not limited to, the procedures set forth in chapter 14, article II, division 3, the Uniform Building Code and the Uniform Fire Code. Costs of such efforts shall be assessed against the property from which the nuisance is removed pursuant to city ordinance. 
(d)  Declaration of nuisance. Any abandoned, damaged, defective, destroyed, unrepaired or unrestored underground liquid storage tank is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(e)  Payment of costs of inspections and tests. The cost of any inspection or testing procedure prescribed by this division shall be the responsibility of the owners of the underground liquid storage tank and the property on which it is located, and their agents. 
(Code 1984, § 380:50) 
Sec. 18-162. - Variances. 
    Variances from the standards of this division and variances required as the result of practical difficulties in strictly carrying out the provisions of this division may be granted pursuant to the provisions of section 18-189. However, as stated therein, no variance will be granted that will tend to subject the public's health, safety or welfare to the dangers of leakage of tank contents. 
(Code 1984, § 380:55) 
Sec. 18-163. - Alternate materials or methods. 
(a)  The provisions of this division represent minimum standards deemed necessary for the protection of the public's health, safety and welfare from the dangers of leakage of tank contents. Alternate materials or methods may be approved unanimously by the building official, fire marshal, and director of public works provided they find that the proposed design, use or operation satisfactorily complies with the intent of this division and that the material, method of work performed, or operation is, for the purpose intended, at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this division in quality, effectiveness, durability, suitability, fire resistance, safety and sanitation. 
(b)  Such officials shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claims that may be made regarding any such alternate material or method, and any of such officials may require tests as proof of compliance with the intent of this division, such tests to be made by an approved agency at the expense of the person requesting approval of the alternate material or method of construction. 
(c)  The details of any action granting approval of an alternate shall be recorded and entered in the files of the fire chief, building official, and director of public works. 
(Code 1984, § 380:60) 
Sec. 18-164. - State fire code to control. 
    The state fire code adopted by reference in this chapter shall supersede the provisions of this article unless the provisions of this article are more stringent or restrictive. 
Secs. 18-165-18-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TANKS INSTALLED ON OR BEFORE MARCH 4, 1987 

Sec. 18-181. - Definitions. 
    Terms defined in division 1 of this article shall have the same meanings when used in this division. The terms "owner" and "operator," when used with regard to tanks, shall have the meanings set forth in Minn. Stats. § 115C.02. 
(Code 1984, § 485:00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-182. - Violations. 
(a)  After June 29, 1988, no person shall own, control, use or allow the use of an underground liquid storage tank installed on or before March 4, 1987, or allow such a tank to remain on one's property or on property under one's control, in violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Each day that a violation of this division continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  An election by the city to criminally prosecute for violation of this division shall not prevent the city from proceeding with any other remedy available to the city for such a violation, and vice versa, and the city may pursue any and all available remedies simultaneously and while any other person, agency, or governmental subdivision is pursuing any remedy available as a result of the activity or violation. 
(Code 1984, § 485:05) 
Sec. 18-183. - Exceptions. 
    The terms of this division shall not apply to tanks installed on or before March 4, 1987, so as to create on a parcel of property a maximum capacity of 500 gallons or less for the storage of heating fuel, which fuel is used to provide heat to a structure on the parcel, subject to the following: The terms of sections 18-184(a)(1) through (7), (9) and (10), 18-185, 18-187(b), and 18-188 to 18-190 shall apply to all such tanks regardless of size or contents. 
(Code 1984, § 485:10) 
Sec. 18-184. - Registration. 
(a)  Within six months after June 29, 1988, or within 30 days after installation, whichever is later, the owner of each tank installed on or before March 4, 1987, and located in the city, and the owner of each parcel of property in the city on which such a tank is located, shall notify the city of the following information and any further information the city may require: 
(1)  The address and legal description of the property on which the underground liquid storage tank is located. 
(2)  The name and address of each owner of such property. 
(3)  The name and address of each owner of each underground liquid storage tank. 
(4)  The name and address of the resident agent who will be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of each underground storage tank and who is legally constituted and empowered to receive service of notice of violation of the provisions of city ordinances, to receive orders, to institute remedial action to affect such orders, to accept all service of process pursuant to law and to be available to be contacted by the city in the case of an emergency. The fire marshal shall be notified immediately in writing of any change of required resident agent information. 
(5)  The actual or anticipated contents of each underground liquid storage tank and the material of which each tank is constructed. 
(6)  The name and address of the registrant and his relationship to all owners of each underground liquid storage tank. 
(7)  The location of any records required to be maintained pursuant to this division. 
(8)  The resin composition used in the manufacture of the fiberglass tank, if fiberglass, together with a listing of compatible product types. For each tank made of steel, the registrant shall provide the design standards effective at the time the tank was installed. 
(9)  A map or drawing of the property on which each tank is located identifying the dimensions of each tank, the location of each tank on the property, and the capacity of each tank. 
(10)  The date of the installation of each underground liquid storage tank. 
(b)  A copy of current information supplied to the state pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 116.48 may be substituted for the registration required in subsection (a) of this section, although the city may require additional information. If any of the information contained in the registration required by subsection (a) of this section shall change, the registrant, or the registrant's successor if the registrant is no longer a party obligated to register pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, shall immediately notify the city of any such change. 
(c)  Within 72 hours of the fire marshal's inquiry concerning the ownership or control of any such underground liquid storage tank and the land on which it is located, every person contacted shall respond in writing to the fire marshal. Such response shall include the name and address of any and all persons succeeding the registrant to the ownership or control of such properties or activities. 
(Code 1984, § 485:15) 
Sec. 18-185. - Conformance deadlines. 
(a)  Except as otherwise required in subsection (b) of this section, within 20 years from the date of installation or within ten years of June 29, 1988, whichever is later, all tanks installed on or before March 4, 1987 in the city must meet the same requirements for corrosion protection and leak detection that are specified for tanks governed by division 1 of this article, or employ methods or technologies deemed by the city to be as good as or better than such requirements, and must be equipped with properly installed and functioning devices that prevent spills and overfills. 
(b)  If the date of installation of any such tank is not known to the city's satisfaction, the deadline for meeting the requirements of subsection (a) of this section shall be five years from June 29, 1988. 
(c)  As an alternative to the requirements set forth in subsection (a) of this section, a tank shall, within the deadlines established in this section, be equipped with a functioning monitoring system approved by the fire marshal, which monitoring system meets or exceeds the standards of division 1 of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 485:20) 
Sec. 18-186. - Inspections. 
    The use, repair and alteration of any underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall be inspected by a designated city official pursuant to such inspection schedules as such official deems appropriate or as designated in the codes, statutes, ordinances and rules governing such activity. 
(Code 1984, § 485:25) 
Sec. 18-187. - Detection of leaks. 
(a)  Reconciliation of contents. 
(1)  The owner or operator of each underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall cause the contents of each tank to be reconciled at least monthly. 
(2)  Such person shall keep records of the reconciliations for inspection and copying by the fire marshal. Any such record more than three years of age may be discarded. 
(3)  The records shall be maintained on forms approved by the city within the area in which a resident agent must reside and shall be available at all reasonable times for inspection and copying by the fire marshal. 
(4)  All records created or maintained by the city pursuant to this section or any other provision of this division shall be public data unless the subject of the data provides proof that its data is classified as private or non-public pursuant to Minn. Stats. ch. 13. Such data, however, may be disclosed when relevant to enforce or cure a violation of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Loss of contents. 
(1)  Any apparent loss of any tank contents registered or required to be registered with the city pursuant to section 18-184 shall be immediately reported to the fire marshal and any other authority as required by law, the contents immediately recovered, if possible, and the cause immediately corrected, and all these actions shall be done by or at the direction of the tank owner or operator or owner of land on which the tank is located. 
(2)  A written notice of such loss shall be delivered to the fire marshal within three days of such report. 
(3)  An apparent loss of contents shall mean the unaccounted absence of five percent of the tank's contents or 500 gallons, whichever is less, at the end of any 30-day period, or at any time. 
(c)  Testing of tank. 
(1)  At least once every five years, the owner or operator of each tank installed on or before March 4, 1987, or the owner of land on which such a tank is located, shall cause the tank to be subjected to a testing procedure approved by the city and designed to assess the tightness of the tank. One such test shall be performed on each tank more than five years old, as measured from the date of installation, at some time during the months of April, May or June, 1989. Beginning in April 1994 and every five years thereafter, all tanks installed on or before March 4, 1987, shall be so tested once during the month of April, May or June. Any such tank for which the installation date cannot be shown to the satisfaction of the city shall be presumed to be more than five years old in April 1989. 
(2)  Such owner or operator shall cause the results of every such test to be filed with the city within 20 days of the test. The fire marshal may, for good cause shown, extend the deadline up to an additional 20 days total.
