(3)  If it can be shown to the fire marshal's satisfaction that such a test was completed after March 4, 1987, the fire marshal may waive the testing required in 1989. 
(4)  Whenever performed, every such test must be performed by a person who demonstrates to the satisfaction of the fire marshal knowledge in the testing of liquid storage tanks and equipment. 
(Code 1984, § 485:30) 
Sec. 18-188. - General operational requirements. 
(a)  Information to be provided to city. Any information required pursuant to this division shall be made available to the city by the registrant, tank owner or operator, or landowner as set forth in this division or when requested by the city. Such person shall notify the city of any change in information supplied pursuant to such a request. 
(b)  Nuisance or dangerous conditions. 
(1)  Prohibited conditions. No underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall be used, kept, maintained, or operated if such use, keeping or maintaining or operation shall be the occasion of any nuisance or shall be dangerous or detrimental to life or health. 
(2)  Right of entry. Every tank owner or operator or landowner shall give, and is deemed to have given, to any representative of the city, permission to: 
a.  Enter upon property at all reasonable times and inspect any such property and/or tank and records required to be kept in conjunction therewith, to ascertain whether there has been compliance with this division. 
b.  Enter upon property for the purpose of correcting violations and conditions described in subsections (b)(3) and (4) of this section and remaining unabated. 
(3)  Immediate abatement. If there is found to be any nuisance, condition or violation of this division that the city determines to pose an imminent danger of loss of life or property or immediately jeopardizes the health, safety or welfare of the general public, the city may immediately enter upon the property for the purpose of abating the violation or condition pursuant to the provisions of subsections (c)(3) of this section after attempting such notice as is reasonably calculated to reach one of the persons referred to in subsection (a) of this section. 
(4)  Abatement after notice. 
a.  If the city finds there to be any nuisance, condition or violation of this division under any other circumstances, the city shall specify by written notice to one of the persons referred to in subsection (a) of this section the corrections necessary to abate the nuisance, violation or condition. 
b.  The notified party shall cause the abatement to be completed within ten days of the delivery or mailing of such notice. 
c.  If the abatement is not completed within the ten-day period, the city may proceed to abate the nuisance pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c)(3) of this section. 
(c)  Abandoned tanks. 
(1)  Any underground liquid storage tank installed on or before March 4, 1987, which, for six successive months commencing after June 29, 1988, remains empty, or for which inventory and testing records are not prepared, maintained, or available, or from which none of its contents are withdrawn for the purpose for which the contents are stored, or which remains unrepaired or unrestored, shall be deemed abandoned unless the owner or operator of the tank or owner of the property on which the tank is located demonstrates otherwise to the council's satisfaction, or unless the tank is used to store fuel for use only when a usual source of fuel is interrupted and it can be shown that records required by this division are prepared, maintained and available for the tank. 
(2)  Any such owner or operator of an abandoned underground liquid storage tank shall cause the portions of the underground liquid storage tank above ground to be dismantled and shall further cause the tank to be completely drained and either filled with material approved by the state fire marshal or removed and the resulting trench filled with sand, which procedures shall be witnessed by the city fire marshal or his designee. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the provisions of subsection (c)(1) of this section shall result in removal of the nuisance pursuant to such procedures as the city deems appropriate, including, but not limited to, the procedures set forth in chapter 14, article II, division 3, the Uniform Building Code and the Uniform Fire Code. Costs of such efforts shall be assessed against the property from which the nuisance is removed pursuant to city ordinance. 
(d)  Declaration of nuisance. Any abandoned, damaged, defective, leaking, destroyed, unrepaired or unrestored underground liquid storage tank installed on or before March 4, 1987, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(e)  Payment of costs of inspections, tests and abatement. The cost of any inspection, testing, abatement or correction procedures prescribed by this division shall be the responsibility of the owner and operator of the underground liquid storage tank and the property on which it is located, and their agents. 
(Code 1984, § 485:35) 
Sec. 18-189. - Variances. 
    Variances from the standards of this division and variances required as the result of practical difficulty in strictly carrying out the provisions of this division may be granted as follows: 
(1)  General provisions and standards. 
a.  The city council shall act as the board of adjustment and appeals. 
b.  In considering all requests for a variance or appeal, and in taking subsequent action, the city staff and the city council serving as the board of adjustment and appeals shall make findings of fact that the proposed action will not: 
1.  Increase the danger of fire or endanger the public safety. 
2.  Unreasonably diminish or impair established property values within the neighborhood. 
3.  Tend to subject the public's health, safety or welfare to the dangers of leakage of tank contents. 
4.  In any way be contrary to the intent of this division. 
c.  The city council serving as the board of adjustment and appeals shall, after receiving the written reports and recommendations of the city staff, make findings of fact and decide upon requests for a variance by approving or denying the variance, in whole or in part, where it is alleged by the applicant that a unique hardship exists in the application of this division. 
1.  For purposes of this section, the term "unique hardship" shall mean a hardship that would make the strict application of the terms of this division result in exceptional difficulties or which creates undue hardship upon the applicant that another person in the same circumstances would not have. 
2.  Should the city council find that the conditions outlined in this subsection apply, the council may grant a variance from the strict application of this division so as to relieve such difficulties or hardships to the degree considered reasonable, provided such relief may be granted without impairing the intent of this division. 
3.  The city staff shall have the power to advise and recommend such conditions related to the variance as it may deem advisable in the interest of the intent and purpose of this division. 
4.  The city council serving as the board of adjustment and appeals shall, after receiving the written report and recommendation of the city staff, make a finding of fact and make a decision on appeals where it is alleged by the appellant that error has occurred in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the city in the enforcement of this division. However, the appeal shall be filed not later than 90 days after the applicant has received a written notice from the city concerning such enforcement or the appeal shall be considered void. 
(2)  Procedures. 
a.  Requests for a variance or appeal shall be filed with the city clerk on an official application form. 
1.  Such application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as established by the city council in section 16-371. 
2.  Such application shall also be accompanied by ten copies of detailed written and graphic materials necessary for the explanation of the request, and a list obtained from and certified by the county, of property owners located within 350 feet of the boundary of the subject property. 
3.  The request shall be considered as being officially submitted when all the information requirements are complied with. 
b.  Upon receipt of the complete application, a public hearing shall be set for the next regular meeting of the city council occurring after ten days from the date of submission and after notice as described in this subsection is given. Notice of the hearing shall consist of a legal property description, a description of the request and a map detailing the property location, and be published in the official newspaper at least ten days prior to the hearing, and written notification of the hearing shall be mailed at least ten days prior to all owners of land within 350 feet of the boundary of the property in question. 
c.  Failure of a property owner to receive the notice shall not invalidate any such proceedings as set forth within this division. 
d.  After the public hearing has been set, the city administrator shall instruct the appropriate staff persons to prepare technical reports where appropriate, and provide general assistance in preparing a recommendation on the action to the city council. 
e.  City staff shall have the authority to request additional information from the applicant or to retain expert testimony with the consent and at the expense of the applicant, such information to be declared necessary to establish performance conditions in relation to all pertinent sections of this division. 
f.  The applicant or a representative thereof shall appear before the city council in order to answer questions concerning the proposed variance request. 
g.  The city council serving as the board of adjustment and appeals shall make findings of fact and shall decide whether to approve or deny a request for a variance or an appeal within 30 days after the public hearing on the request. 
h.  A variance of this division or grant of an appeal shall be by four-fifths vote of the full city council serving as the board of adjustment and appeals. 
i.  The originator of the variance request or appeal shall be notified in writing of the city council's decision. 
(3)  Lapse of variance. 
a.  Whenever, within one year after being granted, a variance shall not have been completed or utilized, then such variance shall become null and void unless a petition for extension of time in which to complete or to utilize the variance has been granted by the city council. 
b.  Such extension shall be requested in writing and filed with the city clerk at least 30 days before the expiration of the original variance. 
c.  There shall be no charge for the filing of such petition. 
d.  The request for extension shall state facts showing a good faith attempt to complete or utilize the variance. 
e.  Such petition shall be presented to the city staff for a recommendation and to the city council for a decision. 
(4)  Performance bond. 
a.  Upon approval of a variance or appeal, the city may require a surety bond, cash escrow, certificate of deposit, securities or cash deposit in an amount it deems to be appropriate to guarantee conformance and compliance with the conditions of the variance or appeal and the ordinances of the city. The security shall be noncancellable. 
b.  The city shall hold the security until compliance with the variance or appeal and ordinances of the city. 
c.  Failure to comply with the conditions of the variance or appeal and the ordinances of the city shall result in forfeiture of the security. 
(Code 1984, § 485:40) 
Sec. 18-190. - Repairs. 
    Repairs of tanks governed by this division shall be governed by the following. For purposes of this division, the terms "alteration" and "repair" shall mean any activity or thing that could or would tend to cause the uncontrolled release of contents of a tank or failure of any of its leak prevention or containment systems, whether temporarily or permanently, and any activity or thing done to enhance or ensure the tightness of the tank and containment of leaks. The terms "alteration" and "repair" shall not apply to ordinary maintenance to pipes, vents and equipment necessary for the proper operation of a tank and located above the ground surface, so long as the procedure could not or will not tend to cause the uncontrolled release of contents of the tank or failure of any of its leak prevention or containment systems, whether temporarily or permanently. 
(1)  Permits. 
a.  The alteration or repair of any underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall require permits issued pursuant to the provisions of the Uniform Fire Code, the building code, and any other applicable code, ordinance, statute or rule. 
b.  The provisions of chapter 10, article I, and chapter 16, article V, pertaining to permit fees, shall apply to permits issued pursuant to this section. 
c.  The application for any permit required by this division shall contain as a minimum any required information not already provided pursuant to section 18-184. 
d.  If any of the information contained in the application required by subsection (1) of this section shall change before the granting or expiration of the permit, the applicant or permittee, as the case may be, shall notify the city of any such change. 
e.  No permit issued pursuant to this section shall be transferable to another person, location or underground liquid storage tank. Every permittee shall respond in writing to the fire marshal within 72 hours of his inquiry concerning the ownership or control of any underground liquid storage tank, the land on which it is located, or the activity for which the permit was granted. Such notice shall include the name and address of any and all persons succeeding the permittee to the ownership or control of such properties or activities, if any. 
(2)  Qualifications of permittees. 
a.  The fire marshal and building official or their designates may investigate applicants and applications for all repair permits. 
b.  The alteration or repair of any underground liquid storage tank shall be performed by a person approved by the fire marshal and building official. Such officials may deny a permit to persons not capable of performing pursuant to ordinance requirements. 
c.  The person actually performing work pursuant to a permit required by this section shall provide the city a bond in an amount established by the building official, which bond shall guarantee performance of the work for which the permit is granted and that the performance will be done in compliance with city ordinances and all state and federal laws and administrative rules applicable to the work. 
d.  The fire marshal and building official may require letters of recommendation from manufacturers of underground liquid storage tanks or others who install, alter or repair such tanks if the fire marshal or building official is not familiar with the applicant for a permit. 
e.  The fire marshal and building official may require other qualifications they deem appropriate prior to the issuance of any permit. 
(3)  Requirements. 
a.  The alteration or repair of all underground liquid storage tanks shall comply with all codes, statutes, ordinances and rules that may be applicable thereto including, but not limited to, article II of chapter 8, the Uniform Fire Code, and Minn. Stats. § 116.49, subd. 2. Wherever there is a conflict of requirements, the more restrictive shall govern so as to further the purpose of this division in protecting the public's health, safety and welfare from the dangers of leakage of tank contents. 
b.  For any alteration or repair of an underground liquid storage tank, five sets of plans and specifications and pertinent explanatory data, including, but not limited to, health and safety features, shall be submitted to the city for approval by the fire marshal, building official and director of public works relative to design, operation, maintenance, repair, and alteration of any underground liquid storage tank. Such plans shall show, in addition to any other information deemed appropriate by the city, the following in a scale of not smaller than one inch equals 20 feet (unless a different scale is approved by the fire marshal, building official, and director of public works under the particular circumstances of the case): 
1.  A layout of the property on which the tank is located showing the location of each tank requiring a permit for alteration or repair, so as to assist the city in determining the potential hazards involved in the proposed work. If the information is not already available to the city, the fire marshal, building official, or director of public works may also require a layout of the entire lot on which the underground liquid storage tank is located together with adjacent properties, distances from the lot lines to the underground liquid storage tank, and the location of other features which may be affected by the underground liquid storage tank, including, but not limited to, features that could be contaminated within 50 feet of the tank, other tanks on the lot, utilities, water supply systems, and buried sewers and sewage systems. 
2.  All dimensions of the underground liquid storage tank. 
c.  Alterations or repairs shall be conducted in conformity with the approved plans. Deviations from the plans must be approved by the fire marshal, building official and director of public works before being done and after the filing of a supplementary plan covering that portion of the work involved and conforming to the provisions of this division. 
d.  Alterations or repairs shall be such that the tanks will function in a sound manner and will not create a nuisance or endanger the safety of any water supply or utility or create any other health hazard. Consideration shall be given to the size and shape of the lot, slope of natural and finished grade, soil permeability, depth to groundwater, geology, proximity to existing or future water supplies and other utilities, accessibility for maintenance and possible expansion. 
e.  Contents of an underground liquid storage tank shall not be discharged to the ground surface, abandoned wells or bodies of surface water, or into any rock formation, or into any well or any other excavation in the ground which does not comply with all the requirements of division 1 of this article. 
(4)  Inspections. 
a.  The repair and alteration of any underground liquid storage tank governed by this division shall be inspected by a designated city official pursuant to such inspection schedules as such official deems appropriate or as designated in the codes, statutes, ordinances and rules governing such activity. No permit required by this section shall be issued unless the permittee agrees in an application to permit inspections. 
b.  If any permittee refuses or directs refusal of free access and entry to the premises where an underground liquid storage tank is located, the permit for the activity to be inspected shall be subject to immediate revocation for such refusal and the city may seek a court order authorizing inspection. In addition, for violation of this section, the permittee shall be subject to the misdemeanor criminal penalties referred to in section 1-13. 
c.  The city shall have authority to inspect activities authorized by the permit at any reasonable time during the repair or alteration of an underground liquid storage tank and thereafter to determine whether or not the provisions of this division are being complied with. 
(5)  Approvals. No contents shall be drained or dispensed from a repaired or altered tank until after its final inspection and approval by the fire marshal. The permittee shall request such final inspection and approval. Such approval shall be withheld until the following as a minimum shall have been accomplished: 
a.  If determined by the fire marshal to be necessary by the nature of the repair or alteration, he may, after completion of the repair or alteration of the tank, require a trained corrosion inspector approved by the fire marshal to energize the system and adjust it for optimum operation so as to ensure its proper operation. A sufficient number of readings, as determined by the fire marshal, shall be obtained to ensure that all metal surfaces are receiving adequate cathodic protection. 
b.  If determined by the fire marshal to be necessary by the nature of the repair or alteration, he may, upon completion of all necessary adjustments, require the corrosion inspector to conduct a final test and inspection of the cathodic protection system, which procedure shall be conducted no sooner than 28 days after installation of the anode system and immediately after energizing of the system. 
c.  The corrosion inspector shall file with the fire marshal a report of his final testing, which report shall include, as a minimum, the following: 
1.  Structure to soil protection measures (current applied). 
2.  Anode current-output to structure. 
3.  Soil resistivity of the lot. 
4.  Additional comments and suggestions by the inspector. 
5.  Such other information as the fire marshal may require. 
d.  Thereafter, the cathodic protection system shall be inspected and tested by a corrosion inspector approved by the fire marshal as frequently as the tightness testing procedure required pursuant to section 18-187. 
(Code 1984, § 485:45) 
Sec. 18-191. - Alternate materials or methods. 
(a)  The provisions of this division represent minimum standards deemed necessary for the protection of the public's health, safety and welfare from the dangers of leakage of tank contents. Alternate materials or methods may be approved unanimously by the building official, fire marshal, and director of public works provided they find that the proposed design, use or operation satisfactorily complies with the intent of this division and that the material, method of work performed, or operation is, for the purpose intended, at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this division in quality, effectiveness, durability, suitability, fire resistance, safety and sanitation. 
(b)  Such officials shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claims that may be made regarding any such alternate material or method, and any of such officials may require tests as proof of compliance with the intent of this division, such tests to be made by an approved agency at the expense of the person requesting approval of the alternate material or method of construction. 
(c)  The details of any action granting approval of an alternate shall be recorded and entered in the files of the fire chief, building official, and director of public works. 
(Code 1984, § 485:50) 
Secs. 18-192-18-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CLEANUP OF CLANDESTINE DRUG LAB SITES AND CHEMICAL DUMP SITES 

Sec. 18-200. - General provisions. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The purpose of this article is to reduce public exposure to health risks where law enforcement officers have determined that hazardous chemicals or residue from a suspected clandestine drug lab site or associated dump site may exist. Professional reports, based on assessments, testing and investigations, show that chemicals used in the production of illicit drugs can condense, penetrate, and contaminate surfaces, furnishings, and equipment of surrounding structures. The city council finds that such sites, and the personal property within such sites, may contain suspected chemicals and residues that place people, particularly children or adults of child bearing age, at risk when exposed through inhabiting or visiting the site or using or being exposed to contaminated personal property. 
(b)  Interpretation and application. In the interpretation and application of this article, the provisions herein shall be construed to protect the public health, safety and welfare. Where the conditions imposed by any provision of this article are either more or less restrictive to the public than comparable provisions imposed by any other law, ordinance, statute, or regulation of any kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher standards or requirements on the public shall prevail. Should any court of competent jurisdiction declare any section or subpart of this article to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the article as a whole or any part thereof, other than the provision declared invalid. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-201. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. Each act of violation and every day upon which a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. In addition to the above, the city may seek civil penalties and enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-202. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms or words shall be interpreted as follows: 
    Chemical dump site shall mean any place or area where chemicals or other waste materials used in a clandestine drug lab operation have been located. 
    Child shall mean any person less than 18 years of age. 
    City shall mean the City of Maple Grove. 
    Clandestine drub lab operation shall mean the unlawful manufacture or attempt to manufacture a controlled substance. 
    Clandestine drug lab site shall mean any place or area where law enforcement has determined that conditions associated with an unlawful clandestine drug lab operation exist. A clandestine drug lab site may include dwellings, accessory buildings, structures or units, a chemical dump site, a vehicle, boat, trailer or other appliance or any other area or location. 
    Controlled substance shall mean any drug, substance or immediate precursor in Minn. Stats. § 152.02 Schedules I through V together with any amendments or modifications thereto. The term shall not include distilled spirits, wine, malt beverages, intoxicating liquors or tobacco. 
    Hazardous waste shall mean waste generated from a clandestine drug lab operation. 
    Manufacture, in places other than a pharmacy, shall mean and include the production, cultivation, quality control, and standardization, by mechanical, physical, chemical or pharmaceutical means, and the packing, repacking, tableting, encapsulating, labeling, relabeling, or filling of drugs. 
    Owner shall mean any person(s), firm(s), corporation(s) or other entity who or which owns, in whole or in part, the land, building, structure, vehicle, boat, trailer or other location associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-203. - Declaration of site and contents as a public health nuisance. 
    All dwellings, accessory structures, buildings, vehicles, boats, trailers, personal property, adjacent property or other locations, associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site are potentially unsafe due to health hazards and are hereby declared to be a public health nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-204. - Law enforcement action. 
    If law enforcement authorities determine the existence of a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site, the site, and all personal property herein, shall be declared a public health nuisance. Law enforcement authorities who identify conditions associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site which may place neighbors, the visiting public, or present and future occupants of the site at risk for exposure to harmful contaminants and other associated conditions are authorized to take the following action: 
(1)  Promptly notify the city building official, child protection, public health authorities and the appropriate enforcement division of the drug enforcement administration of the U. S. Justice Department of the location of the site, and the owner if known, of the conditions found; 
(2)  Treat, store, transport or dispose of all hazardous waste found at the site in a manner consistent with state department of health, Minnesota pollution control and county health department rules and regulations; 
(3)  Issue a temporary declaration of public health nuisance for the affected site and post a copy of the declaration on all doorway entrances to the site or, in the case of bare land, post the declaration in several conspicuous places on the property. This temporary declaration of public health nuisance issued by law enforcement shall expire after the city building official inspects the site and determines the appropriateness of issuing a permanent declaration of public health nuisance; 
(4)  Notify all persons occupying the site that a temporary declaration of public health nuisance has been issued; 
(5)  Require all persons occupying the site to immediately vacate the site, remove all pets from the site, and not return without written authorization from the city building official; 
(6)  Notify all occupants vacating the site that all personal property at the site may be contaminated with dangerous chemical residue; and 
(7)  Secure each doorway entrance to the site to reasonably prohibit people from entering the site without authorization after all occupants of the site have vacated. 
    The obligation to promptly notify the persons and organizations mentioned above may be delayed to accomplish appropriate law enforcement objectives, but only to the extent that public health and child protection responsibilities are not unnecessarily compromised. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-205. - Seizure of property. 
    When the clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site is inside a vehicle, boat, trailer or other form of moveable personal property, law enforcement authorities shall immediately seize it and not allow it to be transported except to a more secure location. In such circumstances, all other requirements of this article shall be followed as closely as possible given the specific type of property in which the site is discovered. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-206. - Action by city building official. 
(a)  Inspection and declaration of nuisance. Within 48 hours of notification that law enforcement authorities have determined the existence of a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site, the city building official shall inspect the site to determine the appropriate scope of a permanent declaration of public health nuisance. Based on the results of the inspection, the city building official or his or her designated representative may then promptly issue a permanent declaration of public health nuisance and a do not enter-unsafe to occupy order for the affected site to replace the temporary declaration issued and posted by law enforcement. A copy of the permanent declaration and order shall be posted on all doorway entrances to the site or, in the case of bare land, shall be posted in several conspicuous places on the property. 
(b)  Abatement order. After the permanent declaration of public health nuisance has been issued and posted, the city building official shall send written notice to the site owner ordering abatement of the public health nuisance. The abatement order shall include the following information: 
(1)  A copy of the declaration of public health nuisance and do not enter-unsafe to occupy order; 
(2)  Information about the potentially hazardous condition of the site; 
(3)  Notification of suspension of the site's rental license if applicable; 
(4)  A summary of the site owner's and occupant's responsibilities under this article; and 
(5)  Information that may help the owner locate appropriate services necessary to abate the public health nuisance. 
(c)  Notice to concerned parties. The building official or appropriate city staff shall also mail a copy of the permanent declaration of public health nuisance, a copy of this article, and a notification of the suspension of the site's rental licensees, if applicable, to the following, but not limited to, concerned parties at their last known address: 
(1)  Occupants or residents of the site if the identities of such persons are known; 
(2)  Neighbors in proximity to the site who may be reasonably affected by the conditions found; 
(3)  The city administrator; 
(4)  The community development director; 
(5)  The city police department; 
(6)  The appropriate enforcement division of the drug enforcement administration of the U.S. Justice Department; 
(7)  The city fire department; and 
(8)  Other city, state and local authorities, such as the city water department, the state pollution control agency, the state department of health, and the department of natural resources which are known to have public and protection responsibilities that are applicable to the situation. 
(d)  Modification or removal of declaration. The city building official is authorized to modify or remove the declaration of public health nuisance after the building official receives documentation from a city approved environmental hazard testing and cleaning firm that holds the necessary federal and state licenses and meets all applicable regulations for hazardous materials site remediation, packaging and shipping stating that the suspected health and safety risks, including those to neighbors and potential dwelling occupants, either do not exist or have been sufficiently abated or corrected to justify amendment or removal of the declaration. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-207. - Site owner's responsibility to act. 
    Within ten business days of the date the abatement order is mailed to the owner of the site, the owner shall accomplish the following: 
(1)  Provide the city building official with written notification: 
a.  That the owner has confirmed that all persons and their pets have vacated the site; 
b.  Of the name(s) of all children who the owner believes were residing at the site during the time period the clandestine drug lab or chemical dump site is suspected to have been at the site; and 
c.  That the site will remain vacated and secured until the public health nuisance is completely abated as required by this article. 
(2)  Contract with one or more city approved environmental hazard testing and cleaning firms to conduct the following work in accordance with the most current state department of health guidelines: 
a.  A detailed on-site assessment of the extent of contamination at the site and the contamination of the personal property therein; 
b.  Soil testing of the site and testing of all property and soil in proximity to the site which the environmental hazard testing and cleaning firm determines may have been affected by the conditions found at the site; 
c.  A complete clean up of the site (including but not limited to the clean up or removal of plumbing, ventilation systems, fixtures and contaminated soil) or a demolition of the site and a complete clean up of the demolished site; 
d.  A complete clean up, or disposal at an approved dump site, of all personal property in the site; 
e.  A complete clean up of all property and soil in proximity to the site which is found to have been affected by the conditions found at the site; 
f.  Remediation testing and follow-up testing, including but not limited to testing of the ventilation system and plumbing, to determine that all health risks are sufficiently reduced, according to state department of health guidelines, to allow safe human occupancy and use of the site and use of the personal property therein and of all property and soil in proximity to the site. 
(3)  Provide the city building official with the identity of the testing and cleaning firm with which the owner has contracted for abatement of the public health nuisance as required above; and 
(4)  Sign an agreement with the city building official establishing a clean up schedule. The schedule shall establish reasonable deadlines for completing all actions required by this article for abatement of the public health nuisance. In determining appropriate deadlines, the city building official shall consider practical limitations and the availability of contractors in approving the schedule for clean up. 
    The site owner must meet all deadlines established on the clean up schedule. Also, pursuant to the deadlines established by the clean up schedule, the site owner is required to provide the city building official with written documentation of the clean up process, including a signed statement from a city approved environmental hazard testing and cleaning firm that the site, all personal property therein and all property and soil in proximity to the site, is safe for human occupancy and use and that the clean up was conducted in accordance with the most current state department of health guidelines. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-208. - Site owner's responsibility for costs. 
    The site owner shall be responsible for all costs, including those of the city, of dealing with and abating the public health nuisance, including contractor's fees and the city's costs for services performed in association with the clandestine drug lab site or chemical dump site clean up. The city's costs may also include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  Posting of the site; 
(2)  Notification of affected parties; 
(3)  Securing the site, providing limited access to the site, and prosecution of unauthorized persons found at the site; 
(4)  Expenses related to the recovery of costs, including the assessment process; 
(5)  Laboratory fees; 
(6)  Clean up services; 
(7)  Administrative fees; 
(8)  Legal fees; and 
(9)  Other associated costs. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-209. - City action and recovery of costs. 
(a)  If the building owner fails to comply with any of the requirements of this article, the city building official is authorized to take all reasonable actions necessary to abate the public health nuisance including, but not limited to, contracting with a city approved environmental hazard testing and cleaning firm that holds the necessary federal and state licenses and meets all applicable regulations for hazardous materials site remediation, packaging and shipping in order conduct the work outlined in section 22-207(2) of this article. The building official is also authorized to provide a copy of the declaration of public health nuisance to the lien and/or mortgage holders of the affected site to help assure that persons with interest in the site have access to information about the declaration of public health nuisance. 
(b)  If the costs to clean the site or to clean the personal property at the site are prohibitively high in relation to the value of the site or the personal property, the city is authorized to remove or demolish the site, structure or building and/or dispose of the personal property therein. These actions shall be taken in accordance with the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 463 together with any amendments or modifications thereto. 
(c)  If the city abates the public health nuisance, in addition to any other legal remedy, the city shall be entitled to recover all of its out of pocket costs plus an additional 25 percent of such costs for administrative and legal expense. The city may recover costs by civil action against the owner of the site or by assessing such costs as a special charge against the site as taxes and special assessments are certified and collected pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 429.101 or according to the provisions of Minn. Stats. ch. 463 together with any amendments or modifications thereto. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-210. - Recovery of costs from persons causing damage. 
    No provisions of this article are intended to limit the site owner's, resident's or the city's right to recover costs incurred under this article from either the persons contributing to the public health nuisance, such as the operators of the clandestine drug lab, and/or from other lawful sources. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-211. - Site owner and address. 
    When the site is real property and the owner or the address of the owner of the site is unknown, the owner and the owner's address is deemed to be that of the property's taxpayer's name and address as that information is maintained by the county auditor's office. When the site is a vehicle, boat or trailer and the owner or the address of the owner of the site is unknown, the owner and the owner's address is deemed to be that of the person on file as the owner on the current or most recent title to the vehicle, boat or trailer. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-212. - Suspension of residential rental license. 
    Upon issuance of a permanent declaration of public health nuisance, any residential rental license issued by the city for the site, or any part thereof, is hereby declared to be immediately suspended pending full compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-213. - Unauthorized removal of postings. 
    It is unlawful for any person, except authorized city personnel, to remove a temporary or permanent declaration of public health nuisance and/or do not enter-unsafe to occupy order from a chemical dump site or a clandestine drug lab site. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-214. - Entry into or onto site. 
    While a declaration of public health nuisance for an affected site is in effect and has been posted at the site, no persons are permitted to be inside the site, or on the site property without prior written consent of the city building official or as otherwise authorized by this article. To confirm compliance with this article and to execute their duties under this article, law enforcement officers, the city building official, and any persons designated by the building official, may enter onto the site property or enter into the site at any time while a declaration of public health nuisance is in effect for the site. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 18-215. - Removal of personal property from the site. 
    While a declaration of public health nuisance for an affected site is in effect and has been posted at the site, no personal property may be removed from the site without prior written consent from the city building official. Consent to remove personal property shall only be granted at the reasonable discretion of the building official, and only in cases of hardship after: 
(1)  A city approved environmental hazard testing and cleaning firm has advised the city, in writing, that the item(s) of personal property can be sufficiently cleaned to remove all harmful contamination; and 
(2)  The owner of the personal property agrees in writing: 
a.  That the owner is aware of the danger of using the contaminated property; 
b.  That the owner will thoroughly clean the property to remove all contamination before the property is used; and 
c.  That the owner releases and agrees to indemnify the city, its staff, and the city council from all liability to the owner and/or third persons for injuries or damages caused, or alleged to have been caused, by the contaminated property. 
(Ord. No. 04-29, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC SAFETY 800 MHZ RADIO BUILDING AMPLIFICATION SYSTEM 

Sec. 18-216. - General. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no person shall erect, construct, change the use of or provide an addition of more that 20 percent to, any building or structure or any part thereof, or cause the same to be done which fails to support adequate radio coverage for the Minnesota Regional Radio Communications System, including but not limited to firefighters and police officers. This section shall not apply to: buildings of less than 8,500 square feet; or any building constructed of wood frame; provided none of the aforementioned buildings make use of any metal construction or any below grade levels or parking areas. Any part of any R-3 occupancy building, including below grade levels and parking areas, are exempt from the requirements of this section. For the purposes of this section, parking structures and stairwells are included in the definition of "building" and stair shafts and elevators are included in the definition of "all parts of the building". For purposes of this section, adequate radio coverage shall be an average received field strength of no less than -93 dBm, or one percent BER, measured at 30 to 36 inches above the floor over 90 percent of the area of each floor and other critical areas determined by the fire chief or the fire chief's designee such as fire command centers, stairwells, elevators, high hazard areas, basements, and parking areas. Without an in-building radio system, only the received signal level standard must be achieved as the talk out path is equivalent to the talk in path in this regional radio system. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 18-217. - Amplification systems allowed. 
    Buildings and structures which cannot support the required level of radio coverage shall be equipped with either a radiating cable system or an internal multiple antenna system with or without FCC type accepted bi-directional 800 MHz amplification as needed. If amplification is used in the system, all required FCC authorizations must be obtained prior to the use of the system. If any part of the installed system or systems contains an electrically powered component, the system shall be capable of operating on an independent battery and/or generator system for a period of at least 12 hours without external power input. The battery system shall automatically charge in the presence of an external power input. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 18-218. - Testing procedures. 
(a)  Acceptance test procedure. With or without an in-building radio system, it will be the building owner's responsibility to have the regional radio system performance tested to ensure that two-way coverage on each floor of the building is a minimum of 90 percent of the total floor area and the critical areas designated. 
(1)  Talk-in from the regional radio system coverage testing. 
a.  The talk-in coverage testing process shall be the same for buildings with and without in-building amplification systems. 
b.  During test measuring, the center of the test equipment receive antenna shall be between 30 and 36 inches above the floor. 
c.  On each floor of a building to be tested, the floor space, except for designated critical areas, shall be divided into square or rectangular areas of approximately the same size and shape. Each floor shall have at least ten grid areas; however, the maximum size of grid areas shall not exceed 2,500 square feet. In buildings with support columns laid out in a grid, the corners of the each grid may be arranged at the columns for ease in identifying grid corners while testing is in progress. In buildings, such as a warehouse, with large open areas, tests shall be conducted near the center of each grid although the exact center may not be easily accessible due to the location of large machinery, storage racks, etc. In buildings with divided office spaces, with or without floor to ceiling patricians, tests shall be conducted in an office at or near the center of a grid. In buildings with a large open area and an attached two-story, split level office or other area, the lower level of the two-story, split level attachment shall be considered as an extension of the large open area. 
d.  In multi-story buildings and parking ramps, testing shall begin at the lowest level, including any subgrade level(s), and continue up one floor at a time. In-building amplification may only be required on the lowest level or levels of a multi-story building or parking ramp. 
e.  Average radio signal field strength shall be measured and recorded in each grid, and in each designated critical area defined above. Average field strength may be obtained through use of an instantaneous measuring instrument and a computer that samples the actual field strength at very short time intervals and averages the sample values. As an alternative, a field strength measuring instrument with an analog or digital readout of average field strength may also be used. Measurements shall be made while the measuring instrument is moved over a distance of four to ten feet. If the average field strength varies over the measurement path, the lowest (most negative) value shall be recorded. The test instrumentation used shall have been calibrated within the six-month period prior to the testing. 
f.  The percentage of area passed shall be calculated as 100 times the result of dividing the number of grids and critical areas that are at least at -93 dBm or one percent BER by the total number of grids and critical areas tested. 
g.  The donor antenna in an in-building amplification system may receive up to 87 800 MHz radio frequencies of approximately equal field strength from the regional system, plus some others of approximately equal field strength from other radio systems. At any time, the donor antenna may be receiving at least 60 radio frequencies of approximately equal level in the pass band ranges. For that reason, it shall be assumed that the output level of talk-in amplifiers will be at + 3.2 dBm per channel maximum. Therefore, grid and critical areas tests shall be conducted while the head end amplifier is disconnected and a signal of + 3.2 dBm is inserted into the connector downstream from the headend amplifier. 
h.  Any in-building talk-in amplification system shall have pass band filters before the input to the first (headend) amplifier that shall pass 806 to 817 MHz and 821-824 MHz only. In the future, within six months after notification by the fire chief or his designee, the pass band filter frequency range shall be changed in accordance with instructions, or an additional pass band filter for 700 MHz band frequencies shall be added. When the donor antenna is installed, the average signal level received on the Hennepin East site control channel shall be measured at the antenna connector. A signal at that average received signal level shall be inserted into the cable to the headend amplifier and filter while the output level of the headend amplifier is measured, and the output level of the amplifier shall be set at + 29 + 1 dBm. 
i.  Alternative in-building amplification systems that do not involve broadband pass band filters will be accepted provided that similar testing can be demonstrated. 
(2)  Talk-out to the regional radio system testing. 
a.  With an in-building amplification system, the talk-out (to the regional 800 MHz radio system) shall be measured at the same grid and critical area locations as the talk-in measurements were made. The measurements shall be made using a three-Watt portable radio with a well-charged battery to transmit into the in-building radio system while field strength is measured out of the connector that is normally attached to the donor antenna. To pass, the field strength at the donor antenna shall be the measured value at the connector plus the donor antenna gain and minus a free space loss factor. The free space loss factor shall be -93 dB for a distance of one mile to the nearest Hennepin East base radio location, adjusted by 6 dB each time the distance is halved or doubled. The acceptable range for passing shall be between -65 and -95 dBm. 
b.  Gain values of all amplifiers shall be measured and the test measurement results shall be kept on file with the building owner so that the measurements can be verified each year during the annual tests. In the event that the measurement results become lost, the building owner will be required to rerun the acceptance test to reestablish, the gain values. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 18-219. - Annual tests. 
    When an in-building radio system is required, the building owner shall test all active components of the system, including but not limited to amplifiers, power supplies and backup batteries, a minimum of once every 12 months. Amplifiers shall be tested to ensure that the gain is the same as it was upon initial installation and acceptance. Backup batteries and power supplies shall be tested under load for a period of one hour to verify that, they will properly operate during an actual power outage. If within the one-hour test period, in the opinion of the testing technician, the battery exhibits symptoms of failure, the test shall be extended for additional one-hour periods until the testing technician confirms the integrity of the battery. All other active components shall be checked to determine that they are operating within the manufacturer's specifications for the intended purpose. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 18-220. - Five-year tests. 
    In addition to the annual test, the building owner shall perform a radio coverage test a minimum of once every five years to ensure that the radio system continues to meet the requirements of the original acceptance test. A radio test shall also be performed whenever there is a change in or to the building that may have an impact on coverage. Examples of the types of changes that may change radio coverage are interior remodeling that adds and/or changes partitions, removal of windows, and the addition of metalized treatment to window surfaces. The procedure described in section 18-218(a)(1) shall be used for these tests. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 18-221. - Qualifications of testing personnel. 
    All tests shall be conducted, documented and signed by qualified and competent personnel that includes: persons in possession of a current FCC license, or a current technician certification issued by the Associated Public-Safety Communications Officials International (APCO) or the Personal Communications Industry Association (PCIA), or a qualified radio engineer licensed as a registered professional engineer by the State of Minnesota. Testing personnel shall have test equipment that is appropriate for the testing procedure, and that test equipment shall have been calibrated within six months prior to the testing. All test records shall be retained on the inspected premises by the building owner and a copy shall be submitted to fire department officials. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Sec. 18-222. - Field testing. 
    Fire and police personnel, after providing reasonable notice to the owner or the owner's representative, shall have the right to enter onto the property to conduct testing to be certain that the required level of radio coverage is present. 
(Ord. No. 06-03, § 1, 2-6-2006) 
Chapter 20 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- State criminal code, Minn. Stats. ch. 609. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Adoption of Minnesota Clean Indoor Air Act by reference; prohibition on use of e-cigarettes in enclosed public areas. 
(a)  The provisions of Minn. Stats. §§ 144.411 to 144.417, as they may be amended from time to time, with reference to the definition of terms and prohibitions on smoking, are hereby adopted by reference and are made a part of this article as if set out in full. It is the intention of the city council that all future amendments or additions to the referenced statutory sections are hereby adopted by reference or referenced as if they had been in existence at the time this provision is adopted. 
(b)  The use of e-cigarettes or similar devices is hereby prohibited in all enclosed public areas. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, "enclosed public area" means any building, structure, or vehicle under the primary control of the city or other public entity, including without limitation the city's government center, library, community center, fire stations, public works facilities, polling places, public school facilities, or vehicles. 
(Code 1984, § 970:10; Ord. No. 13-22, § 1, 11-18-2013) 
Cross reference- Tobacco, § 10-571 et seq. 
Secs. 20-2-20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PROPERTY 

Sec. 20-31. - False advertising. 
    Any person who, with intent to sell or in any way dispose of merchandise, securities, service or anything offered by such person, directly or indirectly, to the public, for sale or distribution, or with intent to increase the consumption thereof, or to induce the public in any manner to enter into any obligation relating thereto, or to acquire title thereto, or any interest therein, makes, publishes, disseminates, circulates or places before the public or causes, directly or indirectly, to be made, published, disseminated, circulated, or placed before the public in the city in a newspaper or other publication having circulation in the city, or in the form of a book, notice, handbill, poster, bill, label, circular pamphlet, or letter, or in any other way, an advertisement of any sort regarding merchandise, securities, service or anything so offered to the public, which advertisement contains any assertion, representation or statement of fact which is untrue, deceptive or misleading, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Code 1984, § 905:00) 
Sec. 20-32. - Malicious destruction. 
(a)  Every person who shall willfully or maliciously displace, remove, injure or destroy any of the following shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with section 1-13: 
(1)  A highway, or a private way laid out by authority of law, or a bridge upon such public or private way. 
(2)  A tree, rock, post, or other monument which has been erected or marked for the purpose of designating a point in any boundary or any mark or inscription thereon. 
(3)  A mileboard, milestone, or guidepost erected upon a highway, or any inscription thereon. 
(4)  A line of telecommunications or telephone, or any part thereof, or any appurtenance or apparatus connected with the working of any magnetic or electric telephone or telegraph, or the sending or conveyance of messages thereby. 
(5)  A pipe or main for conducting gas or water or heat or any works erected for supplying buildings with gas or heat or water, or any appurtenance or appendage connected therewith. 
(6)  A sewer or drain, or a pipe or main connected therewith or forming a part thereof. 
(b)  Any person who shall destroy, or damage with intent to destroy or render useless, any engine, machine, tool, or implement intended for use in trade or husbandry, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1984, § 905:10) 
Sec. 20-33. - Injuring cultivated areas. 
    Every person who shall willfully, without lawful authority or consent, enter without the consent of the owner or occupant, with intent to take, injure or destroy anything there grown or growing, any orchard, fruit garden, vineyard, garden, field, or ground whereon is cultivated or growing any fruit or vegetable shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Code 1984, § 905:15) 
Sec. 20-34. - Taking electric current or telephone service. 
    Any person who shall do any of the following shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in section 1-13: 
(1)  Willfully make any connection with any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, or other apparatus belonging to any person using or engaged in the manufacture, supply, sale or distribution of electricity or of electric current, for the purpose of taking, using or wasting such electricity or electric current. 
(2)  Willfully prevent an electric meter from duly measuring or registering the quantity of electricity supplied, or in any way interfere with its proper action or just registration. 
(3)  Without the consent of such person described in subsection (1) of this section, willfully convert any electrical current or power of such person or in any way willfully use or cause to be used without the consent of such person any electricity manufactured or distributed by such person or aid, counsel, employ, or conspire with any other person to do any of such acts. 
(4)  Deposit in any electric meter or other apparatus used by an electric light or telephone company for the pre-payment of current of service any token, article or device, except lawful coin of the United States, for the purpose of fraudulently obtaining such current or service. 
(Code 1984, § 905:35) 
Sec. 20-35. - Trespass generally; trespass by animals. 
(a)  No person shall occupy or be upon the premises, building, land or personal property of another without the consent of one who has the right to give consent, except in an emergency situation. 
(b)  No person shall permit an animal under his control to perform any of the prohibited acts set forth in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The owner of an animal that commits an act prohibited by this section shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1984, § 905:60) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6. 
Sec. 20-36. - Public drinking. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall, in any of the areas specified in subsection (b) of this section, consume any alcoholic beverage or possess any alcoholic beverage in any container which is or has been opened, or the seal broken, or the contents of which have been partially removed. 
(b)  The prohibited activities described in this section shall apply to the following areas in the city: 
(1)  All property owned by the public or for its benefit including, but not limited to, lakes and schoolgrounds. 
(2)  Any outdoor area of privately owned, residentially zoned property on which permission for such activity has not been granted by a person who has the right to give such permission. If such permission is granted, such person shall be responsible for such activity, shall be present for the duration thereof and shall be liable for any violation of law or ordinance arising therefrom. The terms of this subsection (2) do apply to property zoned R-B, but do not apply to property on which a religious institution is located. 
(3)  Any outdoor area of a religious institution or property zoned other than residential, unless such activity has been approved in advance by the city council, which may impose on the activity such limitations as it deems necessary to preserve the health, safety, or welfare of the public. A violation of any such limitation shall be a violation of this section. 
(4)  The parking lot or lots adjacent to any private businesses. 
(c)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcoholic beverage is defined as set forth in Minn. Stats. ch. 340A. 
Outdoor area means any place not enclosed and covered by a roof, and shall include such things as tents and covered patios. 
Possess means to have on one's person or within the control or easy access of a person. 
(d)  The terms of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Parks and park property for which a duly adopted rule, regulation, ordinance or statute provides regulation of the subject matter of this section. 
(2)  Streets and highways for which a duly adopted rule, regulation, ordinance or statute provides regulation of the subject matter of this section. 
(e)  Any alcoholic beverage and its container consumed or possessed in violation of this section shall be seized and impounded as evidence of violation of this section. Such evidence shall be destroyed by the police department upon a plea or finding of guilt with regard to any of such violations. 
(Code 1984, § 905:65) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 4. 
Sec. 20-37. - Trespass to consume alcohol or controlled substances. 
(a)  No person shall enter upon or bring a motor vehicle onto the land of another to consume or facilitate the consumption of any alcohol or controlled substance without the invitation, express consent, endorsement or ratification of an owner of the land. 
(b)  Factors to be considered in determining the purpose of an uninvited entry of a person or motor vehicle shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Time of day; 
(2)  Presence of containers intended to contain or containing alcohol; 
(3)  Presence of equipment used to dispense alcoholic beverages; 
(4)  Presence of paraphernalia containing identifiable residues of a controlled substance; 
(5)  Noise level; 
(6)  Lighting; 
(7)  Identified physiological responses; and 
(8)  Conduct of persons in the presence of a peace officer. 
(c)  A landowner who expressly consents to, endorses, or ratifies an entry onto land shall not be presumed to be in control of the persons gathered on land, nor is the landowner presumed to have knowledge of an unlawful act merely because of the express consent, endorsement, or ratification. 
(Code 1984, § 905:75) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 4. 
Sec. 20-38. - Use of public waters by aircraft. 
    No person piloting an aircraft of any kind, type or description, except such aircraft as may be in imminent danger, may use any of the public waters within the corporate limits of the city for any purpose whatsoever, except as otherwise permitted by law. 
(Code 1984, § 910:00) 
Sec. 20-39. - Illegal possession of tools and weapons. 
(a)  No person shall have in a motor vehicle, or in his possession, or concealed or furtively carried on his person, any instrument, tool or other implement for picking locks or pockets. For purpose of this section, the phrase "instrument, tool, or other implement" shall include, but not be limited to, controlled paraphernalia as defined in Minn. Stats. § 152.01 and dangerous weapons as defined in Minn. Stats. § 609.02, subd. 6. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, dangerous weapons include, but are not limited to, any device designed as a weapon and capable of producing death or bodily harm. 
(c)  The presence of the registered owner of a motor vehicle in which is found any such prohibited tool car weapon shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section by the registered owner. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement personnel acting within the scope of their employment. 
(Code 1984, § 935:00) 
Sec. 20-40. - Fishing on Arbor Lake, West Arbor Lake, and North Arbor Lake prohibited. 
(a)  Fishing prohibited. All fishing on Arbor Lake, West Arbor Lake, and North Arbor Lake shall be prohibited. Fishing means any method utilized in attempting to catch fish, including but not limited to, fishing with fishing poles, nets, and any other device used in catching fish. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person violating subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a petty misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 05-22, §§ 1-4, 8-1-2005; Ord. No. 05-47, § 1, 12-5-2005; Ord. No. 08-02, § 1, 1-22-2008) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-22, §§ 1-4, adopted Aug. 1, 2005, did not specify a manner of inclusion of its provisions within the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 20-40 was at the editor's discretion. Ord. No. 05-47, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2005, extended Ord. No. 05-22, and therefore the provisions of § 20-40 of the Code, an additional six months. 
Secs. 20-41-20-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PUBLIC PEACE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-61. - Disorderly conduct. 
    Each of the following acts, done without authority of law by any person, is hereby declared to be disorderly conduct: 
(1)  The use of profane, vulgar, or indecent language in or about any public building, store or place of business or upon any public property so as to be audible and offensive. 
(2)  Lurking, lounging, loitering, or being concealed in, upon, or near the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, sidewalks or other public places, public grounds, and public buildings; places of amusement, entertainment or refreshment; vacant lots, parking lots, or other unsupervised places; or any property, whether public or private, not his own, when: 
a.  Such conduct results in the making of any noise, riot, disturbance or improper diversion to the annoyance or disturbance of another; 
b.  Such conduct tends reasonably to or is likely to arouse alarm, anger, fear, or resentment in another; 
c.  Such conduct is with intent to do any mischief or to commit any crime or unlawful act; or 
d.  One is part of a group or crowd in, upon, or near any street, sidewalk, or public place in the city so as to obstruct public travel or movement thereof. 
(Code 1984, § 966:00) 
Sec. 20-62. - Loitering; police order to disperse. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone or with others in a public place in such manner so as to violate any following provisions: 
(1)  No person shall obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or other public place or building by hindering or impeding or an act tending to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians. 
(2)  No person shall commit, in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or other public place or building, any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk, or other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress therein, thereon and thereto. 
(3)  No person shall loiter, stand, sit or lie in or upon any public property, private sidewalk, street, curb, crosswalk, walkway area, parking lot, mall, or other portion of private property open for public use, so as to unreasonably block, obstruct, or hinder free passage of the public. 
(4)  No person shall, without consent of the owner of occupant, unreasonably block, obstruct, or hinder free access to the entrance of any building or part of a building open to the public. 
(b)  When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (a) of this section and is ordered by the owner, agent, manager, or person in charge of the premises, or by a police officer or any law enforcement officer, to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse, any person who fails or refuses to obey such an order or returns to the premises within 24 hours after having been so requested or ordered to vacate shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1984, § 965:00) 
Sec. 20-63. - Dangerous weapons. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section the following terms shall have the following meaning: 
(1)  "Dangerous weapon" includes the following which are specifically designed as a weapon and capable of producing death or bodily harm, or any other device or instrumentality which in the manner it is used or intended to be used, is calculated or likely to produce death or bodily harm: 
a.  Firearms, where any device from which is propelled a missile, projectile or other mass through a barrel by means of explosives, gas, air, or spring devices. Firearms include, but are not limited to shotguns, rifles, air guns, pellet guns, BB guns, pistols, revolvers, slingshots, blow-guns and bows and arrows; 
b.  Paint ball guns; 
c.  Artificial knuckles or other objects designed to be worn over the fist or knuckles; 
d.  Daggers, dirks, stilettos, switch blade knife, spring blade knife, push button knife or figures or discs with sharpened points or edges; 
e.  Japanese or other night sticks, nunchaku, chaka, flail, karate sticks; 
f.  Sabre, swords, spears, lances; 
g.  Blackjacks, sand clubs, sap, sap gloves, pipe club, bludgeon, mace club. 
(2)  "Explosive" means an "explosive device" or "incendiary device" as defined in Minn. Stats. § 299F.72. 
(3)  "Possess" or "possession", or any derivative thereof, shall mean a person who possess or is in possession of a dangerous weapon, but excluding a pistol where a person has been issued a permit pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 624.714, and is in compliance with the law. 
(b)  Discharge prohibited. Except as herein specifically authorized, it shall be unlawful to hunt with, shoot, discharge or use a dangerous weapon within the corporate limits of Maple Grove. It shall also be unlawful for any person to be under the influence of alcohol, narcotics or any other drug when hunting or discharging a dangerous weapon. 
(c)  Aiming prohibited. The aiming or pointing of any dangerous weapon, whether loaded or not, at or towards any human being is prohibited. 
(d)  Concealed weapons . The possession by any person other than a public officer of any dangerous weapon concealed or furtively carried on a person is prohibited. This does not preclude a person from carrying a firearm when that person possesses a valid permit to carry under Minn. Stats. § 624.714, or possessing explosive devices under a valid permit issued by the department of public safety, the chief of police, or the department of conservation. 
(e)  Reckless handling or use of a dangerous weapon or explosive. It shall be unlawful to recklessly handle or use a dangerous weapon or explosive so as to endanger the safety of another. 
(f)  Discharge exceptions. Discharge of a dangerous weapon is authorized under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Persons duly authorized to act as a law enforcement officer as defined by Minnesota Statutes, or members of the military forces of the United States or the State of Minnesota in the discharge of their duties. 
(2)  Firearms or bow and arrows may be discharged on any approved shooting range, gun club or gun range operating under a permit issued by the city council under section 10-121 of the Maple Grove City Code, or within any county or regional park while participating under a permit or license for target practice or a special hunting program established by the county or park board. 
(3)  Bow and arrows may be used on school or city property in connection with an organized school or recreation class provided the arrows used shall be equipped with blunt tips (also known as "field points" or "target arrows"). 
(4)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to include any firing of a gun or use of other weapons when done in the lawful defense of persons or property or family. 
(5)  Persons involved in lawful hunting, with a valid permit from the chief of police in designated areas within the city. 
(6)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to include any discharge of any device used exclusively for the firing of stud cartridges, explosive rivets or similar industrial ammunition when used for construction purposes. 
(7)  Use of a starter pistol by a person for dog training or the start of any sanctioned athletic event. 
(8)  For military and law enforcement honor guards firing salutes over the graves of deceased persons. 
(9)  No discharge or explosion of any explosive material is allowed unless specifically authorized by permit issued by the department of public safety, or by permit from the chief of police, or by a permit issued by the state department of conservation. 
(10)  Persons engaged in the taking of rough fish by bow and tethered arrow pursuant to subsection 20-63(h). 
(g)  Permit. 
(1)  Hunting is not allowed on privately owned property unless it is done in areas designated by the city council and a permit is issued by the city for such activity. 
(2)  Hunting is not allowed on property owned by another unless the property owner has granted permission or lawful possessor of the property and the hunting is done in areas designated by the city council and pursuant to a permit issued by the city for such activity. 
(3)  This regulation shall not apply to law enforcement personnel acting in the scope of their official duties. 
(4)  Before any person may hunt with, shoot or use a dangerous weapon in a designated area within the city limits, that person shall obtain a permit from the chief of police. 
(5)  The permit shall specify its effective date, its expiration date, the name of the permit tee, the property, the type of dangerous weapon and the activity for which it is valid, and such other data and restrictions as the chief of police shall deem reasonable and necessary. 
(6)  A request for such a permit shall be accompanied by written permission from the owner, occupant, or lessee of the property to engage in the activities for which the permit is requested. 
(7)  No permit or hunting will be allowed by a person under the age of 16 unless the following requirements have been satisfactorily met: 
a.  A person age 14 or 15 that possesses a firearms safety certificate; 
b.  A person age 12 or 13 who possess a firearms safety certificate, and are accompanied by a parent or guardian while hunting, shooting, using or possessing a dangerous weapon. 
(h)  Bow fishing. Persons properly licensed by the state may take rough fish from public and private waters by bow and tethered arrow during the months allowed under state law from sunrise to sundown. The arrow shall be tethered by a line no more than 20 feet in length. Any person bow fishing shall always shoot the tethered arrow directly into the water. Fish, once taken, shall not be returned to any waters, nor shall fish of any kind be left on the banks of any waters or any public or private property. Persons bow fishing shall not trespass on private property. Persons shall not bow fish within 100 feet of any roadway or dwelling, place of business, school, place of worship, or other structure likely to be occupied by people. Persons under the age of 12 shall be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(i)  Furnishing a dangerous weapons to minors. No person shall sell, give, loan, or in any way furnish any firearm, ammunition, or dangerous weapon to a minor under the age of 18 years without the written consent of the minor's parent or legal guardian, or of the chief of police or a court of law. 
(j)  Transporting dangerous weapons or explosives. 
(1)  A firearm may not be transported unless in compliance with Minn. Stats. §§ 624.714, 624.715, or 97B045. 
(2)  A bow and arrow may not be transported unless in compliance with Minn. Stats. § 97B051. 
(3)  No transporting of explosives can be done unless that person has obtained a permit from the department of public safety, the Maple Grove Chief of Police, or the state department of conservation. 
(4)  All other dangerous weapons, as defined by this section, may not be transported in a vehicle unless they are in the locked trunk or if the vehicle does not have a trunk, in the farthest rear portion of the vehicle not normally occupied by the driver. 
(Code 1984, § 960:00-960:15; Ord. No. 03-26, § 1, 10-6-2003; Ord. No. 07-23, § 1, 12-3-2007) 
Sec. 20-64. - Trespass on school property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remain in or on any public school property after being requested to leave by the school principal or other person lawfully responsible for the control of the premises.
