    No person shall make or cause to be made any connection to the municipal water system unless the property has been fully assessed for water service or there has first been paid to the city for the improvement fund a connection charge equal to the average full assessment in the year prior to the time such connection is made. Where land is divided after special assessment or hookup charge, payment of an additional hookup charge may be required so as to equalize costs. Such sums shall be used to defray improvement costs for maintenance, for depreciation, or for any other purposes deemed appropriate by the city from time to time. 
(Code 1984, § 245:00) 
Sec. 34-33. - Water treatment connection charge. 
    All real property, when connecting to the municipal water system, shall pay a water treatment connection charge as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. The water treatment connection charge shall be paid at the time of the issuance of a permit for connection of the property to the municipal public water system. 
(Code 1984, § 245:01) 
Sec. 34-34. - Water treatment surcharge. 
    All real property that is connected to the municipal water system shall pay a water treatment surcharge as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. The water treatment surcharge shall be payable commencing the date a permit is issued for connection of the property to the municipal public water system irrespective of whether the actual water connection is made at the time of the issuance of the permit. All bills for the water treatment surcharge shall be paid with the quarterly water usage charges. 
(Code 1984, § 245:02) 
Sec. 34-35. - Permit required for connections and other work. 
    No person shall open, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public water line or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the public utilities department of the city pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1984, § 245:03) 
Sec. 34-36. - Persons authorized to work on service pipes and meters. 
    No person except a master plumber duly licensed by the state or a duly authorized employee of the city is permitted to do any work on service pipes or water meters connected with the water system. 
(Code 1984, § 245:06) 
Sec. 34-37. - Connection permit. 
    Application for water service shall be made on printed forms, and shall state the legal description and street and official house number of the premises to be supplied by the water system and the nature of the improvement to be performed. The application for the written permit to hook up to the city water system as referred to in this section shall be made jointly by the master plumber who will make the installation and by the owner of such premises or his authorized agent or by the occupant or person in possession of the premises. The permit shall be issued to the owner and the master plumber applicant, and each applicant by such application shall subscribe to and be obliged to be bound by the city's applicable ordinances and rules and regulations. 
(Code 1984, § 245:09) 
Sec. 34-38. - Tapping charge and deposit. 
    A utility usage deposit shall be paid at the time the permit application is submitted under section 34-37 and before the service is installed. Charges for tapping mains shall be paid at the time of any final inspection required pursuant to this article or chapter 8, article II, before any required certificate of occupancy is issued for the premises and before any water is used. The fees, deposits and charges required by this article shall be as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. 
(Code 1984, § 245:12) 
Sec. 34-39. - Annual fee for service connection. 
    Each premises connected to the city public water supply system shall pay an annual fee for each service connection as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. The fee will be billed quarterly with the city water bills and shall be paid for each quarter or portion thereof the connection continues at the premises. 
(Code 1984, § 245:14) 
Sec. 34-40. - Notification of city prior to making tap. 
    The master plumber requesting a water tap shall give notice at least eight business hours in advance of his need. The master plumber must help uncover the main and locate the tap if requested by the director of public works. 
(Code 1984, § 245:15) 
Sec. 34-41. - Persons authorized to make taps. 
    Only the city crew or persons bearing specific authority by the written permit required under this article shall be authorized to tap into the water lines, and all others are prohibited from doing so. 
(Code 1984, § 245:18) 
Sec. 34-42. - Payment of fees and deposits required prior to turning on water. 
    A permit and inspection fee, as set forth in chapter 16, article IX, shall be paid to the city, and no water shall be turned on until all charges, deposits and fees are paid, including any unpaid usage charges for the premises. 
(Code 1984, § 245:21) 
Sec. 34-43. - Bond for master plumbers. 
    A license or permit bond shall be filed with the city by a master plumber permittee under this article in the sum of $10,000.00 conditioned upon the full, complete, and satisfactory completion of each water hookup installation undertaken by the permittee in the city. If the master plumber permittee is to do his own excavation work, the $10,000.00 bond shall also bond such excavation work so that he need not file a separate bond for his excavation permit required in section 34-45. 
(Code 1984, § 245:24) 
Sec. 34-44. - Insurance requirements for master plumbers and excavators. 
(a)  Insurance requirements for master plumbers shall be as provided in chapter 16, article XII, and section 8-181. 
(b)  Should the insurance coverage provided for in this section be inadequate in amount, then such master plumber shall himself indemnify and save harmless the city and all of its officers and personnel in like manner. 
(c)  Whenever the person receiving a separate excavation permit for the installation of public water pursuant to this article is a different person than the master plumber who has been issued the permit for the project, the excavator shall obtain and supply proof thereof to the city that the excavator is insured in such a manner as to meet all of the requirements of insurance set forth in this section of a master plumber permittee. Such insurance requirements of the separate excavator shall not, however, absolve the master plumber permittee of liability for all acts and omissions, including those of the excavator, which are performed in connection with the water installation for which the permit is granted. 
(Code 1984, § 245:27) 
Sec. 34-45. - Excavation permit. 
(a)  The permit required in this article for the water hookup installation shall not be deemed to authorize any excavation work in connection therewith. Where excavation work is required in conjunction with the work for which the permit is required, a separate excavation permit shall be obtained from the city. An excavation permit shall be applied for on forms provided by the city. 
(b)  At the time of granting such excavation permit, a bond must be filed with the city by the person doing the actual excavation unless such excavation permittee is excused therefor under section 34-43. The bond shall be in the sum of $10,000.00, conditioned upon the full, complete and satisfactory completion of every excavation undertaken in connection with the installation for which the permit is granted. 
(c)  A separate excavation permit fee, as set forth in chapter 16, must be paid for the permit. Excavation permit fees may be established on a single-permit basis or may be on an annual fee basis, and in either instance shall be established by the city council and may be changed in subsequent action of the council. 
(d)  An excavation permit may be issued to persons other than a master plumber and when so issued shall authorize only excavation work in connection with the water installation. When the master plumber permittee intends to perform his own excavation work, he shall comply with all of the separate excavation permit requirements set forth in this section except as may be waived in section 34-43. 
(Code 1984, § 245:30) 
Sec. 34-46. - Ownership of meters. 
    The city shall exclusively own and control the water meters to be used in the water systems. 
(Code 1984, § 245:36) 
Sec. 34-47. - Installation of meters. 
(a)  All water meters in residential homes shall conform to AWWA standards and meet NSF 61 requirements, with annexes; shall meet AWWA C-700 for bronze case; shall be magnetic drive and positive displacement type; shall be equipped with a strainer and frost bottom; shall have a sealed digital register which records in gallons and allows direct visual reading, shall be capable of flagging true reverse flow direction, and shall have leak detection capability; which shall work/function together with radio transmitter units compatible with or capable of communicating with city's Neptune R450 network, or shall be Neptune T-10 meter with Neptune E-coder register and R900 or R450 radio transmitting unit. 
(b)  All water meters shall be installed as follows: 
(1)  The service pipe from the water main to the meter, where the service pipe enters the building, shall be brought through the floor in a vertical position. 
(2)  The meter shall be so located that the bottom is from 12 inches to 18 inches above the finished floor line. The meter shall not be set more than 12 inches, measured horizontally, from the inside line of the basement wall. Deviation from these standards may be made only with written permission of the water superintendent. An approved yoke or horn shall be provided to support the meter in the proper vertical position. Meters larger than one inch shall be set on a pedestal. 
(3)  All meter installations shall have a gate valve on the street side of the meter. In no case shall there be more than 12 inches of pipe exposed between the point of entrance through the floor and the gate valve. A gate valve shall also be installed on the house side of the meter. 
(4)  The water service connecting with the main shall not be run within any structure or under any basement floor for a distance of more than two feet, measured from the inside foundation wall, before being connected to the water meter, except if the service line is run specifically under the concrete basement floor to a designated location shown on the approved plan. If the water service is installed under the concrete basement floor, the point of entry under the foundation must be identified on the approved building plan and the water line shall be installed in a straight line between the point of entry and the location where the service line extends through the concrete floor. 
(Code 1984, § 245:39; Ord. No. 13-04, § 2, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 34-48. - Damaged meters; point of sale replacement. 
(a)  If any meters are damaged by freezing, hot water, etc., either by carelessness or neglect of the owner or occupant of the premises or other agents, the owner or occupants must pay for the repair of such damages. The cost of ordinary maintenance and repair of all meters owned by the city shall be borne by the water department. 
(b)  At the time a residential home is sold or title transfers to another party, the current water user must have the water meter required by City Code section 34-47(a) installed. If the water meter required by City Code section 34-47(a) has not previously been installed, the city will install the required meter with the costs being borne by the water department, to the extent the water meter is readily accessible as required by the Minnesota Plumbing Code. Any costs, expenses, or repairs to make the water meter readily accessible shall be born by the property owner. 
(Code 1984, § 245:42; Ord. No. 13-04, § 3, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 34-49. - Meter tests. 
(a)  At the written request of any water user, the director of public works will test or cause to be tested the meter supplying the premises of such owner or consumer. A deposit in the amount duly established by the council from time to time as set forth in chapter 16, article IX will be required before the meter is disconnected, which will be returned to the owner or consumer if the meter is not found to be registering correctly within three percent; otherwise the deposit so made shall be retained by the water department to cover the cost of such tests. The owner or consumer may, if he desires, be present at the time any such test is made. The result of any such test shall be reported to such owner or consumer in every case. 
(b)  If the testing of a meter, as provided in this section, indicates that it registers in excess of three percent error, the charge to the consumer for water consumed and used during the quarter within which such test is made shall be adjusted in a fair and equitable manner. 
(Code 1984, § 245:45) 
Sec. 34-50. - Obstructing meters. 
    The consumer is prohibited from obstructing the water meter so as to prohibit the reading or repairing of the meter. Without limitation, not having the water meter required by City Code section 34-47(a) is deemed obstructing the water meter. 
(Code 1984, § 245:48; Ord. No. 13-04, § 4, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 34-51. - Misreading or tampering with meters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to misread or to tamper with any meter so as to avoid just charges for water. 
(Code 1984, § 245:51) 
Sec. 34-52. - Bypassing meter or taking water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bypass a meter or otherwise use the water of the city without making just compensation therefor, except as may be specifically authorized in this article. 
(Code 1984, § 245:54) 
Sec. 34-53. - Ownership of stop boxes. 
    The stop box and cover at the water main and boulevard are the property of the city, and all persons are forbidden to interfere with them. 
(Code 1984, § 245:57) 
Sec. 34-54. - Maintenance responsibilities of property owner. 
(a)  The service pipe to the water main and the connections thereto shall be the property of the user. 
(b)  All service pipes and connections to water mains must be protected and maintained by the user. If such user shall fail to make any necessary repairs to such service connections or pipe within 24 hours after being notified to do so by the director of public works, the director of public works shall forthwith disconnect water from the premises. 
(Code 1984, § 245:60) 
Sec. 34-55. - City not liable for damages resulting from interruption of service. 
    The city shall not be liable for any damages resulting from stoppage of the supply or flow of water as the result of breaks in any mains, service pipes, or fixtures, or by reason of the breaking of machinery or stoppage for necessary repair, or any other interruption of service. 
(Code 1984, § 245:63) 
Sec. 34-56. - Access to premises. 
    The director of public works or any authorized employee of the utilities department shall have free access at all reasonable hours to premises to ascertain the location or condition of all hose connections, pipes, and plumbing fixtures. 
(Code 1984, § 245:66) 
Sec. 34-57. - Turning on water without authorization; unauthorized connections. 
(a)  No person shall turn on water to any premises without having written authorization from the utilities department. 
(b)  No person shall turn on water to any premises unless and until a meter has been placed on the service in such manner that it will register all water consumed and all other parts of the plumbing and pipefitting in and about the premises are in full compliance with the rules and regulations of this article and all other lawful rules and regulations. 
(c)  No person shall make any connection with any service pipe which is not in use between the water mains and the meters without obtaining a written permit from the director of public works for the performance of such work. 
(d)  No person shall make any replacement tap or connect any tap or connection theretofore made in any water main without shutting off the water in such old tap or connection at the corporation in the water main. 
(Code 1984, § 245:69) 
Sec. 34-58. - Discontinuance of use. 
(a)  Any person desiring to discontinue the use of municipal water shall notify the director of public works to that effect, who shall have the service at the curb stop box cut off by authorized personnel. 
(b)  No unauthorized personnel shall cut off the water service. 
(c)  Where municipal water has been turned off, a fee, in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article IX will be charged for turning it back on. 
(Code 1984, § 245:72) 
Sec. 34-59. - Lawn sprinkler and irrigation systems. 
(a)  Permit required. All lawn sprinkler systems and irrigation systems connected to the municipal water system, whether such systems are aboveground or underground, shall require a permit for connection and shall be installed in accordance with the plumbing code adopted by reference in chapter 8, article II. 
(b)  Rain-detection device. To conserve water, all lawn sprinkler systems and irrigation systems which are automatic or are equipped to operate automatically, whether installed before or after May 26, 1993, and which are connected to the municipal water system, shall be equipped with a rain-detection device such as the Mini Click 11 rain sensor manufactured by Glen Hilton Products or its equal so as to prevent the system from operating when it rains. 
(Code 1984, § 245:74) 
Sec. 34-60. - Emergency water shortages; emergency board. 
(a)  Because critical shortages of water may result from time to time and such shortage may come about suddenly, emergency procedures are hereby established. These procedures must be followed at all times when the emergency board established by this section or the council determines that an emergency exists. 
(b)  The emergency board shall consist of the mayor, engineer and director of public works. 
(c)  Whenever, in the judgment of any two or more members of the emergency board, the pressures or quantities of water in any part of the water system have become or are about to become inadequate for fire or other needs, a water emergency shall be declared by either posted notice or by public address or both. Thereupon, such restrictions as are found to be necessary shall be in effect until the next and each following council meeting, when such restrictions shall be confirmed or removed if they have not already been removed by the emergency board. Notice of such restrictions shall be published in the legal newspaper at the first opportunity. 
(d)  In addition to penalties otherwise provided, on violation of this section, the engineer or director of public works shall have authority to discontinue service. 
(Code 1984, § 245:75) 
Sec. 34-61. - Cross connections. 
    No water pipe of the municipal water supply shall be connected with any pump, well, pipe, tank or device that is connected with any other source of water supply. When such connections are found, the water department shall notify the owner or occupant to disconnect the connection, and if not immediately disconnected the water supply shall be turned off. Before any new connection to the municipal system is permitted, the water department shall ascertain that no cross connections will exist when the new connection is made. 
(Code 1984, § 245:78) 
Sec. 34-62. - Rates for water service. 
    Water rates shall be in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. 
(Code 1984, § 245:81) 
Sec. 34-63. - Billing; estimated use charge. 
    All bills for water usage shall be paid quarterly. If the water meter required by City Code section 34-47(a) is not installed to measure domestic water usage, the city shall charge the water user an estimated use charge in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. 
(Code 1984, § 245:84; Ord. No. 13-04, § 5, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 34-64. - Meter reading fees; late payment charge; delinquent bills. 
(a)  If an estimated use charge is necessitated, an administrative fee will be assessed in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. 
(b)  A late charge, in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article IX, will be charged if bills are not paid by the due date. 
(c)  If bills are not paid within 30 days from the date of billing, they shall be deemed delinquent. 
(d)  In case of any delinquency, mailed notices shall be sent, and after three days following such mailing the water may be disconnected. 
(Code 1984, § 245:87; Ord. No. 13-04, § 6, 2-4-2013) 
Sec. 34-65. - Lien for unpaid charges. 
    All provisions of this article wherein the term "user" or "consumer" is used shall be construed as including the owner of the premises served. Each owner of premises using water shall be deemed to have agreed, and any delinquencies in the payment for the water usage on the premises shall be a lien and charge against the premises so served regardless of whether the premises are a homestead or not. In case of a delinquency, the lien, including a certification processing fee in an amount set forth in section 16-291, may be certified to the county auditor with the taxes against such property, in the same manner as special assessments on real estate for street improvements, and shall be collected in the same manner as taxes against real estate. Nothing in this section shall change the provisions of the ordinances of the city with reference to cutting off the water for delinquency or any provisions as to the utility usage deposit. 
(Code 1984, § 245:90) 
Sec. 34-66. - Fire protection fees. 
(a)  For the benefit derived from fire protection by any taxpayers in the city, the city shall pay from the general fund into the public utilities fund a sum for water consumed during the year as shall be determined from time to time by the council. 
(b)  In case of fire, no property or user shall be charged for water used in fighting the fire. 
(Code 1984, § 245:93) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention bureau fees, § 16-201 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 18. 
Sec. 34-67. - Use of water from fire hydrants. 
    No person, except a person authorized by the city, shall be allowed to open any fire hydrant in the city for any purpose whatsoever, without first securing a permit from the director of public works. Payment for such water used, except for firefighting, shall be made in accordance with the rate schedule set by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article IX. 
(Code 1984, § 245:96) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 18. 
Secs. 34-68-34-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWER SYSTEM 

Sec. 34-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD and biochemical oxygen demand mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in parts per million by weight. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building well. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or to another place of disposal, serving only the building drain from which the sewage originates. 
    Individual sewage disposal system means a sewage disposal system, other than a public community system, which receives sewage from an individual establishment. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes, as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Inspector means the person employed or engaged by the council and assigned responsibility for administration of this article. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    pH means the negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sanitary sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and which is controlled by a public authority. 
    Raw sewage means sewage which has not been subjected to any treatment process. 
    Sanitary sewage means any water-carried domestic waste, exclusive of footing and roof drainage, of any residence, industry or commercial establishment, whether treated or untreated, and includes the liquid wastes produced by bathing, laundry and culinary operations, and from toilets and floor drains. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating, and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Storm sewer and storm drain mean a sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage but excludes sanitary sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1984, § 340:01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-102. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. Each day that any violation is continued shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1984, § 340:97) 
Sec. 34-103. - Waivers. 
    The council may waive any of the regulations set forth in this article upon a showing that a hardship would result in compliance with this article or that it would be impossible due to land topography to comply with this article. Such waiver, however, shall not be granted unless the council is fully satisfied, after consultations with the engineer and the inspector, that the alternative system for which a waiver is granted will fully satisfy the objectives of this article as set forth in sections 34-112 through 34-118. 
(Code 1984, § 340:99) 
Sec. 34-104. - State regulations for individual sewage treatment systems adopted. 
    The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency Water Quality Division Individual Sewage Treatment System Regulations, one copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, is hereby adopted and confirmed as the public and individual disposal systems regulations of the city and is hereby incorporated in this article as if set out in full. By this section, the city undertakes to provide for administration and enforcement of these standards in the city. 
(Code 1984, § 340:00) 
Sec. 34-105. - Damaging or tampering with sewage works. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the municipal sewage works. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable in accordance with section 1-13. 
(Code 1984, § 340:05) 
Sec. 34-106. - Inspections. 
    The engineer and other duly authorized municipal employees bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 340:10) 
Sec. 34-107. - Liability for expense or damage caused by violation. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1984, § 340:15) 
Sec. 34-108. - Sanitary disposal of waste required; use of private disposal systems. 
(a)  Prohibited deposits of waste. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city, or in any area under its jurisdiction, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  Discharge of polluted water. It shall be unlawful to discharge into any natural outlet or to any storm sewer or storm drain within the city, or in any area under its jurisdiction, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Use of private disposal systems restricted. Except as provided in this article and Hennepin County Ord. No. 19, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  Connection to public sewer required. The owner of each house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purpose, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so, provided that the public sewer is located in the street or alley of abutting property. In the case of malfunction of a private system, the council may require connection in less than 90 days. 
(e)  Discontinuance of use of private system when repair or pumping is needed. The owner of each house, building or property where cesspools and septic tanks have been in existence prior to the construction of the sanitary sewer shall connect with the public sewer when such septic tanks and cesspools are in need of repair, reconstruction or pumping. No septic tanks or cesspools shall be permitted to discharge into any public sewer or natural outlet. 
(f)  Discontinuance of use of private system when public sewer becomes available. At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property previously served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material, if so ordered by the inspector. Unless subsection (d) of this section has been previously invoked, all buildings with public sewer available shall connect to the public sewer within two years after the official notice of sewer availability. 
(g)  Emptying of septic tank into public sewer. As provided in this section only, contents of septic tanks or cesspools may be pumped into the sewer or may be emptied by flowing the contents thereof into a building sewer pipe at the property line provided that a screen is placed at the inlet to the pipe or at the point of suction to prevent obstructions from entering the system. After such draining into the sewer system, the line shall be flushed with clean water for a period of two hours. No solids shall be permitted to enter the sewer system. Written permission must be obtained before pumping or dumping the contents of any septic tank or cesspool into the public sanitary sewer system, as required by this article. 
(h)  Permit for emptying of tanks by scavengers. The emptying of tank contents by scavengers is hereby expressly prohibited except upon obtaining a special permit from the council. Such a permit shall be issued only upon a showing by the applicant that such disposal will not work a detriment or cause the capacity of the system to be exceeded. A fee in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article X shall be charged for such privilege and such disposal shall be subject to inspection by the inspector. 
(i)  Filling of septic tanks. 
(1)  Any cesspool, septic tank or similar tank shall be filled in a manner and with material approved by the city in any one or more of the following instances: 
a.  Whenever a dwelling structure is abandoned or destroyed to an extent as described in and determined pursuant to section 36-6(d). 
b.  Whenever a dwelling structure is removed from its lot. 
c.  Whenever a dwelling structure is moved within its lot and public sanitary sewer service is available as described in subsection (d) of this section. 
d.  At the time any structure previously served by such is connected to the public sanitary sewer system. 
e.  Whenever it is ordered and required of the property owner or occupant by the inspector for the health, safety or welfare of the public. 
1.  The owner or occupant may appeal the order to the city council, in writing, by filing the appeal with the city clerk within five days of the inspector's order. 
2.  The appeal shall be placed before the city council at its next regular meeting. 
3.  Before the appeal is heard and decided, the person appealing the inspector's order shall secure or contain the cesspool, septic tank or similar tank in such a manner acceptable to the inspector as will reasonably tend to secure the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
f.  The council shall hear all testimony and receive all evidence offered by the person appealing and offered by the inspector. After considering all of the evidence and testimony submitted, the council may order such action as it, in its sole discretion, deems appropriate. 
(2)  No filling above the cover level of any cesspool, septic tank or similar tank or any building sewer shall commence until permission has been granted by the inspector's office. 
(j)  Private system required when public sewer is not available. Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 340:20(1)-(11); Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 4-2-2012) 
Sec. 34-109. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-06, § 2, adopted April 2, 2012, repealed § 34-109, which pertained to licensing of private disposal system installers and cleaners and derived from Code 1984, § 340:20(12). 
Sec. 34-110. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-06, § 2, adopted April 2, 2012, repealed § 34-110, which pertained to permits for installation or repair of private disposal systems and derived from Code 1984, § 340:20(13). 
Sec. 34-111. - Standards for private disposal systems. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section shall be to provide minimum standards for, and regulation of, individual sewage treatment systems (ISTS) to protect surface water and groundwater from contamination by human sewage and waterborne household and commercial waste, to protect the public's health and safety, and to eliminate or prevent the development of public nuisances pursuant to the authority granted under Minn. Stats. chs. 115 and 145A and Minnesota Rules chapter 7080 that may pertain to sewage and wastewater treatment. 
(b)  General requirements. 
(1)  Standards adopted. The city hereby adopts, by reference, Minnesota Rules parts 7080.0010 to 7080.0315 and 7080.0919, as allowed under the terms of this section. 
(2)  Failing septic systems. 
a.  A failing individual sewage treatment system shall be upgraded or replaced or its use discontinued within two years, unless it is inspected by a licensed inspector and not found to be an imminent threat to public health and safety. The system may continue to be used until it is found to be an imminent threat to health and safety. 
b.  An individual sewage treatment system posing an imminent threat to public health or safety shall be upgraded, replaced or repaired, or its use discontinued, within an appropriate time no greater than eight months. 
(3)  Additional soil treatment area. All lots created after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, and all lots which are existing on such date, and all undeveloped lots, shall include at least one additional designated soil treatment area which can support a standard soil treatment system. All soil treatment areas shall be protected before, during and after construction on the lot. The method of protection of the additional soil treatment area shall be approved by the building official and may include, but is not limited to, such things as snow fencing, permanent fencing and silt fencing. No building permit shall be issued for construction on any property within the city until at least two soil treatment areas have been identified and protected on all parcels for which a building permit is applied for. 
(c)  Minimum setback distances. Minimum setback distances are as follows: 
(1)  Any water well supply: 50 feet. 
(2)  Water under pressure: Ten feet. 
(3)  Wetlands: 75 feet. 
(4)  Property lines: Ten feet. 
(d)  Modifications to adopted standards; alternative and experimental systems; metering of wastewater. 
(1)  Section 7.080.0130, subpart 3(A), of the standards adopted in subsection (b)(1) of this section is modified by requiring at least two septic tanks with a minimum capacity of 1,000 gallons. 
(2)  Section 7.080.0160, subpart 1(c), of the standards adopted in subsection (b)(1) of this section is modified to require a minimum dosing tank of 1,000 gallons. 
(3)  Section 7.080.0910 of the standards adopted in subsection (b)(1) of this section, specifying alternative and experimental systems, shall be utilized only on existing developed lots with existing septic systems which have failed. Systems designed or installed in a slope greater than 12 percent shall be considered experimental on any lot. 
(4)  All wastewaters discharged into the septic system shall be metered on all non-single-family uses. 
(e)  Issuance of building permits and other licenses and permits. No building permit, certificate of occupancy, license, or other permit shall be issued for construction upon or use or occupation of any parcel of property within the city unless the requirements of this section and Hennepin County Ord. 19 are met with respect to such parcel of property. 
(Code 1984, § 340:21; Ord. No. 12-06, § 3, 4-2-2012) 
Sec. 34-112. - Connection permit required; connection charge; applicability of sewer usage charge. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall make or cause to be made any connection to the municipal sewer system unless such person has first obtained a permit from the city to do so and paid the required fee as set forth in chapter 16, article X. 
(b)  Expiration of permit. 
(1)  A connection permit, when issued, shall be valid for a period of 90 days from and after the date of issuance of the permit. If the installation and hookup is not completed within the 90-day period, the permit shall become invalid unless otherwise extended as set forth in this section. 
(2)  Upon a permit becoming invalid due to the fact that the sewer connection and hookup is not completed, there shall be no refund made for any fees or charges made in connection with the issuance of the permit. Appropriate allowances shall be made upon a reapplication at a subsequent date for any of such charges which were by their nature a deferred assessment of a metropolitan sewer board service availability charge. 
(3)  If the applicant fails to hook up to the sewer system during the period of time the permit is valid, the sewer usage charges referred to in subsection (c)(2) of this section shall cease on the date that the permit becomes invalid and sewer usage charges pursuant to subsection (c)(2) shall be made on a prorated basis for the period of time that the permit was valid. 
(4)  If the 90-day permit validity period should be inadequate and becomes a hardship by its limitation, the permittee may apply to the director of fire and building inspection services for an extension of the period of time for a period not to exceed another 90 days. If the director of fire and building inspection services shall determine that the 90-day limitation period is inadequate and a hardship, he may then extend the time period for which the permit is valid for not to exceed an additional 90-day period. 
(c)  Charges. 
(1)  No person shall use or cause to be used any such connection unless such person has first paid to the sewer fund a connection charge in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article X. The sewer connection charge shall be payable at the time of any final inspection required pursuant to this article or chapter 8, article II before any required certificate of occupancy is issued for the premises, and before any such connection is used. 
a.  Any sums collected as a connection charge under this article shall be deposited in the general funds and shall be used to defray improvement costs, for maintenance, for depreciation, or for any other purposes deemed appropriate by the council from time to time. 
b.  No connections shall be made unless the property has been covered by special assessments for trunks and laterals, or equivalent sums have been paid to the city. 
(2)  A sewer usage charge set forth in chapter 16, article X shall be payable as of the date of the issuance of the permit for the connection of the sewer system into the public sewer system. The issuance of the permit itself shall be deemed to be the actual hookup into the sewer system irrespective of the fact that the permit may allow a specified period of time for hookup and irrespective of the fact that the actual sewer connection hookup may or may not be made immediately at the time of the issuance of the permit. 
(Code 1984, § 340:65) 
Sec. 34-113. - Standards for plumbing work. 
(a)  Interior plumbing work. No plumbing shall be done on the inside of any building except under the direct supervision of a master plumber or by the owner of the building who resides therein when connected with a public sewer. 
(b)  Connection to public sewer. Connection to the public sewer on the exterior part of the building may be made by a master plumber, his agents, a duly licensed contractor as licensed for such construction under the terms of this article or the owners of the building. The exterior building sewer connections shall be made under the terms and conditions set forth in this section, which shall apply to all parties making sewer installations. 
(c)  Permits. The installer shall first obtain a permit as required in this article. 
(d)  Materials and workmanship. The requirements of this article relative to materials and workmanship shall in all cases apply to every installation. 
(e)  Inspection of building sewer. Before covering or backfilling a building sewer, the permittee shall arrange for inspection and approval of such building sewer construction by an inspector or his designated agent. 
(f)  Construction in right-of-way; direct connection to lateral or stub. Occasionally a permittee will be permitted to carry on construction within street rights-of-way or to connect directly to a public sewer lateral or stub if the permittee is a master plumber or, if not a master plumber, is operating under the direct supervision of an authorized city inspector. 
(g)  Construction of building sewer without making connection. In cases where a permittee chooses to construct a building sewer without connecting to either the public sewer or the building drain, such construction shall be permitted if carried out in accordance with this article and provided that, at such time as connection is made to either the building drain or the public sewer, a second permit shall be required and inspection and approval of such additional connection shall be made by the inspector before the connection is covered or backfilled. 
(h)  Demonstration of competency. In cases where the inspector has reason to believe that the owner is not competent to do the plumbing contemplated by this article, the owner shall demonstrate his skill, training, knowledge, and experience to the satisfaction of the inspector. If the inspector concludes that the demonstration is unsatisfactory, the permit shall be terminated and revoked. 
(i)  Standards for building sewer. Building sewer construction shall be in accordance with this article. 
(j)  Safety code. In addition to any other safety factors as set forth in this article, the Industrial Safety Code, being Minnesota Regulations Relating to Industrial Safety, 1964 edition, sections 305 through 315, are incorporated in this section by reference and made a part of this article. Copies shall be available at the city hall, and any violation shall be a violation of this article. In addition thereto, if any person should fail to comply with the requirements of the safety code, the inspector may, by written directive, cause the stopping of all work in the trench until there is compliance, including sheeting and bracing if ordered. Each one-half hour of work in the trench after written directive to stop shall constitute a separate violation under this section. 
(k)  Minnesota Plumbing Code adopted. The Minnesota Plumbing Code, as amended, is hereby adopted and incorporated in this section by reference. All sanitary sewer construction and material shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Minnesota Plumbing Code except as follows: 
(1)  If the distance is farther than 75 feet from the street to the building, a four-inch cleanout pipe must be installed and brought to the surface of the ground from the sanitary sewer service line at a distance not to exceed each 75-foot interval. 
(2)  The diameter of all building sewer pipe must be equal to or less than the diameter of the service stub. 
(3)  All quarter bends used in the sewer lines must be the longsweep of bends. 
(4)  A maximum of only two quarter bends will be permitted in a building sewer without cleanout. 
(5)  No construction of the building sewer will be allowed until the service has been uncovered to establish the maximum building sewer grade. If the distance is farther than 100 feet from the street to the building, grade will be established and maintained by stubs and batter boards. 
(6)  Only joints connected with approved connectors will be allowed connecting the building sewer to the building drain or the building drain to the public sewer. 
(Code 1984, § 340:70) 
Sec. 34-114. - Bond and insurance requirements for sewer connections; excavation permit. 
(a)  Bond. 
(1)  Eligibility for permit; amount of bond. Permits for building sewer connections shall be issued only to a duly licensed master plumber after the plumber has supplied an irrevocable letter of credit to the city in the sum of $10,000.00 conditioned upon the full, complete and satisfactory completion of each sewer installation undertaken in the city, or to the owner of the premises to be served by such connections providing the owner actually occupies the premises as his residence. 
(2)  Excavation permit. 
a.  The permit for the sewer connection to the public sewer system will not, however, permit any excavation work to be performed unless the permit is accompanied by a separate excavation permit granted by the city. An excavation permit shall be applied for on forms provided by the city. 
b.  In order to obtain an excavation permit, an irrevocable letter of credit must be filed with the city by the person doing the actual excavation work. The bond shall be in the sum of $10,000.00, conditioned upon the full, complete and satisfactory completion of each excavation undertaken in connection with the installation of sewers in the city. 
c.  A permit fee for an excavation permit may be established on a single-permit basis or may be on an annual fee basis, at the council's discretion, as set forth in chapter 16. 
d.  An excavation permit may be issued to persons other than a master plumber, and when so issued shall authorize only excavation work in connection with the sewer installation. 
e.  When the master plumber permittee intends to perform his own excavation work, he shall comply with all of the separate excavation permit requirements set forth in this section, except he need not file an additional $10,000.00 bond. 
(3)  Instances where owner must comply with requirements of master plumber. If the owner of the building residing therein is constructing the sewer system as provided in section 34-113, the owner shall obtain the permits and shall comply with all of the requirements made in this section of the master plumber, including those of bonding and insurance. 
(b)  Insurance. 
(1)  Insurance requirements under this section shall be as provided in chapter 16, article XII. 
(2)  Should the insurance coverage provided for in this section be inadequate in amount, then such master plumber shall himself indemnify and save harmless the city and all of its officers and personnel in like manner. 
(3)  Whenever the person receiving the excavation permit to perform work on a sewer installation is a different person than the master plumber who has been issued the permit for the project, the excavator shall obtain and supply proof thereof to the city that the excavator is insured in such a manner as to meet all of the requirements of insurance set forth in this section of a master plumber permittee. Such insurance requirement of the separate excavator shall not, however, absolve the master plumber permittee of liability for all acts and omissions, including those of the excavator, which are performed in connection with the sewer installation for which the permit is granted. 
(Code 1984, § 340:80) 
Sec. 34-115. - Building sewer permits. 
(a)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
(b)  In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city, which form shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information which the engineer may reasonably require. A permit and inspection fee for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and for an industrial building establishment shall be payable in the amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article X. The fee shall be paid at the time the application is filed. 
(Code 1984, § 340:85) 
Sec. 34-116. - Standards for sewer connections and building sewers. 
(a)  Permit card. The city shall furnish a red permit card with the permit number, which shall be prominently displayed on property where a sewer connection is being made. The card shall be displayed for the duration of the work. 
(b)  Payment of costs; indemnification of city. All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city for any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(c)  Separate building sewer required for each building; exceptions. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer except for rate purposes. 
(d)  Use of old building sewers. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the inspector, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1984, § 340:90) 
Sec. 34-117. - Discharges to public sewers. 
(a)  Discharge of unpolluted water to sanitary sewer. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, or runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Permitted discharge of unpolluted water. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such drains as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the council. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon approval of the council, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(c)  Connection of roof and surface water drains to sanitary sewer. No roof or surface water drains shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system of the city. 
(d)  Leaders for roof drainage. Every building without a yard adequate to absorb the surface water collected from such building shall be equipped with proper metallic leaders for conducting water from its roof in such manner as shall protect the walls and foundation from damage, and shall be connected with a public storm sewer wherever there is such a public storm sewer within 50 feet of such building in any abutting street or on private land. Such leaders shall be so placed and such connection shall be so made that no water flows upon any public sidewalk or damages any street abutting such premises. 
(e)  Notice to install roof drainage facilities. Whenever a building does not comply with one or more of the requirements of subsection (d) of this section, the inspector shall serve a notice on the owner of such building requiring him to install the necessary roof drainage facilities and to make connection with a storm sewer as required by subsection (d). 
(f)  Discharge of sanitary sewage into storm drains. No person shall in any way permit any sanitary sewage to flow into any public storm drain from any premises owned by him or under his control. 
(g)  Grease, oil and sand interceptors required; standards. 
(1)  Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand, and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. 
(2)  All such interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the engineer, and shall be located so as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(3)  Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. 
(4)  They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. 
(h)  Maintenance of interceptors. Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(i)  Review by of discharges by engineer. 
(1)  The admission into the public sewers of any of the following waters or wastes shall be subject to the review and approval of the engineer: 
a.  Those having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 300 parts per million by weight; 
b.  Those containing more than 350 parts per million by weight of suspended solids; 
c.  Those containing any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in subsection (g) of this section; 
d.  Those having an average daily flow greater than two percent of the average daily sewage flow of the city; or 
e.  Those failing to meet the current standards of the metropolitan waste control commission or the state pollution control agency. 
(2)  The owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: 
a.  Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 300 parts per million and the suspended solids to 350 parts per million by weight; 
b.  Reduce objectionable characteristics of constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in subsection (g) of this section; or 
c.  Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. 
(3)  Plans, specifications, and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the engineer and the state pollution control agency, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approvals are obtained in writing. 
(j)  Maintenance of preliminary treatment facilities. Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(k)  Control manhole. The owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the engineer. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(l)  Measurements, tests and analyses. All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of water and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with methods employed by the state department of health, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided for in subsection (k) of this section or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(m)  Special agreements for acceptance of industrial waste. No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1984, § 340:95(1)-(13)) 
Sec. 34-118. - Rates for sewer service; billing and collection of charges. 
(a)  Rates generally. The following rates and charges for use and service of the sanitary sewer system are established in the amounts as set forth in chapter 16, article X, such charges and rates to be made against each lot, parcel of land, unit or premises which may have a connection directly or indirectly into the municipal sanitary sewer system and which discharges only normal sewage into such system: 
(1)  A minimum quarterly charge, whether use of water is metered or not. 
(2)  A flat charge where the rate is not based upon the metered use of water. 
(3)  Metered flow charges for all premises where the rate is to be based upon metered use of water. 
(b)  Industrial rates. On each lot, parcel, premises, or unit not enumerated under subsection (a) of this section the use of water shall be metered and the rate shall be the same as that provided in subsection (a)(3) of this section, pertaining to metered flow charges. 
(c)  Metering of water use. A meter recording the use of water may be installed on any nonresidential lot, parcel, premises or unit enumerated in subsection (b) of this section, pertaining to industrial rates, and thereafter the rate shall be based upon such use of water. The council may, by resolution, require and order the installation of such meter on any such lot, parcel, premises, or unit or class thereof where it shall determine that the flat charges are impractical to apply or result in inequitable charges because insufficient or excessive, and thereafter the rate shall be based upon such use of water. 
(d)  Meter installation and maintenance. Any water meter installed for use or used as a basis for the computation of sewer rates shall be installed and maintained in good operating condition at all times, such installation and maintenance to be without expense to the city. Any such meter shall be of a type obtained from the city, and shall accurately measure all water received on the premises. Installation and maintenance of such meter shall be made in accordance with plumbing regulations of the city. 
(e)  Use of extra meters when portion of water does not enter sanitary sewer. If the lot, parcel of land, or premises discharges normal sewage or industrial waste into the sanitary sewage system, either directly or indirectly, and it can be shown to the satisfaction of the council that a portion of the water measured by the water meter does not and cannot enter the sanitary sewer system, then, and in that event, the council may permit or require the installation of other or additional meters in such manner that the quantity of water which actually could enter the sewer system may be determined. In such case, the charges or rates shall be based upon the amount of water which can enter the sanitary sewer system. 
(f)  Required information. The owner, occupant, or person in charge of any premises shall supply the city with such information as the city may reasonably require related to use of water, use of sewers or sewer rates. Willful failure to provide such information or willful falsification of such information shall constitute a violation of this article, as shall willful failure to comply with any requirement or order issued pursuant to this article. 
(g)  Estimated bills. If the owner, occupant or person in charge of any premises shall fail to provide information as provided in subsection (f) of this section, or shall fail or refuse to comply with any requirement of this article, the proper charge for such premises shall be estimated and billed in accordance with such estimate. 
(h)  Proration of charge when beginning service. For a fraction of a quarter, the charges and rates for non-metered units shall be based upon the amount of the established flat charge; provided, however, that the actual month of beginning shall be considered as having begun on the first or 15th of the month, whichever is closer. 
(i)  Billing. Bills for charges for the use and service of the sewer system shall be made out by the city in accordance with the usual and customary practice. All bills shall be payable at the city hall. Bills shall be rendered quarterly. 
(j)  Payment of charges; late fee; collection of unpaid charges. Payment shall be made in accordance with the billings not later than the tenth day of the following month. A ten percent late charge will be charged if bills are not paid by the due date, subject to a minimum charge in an amount duly established by the council as set forth in chapter 16, article X. If bills are not paid within 30 days from the date of billing, they shall be deemed delinquent. In case of any delinquency, mailed notices shall be sent, and after three days following such mailing civil action may be begun on behalf of the city for the collection of the sewage service charge. If such charge is not paid within 60 days after due, the unpaid charge plus penalty, together with a certification processing fee in the amount set forth in section 16-321, may be certified to the county auditor with the taxes against such property and shall be collected with other taxes on such property. 
(k)  Disposition of revenue. All revenues derived from these rates and charges shall be credited to the sewer operating fund. Such revenue shall be used only for the purpose of paying the cost of operating and maintaining the sewage system, payment of Metro Sewer billings, paying charges made by the city, providing an adequate depreciation fund, and paying costs of meter reading, billing, collection, and other similar or related sewer operating expenses, provided that any surplus above such needs may be transferred to the general funds. 
(Code 1984, § 340:95(14)-(24)) 
Secs. 34-119-34-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INDIVIDUAL SEWAGE TREATMENT SYSTEM AND WATER WELL LOAN PROGRAM 

Sec. 34-151. - Purpose. 
    The city recognizes that a need exists to provide for the creation of a loan program to assist property owners to finance the site evaluation, design, installation, repair, and replacement of individual sewage treatment systems and to finance the sealing, replacement and/or repair of wells on privately owned property. 
(Code 1984, § 336:00) 
Sec. 34-152. - Definitions; conflicting regulations. 
    The words and phrases used in this article shall have the meanings set forth in Minn. Stats. § 115.57, subd. 2, and article III of this chapter. In the event of a conflict between Minn. Stats. § 115.57, subd. 2, and article III of this chapter, the more restrictive shall apply. 
(Code 1984, § 336:10) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-153. - Program established. 
    Pursuant to Minn. Stats. § 115.57, the city hereby creates a loan program to accomplish the purposes set forth in section 34-151. Upon approval of a loan application by the city, the city may loan an amount up to $12,000.00 for sewer work and up to $6,500.00 for well sealing, repair, and/or replacement. 
(Code 1984, § 336:05) 
Sec. 34-154. - Loan application. 
(a)  An application for a loan under this article shall be made to the city on a form provided by the city and shall be accompanied by the loan application fee as set forth in this article. 
(b)  The application shall contain, but not be limited to, the following: the full name of the applicant, the applicant's residential address and the legal description and PID number of the property, the applicant's home and business telephone numbers, the nature of the work proposed to be done on the property and the estimated amount to be charged for the work, and any additional information the city deems necessary. 
(c)  To ensure repayment of the loan to the city, as part of the application, an agreement of assessment and waiver of irregularity and appeal form, providing for the placement of special assessments upon the property that is the subject of the loan, shall be executed by applicant and returned to the city as part of the application. No application shall be deemed complete by the city unless and until all information requested is provided to the city. 
(Code 1984, § 336:15) 
Sec. 34-155. - Representations and warranties by property owner. 
    The property owner applying for a loan under this article shall warrant that: 
(1)  The applicants are all of the owners of the property for which the loan is sought, and that they have a legal right to obtain such a loan under the terms required by the city. 
(2)  Any amounts borrowed pursuant to the loan program together with all other outstanding loans and liens on the subject property do not exceed 105 percent of the city assessor's current assessed market value. 
(3)  Any amounts borrowed pursuant to the loan agreement shall be used exclusively for the evaluation, design, installation, repair, and replacement of individual sewage treatment systems and/or the sealing or replacement of water wells on privately owned property. 
(4)  The amount borrowed pursuant to the loan agreement shall not be used to facilitate new building construction which includes increasing the capacity of an individual sewage treatment system beyond what is reasonably required to serve any existing buildings and lots in existing recorded plats. 
(5)  Loans shall be given only for work that will be performed only by a sewage treatment system professional, a well contractor or a limited well contractor, licensed and bonded by the city. 
(Code 1984, § 336:20) 
Sec. 34-156. - Assessments. 
    Any amounts borrowed from the city pursuant to the loan program established by this article shall constitute liens against the subject property, and such amounts shall be specially assessed against the subject property. The property owner shall obtain the necessary consent so that the lien for the loan program shall take a priority interest as to any and all subsequent liens on the subject property. 
(Code 1984, § 336:25) 
Sec. 34-157. - Term for repayment of loan. 
    Any amounts borrowed pursuant to a loan agreement under this article shall be repaid as special assessments levied against the subject property in accordance with the following terms: 
Amounts Borrowed Applicable Special Assessment 
Levy Period Under $5,000.00 10 years $5,000.00 to $10,000.00 15 years Over $10,000.00 20 years  
(Code 1984, § 336:30) 
Sec. 34-158. - Interest rate. 
    The applicable interest rate to be charged under this article on any outstanding principal balance shall be established at the time of the loan. Interest shall begin to accrue from the date of the issuance of the loan proceeds and shall continue until all the outstanding principal is paid in full. 
(Code 1984, § 336:35) 
Sec. 34-159. - Fees. 
    The applicable fee for a loan under this article shall be a one-time charge of $20.00 plus an interest rate charge of 0.5 percent above the established loan interest rate, for life of the loan. The property owner shall have the option of paying the $20.00 fee to the city at the time the loan proceeds are disbursed, or the fee may be added to the principal balance of the loan and be repaid in accordance with the terms of the agreement. 
(Code 1984, § 336:40) 
Sec. 34-160. - Prepayment of loan. 
    The applicant for a loan under this article may prepay the principal amount outstanding in whole or in part up to the special assessment certification date established by the city without interest. Any partial prepayment shall be applied against principal and shall not postpone the due date of any subsequent payments. After the special assessment certification date, any amounts outstanding shall be treated as special assessments against the property and shall be paid off accordingly. 
(Code 1984, § 336:45) 
Sec. 34-161. - Joint liability of applicants. 
    If more than one, the applicants for a given parcel of land shall be jointly and severally liable under the loan program and any agreement executed pursuant thereto shall be binding upon them and their successors and assigns. 
(Code 1984, § 336:50) 
ARTICLE V. - CONNECTIONS AND DISCHARGES TO THE STORMWATER SYSTEM 

Sec. 34-162. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized enforcement officer. The city manager or the city manager's designee, who is authorized to enforce this article. 
    Best management practices (BMPs). Schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly to stormwater, receiving waters, or stormwater conveyance systems. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to control site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
    Clean Water Act. The federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    Construction activity. Activities subject to NPDES construction permits. Currently these include construction projects resulting in land disturbance of one acre or more. Such activities include, but are not limited to, clearing and grubbing, grading, excavating and demolition. 
    Hazardous materials. Any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, that, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Illegal discharge. Any direct or indirect non-stormwater discharge to the storm drain system, except as exempted in section 34-167. 
    Illicit connections. An illicit connection is defined as either of the following: 
(1)  Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, that allows an illegal discharge to enter the storm drain system including, but not limited to, any conveyances that allow any non-stormwater discharge including sewage, process wastewater, and wash water to enter the storm drain system and any connections to the storm drain system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by the authorized enforcement officer; or 
(2)  Any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the storm drain system that has not been documented in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by the authorized enforcement officer. 
    Industrial activity. Activities subject to NPDES industrial permits as defined in 40 CFR, Section 122.26(b)(14). 
    MS4. The municipal separate storm sewer system. 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) stormwater discharge permit. A permit issued by EPA (or by a state under authority delegated pursuant to 33 USC § 1342(b)) that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group, or general area-wide basis. 
    Non-stormwater discharge. Any discharge to the storm drain system that is not composed entirely of stormwater. 
    Person. Any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm, corporation or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner or as the owner's agent. 
    Pollutant. Anything that causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may include, but are not limited to: paints, varnishes, and solvents; oil and other automotive fluids; non-hazardous liquid and solid wastes and yard wastes; refuse, rubbish, garbage, litter, or other discarded or abandoned objects, and accumulations, so that same may cause or contribute to pollution; floatables; pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers; hazardous substances and wastes; sewage, fecal coliform and pathogens; dissolved and particulate metals; animal wastes; wastes and residues that result from constructing a building or structure; and noxious or offensive matter of any kind. 
    Premises. Any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land whether improved or unimproved including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. 
    Storm drainage system. Publicly-owned facilities by which stormwater is collected and/or conveyed, including but not limited to, any roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, gutters, curbs, inlets, piped storm drains, pumping facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and human-made or altered drainage channels, reservoirs, and other drainage structures. 
    Stormwater. Any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water from any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation. 
    Stormwater pollution prevention plan. A document that describes the best management practices and activities to be implemented by a person or business to identify sources of pollution or contamination at a site and the actions to eliminate or reduce pollutant discharges to stormwater, stormwater conveyance systems, and/or receiving waters to the maximum extent practicable. 
    Wastewater. Any water or other liquid, other than uncontaminated stormwater, discharged from a facility. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 34-163. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to all water entering the storm drain system generated on any developed and undeveloped lands unless explicitly exempted by an authorized enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 34-164. - Responsibility for administration. 
    The city manager or the city manager's designee shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 34-165. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this article are hereby declared to be severable. If any provision, clause, sentence, or paragraph of this article or the application thereof to any person, establishment, or circumstances shall be held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect the other provisions or application of this article. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 34-166. - Ultimate responsibility. 
    The standards set forth herein and promulgated pursuant to this article are minimum standards. Therefore this article does not intend or imply that compliance by any person will ensure that there will be no contamination, pollution, nor unauthorized discharge of pollutants. 
(Ord. No. 18-09, § 1, 7-16-2018) 
Sec. 34-167. - Discharge prohibitions. 
(a)  Prohibition of illegal discharges. 
(1)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged into the municipal storm drain system or watercourses any materials, including but not limited to pollutants or waters containing any pollutants that cause or contribute to a violation of applicable water quality standards, other than stormwater. 
(2)  The commencement, conduct or continuance of any illegal discharge to the storm drain system is prohibited except as follows: 
a.  The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions established by this section provided they meet all other requirements of law: water line flushing or other potable water sources; landscape irrigation or lawn watering; diverted stream flows; rising ground water; ground water infiltration to storm drains; uncontaminated pumped ground water; foundation or footing drains (not including active groundwater dewatering systems); crawl space pumps; air conditioning condensation; springs; natural riparian habitat or wetland flows; swimming pools (if dechlorinated - typically less than one PPM chlorine); the application of fertilizers to gardens, trees, bushes, or turf; the application of salt to walkways, parking lots and streets for safety purposes (but not the storage of salt uncovered); composting of leaves and organic materials on turf or garden areas; discharges resulting from firefighting activities; mowing grass (as long as clippings are not discharged to the adjacent roadway); and any other water source not containing pollutants. 
b.  Discharges specified in writing by the authorized enforcement officer as being necessary to protect public health and safety are allowable. 
c.  Any discharge is allowable if approved in writing by the authorized enforcement officer as being a reasonable, incidental and customary use of real property that, when considered by itself or in combination with other similar discharges, will not have a significant effect on surface waters.
